He is unable to accept his homosexuality and his relationship in front of others especially due to cultural context. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Jessica, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: You're doing okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some recent difficulties that brought you into our agency. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about that? ; Patient: Well, I've been having a lot of anxiety lately. ; Therapist: Anxiety? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Just getting really nervous in the morning when it's time to go to work. ; Patient: Just like butterflies in my stomach kind of pounding hard. ; Therapist: So you're anxious when you're getting ready to go to work? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you know what might be causing that? ; Patient: Well, I noticed it a little while ago when I went to get in my car to go to work in the morning. ; Patient: I was putting some stuff in the trunk and I saw some damage that had happened to the car from a previous car accident. ; Patient: And just out of nowhere I started feeling nervous about driving to work. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you went out to your car, you saw some damage, it reminded you of an accident? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I was in an accident at the end of last year. ; Patient: I didn't get hurt. ; Patient: There was no real damage to the car that I noticed. ; Patient: I just went on about my business. ; Patient: I didn't have any issues after the accident. ; Patient: And now all of a sudden I'm thinking about this car accident again. ; Patient: And I don't know where that's coming from. ; Therapist: And you said the accident occurred at the end of last year? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I can't really remember exactly when, but it was cold out when it happened. ; Therapist: So maybe about eight months ago. ; Therapist: Does that sound right? ; Patient: Yeah, around Halloween or so. ; Therapist: When did the symptoms start, being anxious when you're getting ready to go to work? ; Patient: I would say at least a month ago, maybe six weeks. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you've been having those continuously from then? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Every morning I get up, I'm just really nervous about going to work. ; Patient: And I come out to get in the car and sometimes I can barely get in, just thinking about being in a car accident again. ; Therapist: Have you ever been late to work because of the anxiety? ; Patient: I'm late almost every day. ; Therapist: Almost every day? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So this has been a problem for you in a few different ways. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I even called out a couple times because I was just paralyzed. ; Therapist: Have you tried anything to reduce the anxiety, like using another car or anything else? ; Patient: Well, yeah. ; Patient: I live in a house with multiple cars, so I tried driving my mom's car to work one day. ; Patient: And I had the same feelings. ; Patient: And initially I thought it was just my car because I did notice some damage to the back of the car. ; Patient: I was hit in the back. ; Patient: And I was going through the trunk one day and I saw that the car was actually pushed in. ; Patient: I didn't think there was any real damage. ; Patient: Then I noticed damage to the back of the car and I was like, wow, I could have been seriously hurt in this accident. ; Patient: And that's when I started having these feelings. ; Patient: I just started thinking about how bad the accident could have been. ; Patient: So you ask if I tried to do anything different. ; Patient: I tried driving my mom's car. ; Patient: I tried driving my dad's car. ; Patient: But it seems to be just driving any car. ; Patient: I'm having all of this anxiety. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you're having kind of physical distress too. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Like you're feeling it physically? ; Patient: Overwhelmed. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm feeling a lot of swelling in my chest. ; Patient: Like really panicky. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you ever have any dreams about the accident or anything related to the accident? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: Do you ever have any point when you're not asleep where you feel like you're kind of taken back to the time the accident happened? ; Therapist: Like you're reliving it in any way? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Do you remember the accident? ; Patient: Yeah, I remember it pretty well. ; Patient: I was waiting at a stop sign and I think the person behind me, they must not have been paying attention, but they rear-ended me. ; Therapist: Who do you believe is responsible for the accident? ; Patient: Nobody really. ; Patient: I mean, it was an accident. ; Patient: There was no real damage. ; Patient: Accidents happen all the time. ; Patient: It's just a fender bender. ; Therapist: So from the time that you noticed these anxiety symptoms, have you had periods where you were happy and had kind of positive emotional experiences? ; Patient: I've been really down since I started having these symptoms. ; Therapist: Have you been down the whole time? ; Therapist: Have there been moments where you haven't been or has it been consistently down? ; Patient: I would say more down. ; Therapist: More down, but sometimes up? ; Patient: I can't really remember any times. ; Patient: Not sure. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about your relationships with other people? ; Therapist: Have they changed from when the anxiety started? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: Do you feel detached from people? ; Patient: Detached? ; Patient: You mean like separated, like not wanting to be around? ; Patient: Not connecting with people? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: Nothing like that. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about any feelings of irritability or anger outbursts or anything like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you've been behaving in a more reckless way at all? ; Patient: What do you mean by reckless? ; Therapist: Like taking more chances in relationships or another, nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You're aware of like when something surprises us, we kind of have this startle response, like we jump, it's natural. ; Therapist: Have you noticed that response has changed at all? ; Patient: Yeah, I have been a little on edge. ; Patient: Things have been like scaring me, the phone ringing, people knocking at the door, dogs barking. ; Patient: It's kind of had me on edge a little bit. ; Therapist: And you feel like your response is more than it used to be, more than just the natural startle response you had? ; Patient: Yeah, that's kind of worrying me a little bit too. ; Therapist: That's worrying you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any trouble concentrating? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: You've been okay concentrating? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Staying focused has been... ; Patient: Yeah, I'm good in that area. ; Therapist: How about trouble with sleep? ; Therapist: Trouble falling asleep, staying asleep? ; Patient: No trouble falling asleep, but I have had trouble staying asleep. ; Patient: I've been waking up pretty much around the clock throughout the night. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you're getting to sleep okay, you're falling asleep okay, but just having trouble staying asleep. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Are you thinking of anything specific when you wake up? ; Patient: Not really, just maybe like thinking about going to work in the morning and... ; Patient: But no, nothing major. ; Therapist: Any use of drugs or alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about medical problems? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Therapist: Are there ever points from when this anxiety started that you feel kind of outside of your own body, kind of an unreal feeling where you're separated from your own body? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: How about times when you feel disconnected from the environment, like an unreal feeling about what's going on around you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: All right, Jessica, I'm going to get you in to see a counselor here if you're open to that, if that's something you want to do. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And I appreciate you taking the time to tell me what's going on and answer these questions. ; Therapist: It's been helpful. ; Patient: Thank you for seeing me. ; Therapist: Sure.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jessica, sex female ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety and panic attacks chief complaints 1 flashbacks 2 daily routine disturbed 3 sleep disturbances ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech fast n blurry, mood  affect disturbed, thought negative, perception poor, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problems patient experiences anxiety and panic attacks, particularly while driving to work and being reminded of a past car accident. 2 impacts she is always late for work due to her anxiety and even leading to occasional absences due to feeling paralyzed by her symptoms. She has dreams or flashbacks related to the accident which cause trouble staying asleep. 3 acceptance she is willing to see a counsellor for more help. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor

dialogue: Therapist: So this is a Breaking Bad News consultation. ; Therapist: It's a case of a 47 year old man who has been seen by one of my colleagues who had an ultrasound scan requested for some right upper quadrant pain. ; Therapist: And the scan was reported as saying that there was a potential mass in the head of the pancreas so the ultrasound department requested an urgent CT and I'm on call and the facts have just come through to me suggesting that there is a mass in the head of the pancreas and some potential liver metastases. ; Therapist: I have waited until the end of my morning surgery, booked a double appointment and let the girls know not to disturb me now that I'm not on call, and have rung the patient up and asked him to come in, told him that there's something on the scan that we need to discuss, offered for him to bring somebody with him and give him a bit of a warning shot and he's just arrived. ; Therapist: Come in. ; Therapist: Hi! ; Patient: Hi there Doc. ; Therapist: Have a seat. ; Therapist: So we just spoke on the phone didn't we? ; Therapist: My name is Dr. Evers. ; Patient: Right yes. ; Therapist: I know you've previously been seeing my colleague haven't you? ; Patient: Yes, yes I saw Dr O'Donovan and he did that scan for gallstones. ; Therapist: Okay. So, what happened from there then? ; Therapist: Just tell me a little bit about what's happened so that I'm up to speed. ; Patient: I went for that scan and then I was a bit surprised actually. ; Patient: They actually rang me up a few days afterwards and said that I needed another scan to check things out. ; Patient: So I was there, it was on Monday this week, when I went and they put me through that doughnutty thing and then you gave me room. ; Therapist: Okay. So, in between the scan happening and the second scan happening, was it the department that had rung you or had you spoken to Dr O'Donovan about it? ; Patient: No, no it was a nice old sound girl who rang me saying they were booking this appointment for this extra scan. ; Therapist: And did they give you any idea why they needed to do an extra one? ; Patient: No they didn't actually, I mean I tried to ask you always do, and like sweet talk a lady but she was not for telling. ; Therapist: Okay and had you had any thoughts yourself or any worries about why they were calling you back? ; Patient: I guessed it was something in the gallstones. ; Therapist: So just tell me a little bit about what symptoms you've been having then, but we do have your scan result here today and there is something we need to discuss on it. ; Therapist: I'd just like to make sure that I know what's been happening to you first of all and then we'll go into the detail. ; Patient: It all started a few months ago really with this tummy pain and then I saw your colleague and he said we'd better get his scan. ; Patient: So I went for that scan, it was only about two weeks ago and then I got literally four or five days later got the phone call that I needed this additional scan so I went on Monday and had that done. ; Therapist: Okay, and so do you still have pain at the minute? ; Patient: Yes, yeah I mean it's just there all the time. ; Therapist: Okay, well as I said your scan result has come through to me today and I'm afraid there is something that's potentially a little bit worrying on it. ; Patient: Really? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I didn't expect that. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: So what's the worrying thing that you found? ; Therapist: Well, if I take you back to the first scan, first of all, so what it appears that that showed is that there was something suspicious on what we call the pancreas gland. ; Patient: Suspicious? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So there is a gland at the top of your abdomen here which is quite close to your gallbladder and called the pancreas. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And when they did the ultrasound scan which is a good scan but isn't particularly detailed. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: There was something on it that they saw that they wanted a little bit more information ; Therapist: about. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So that's why they called you back for the second scan. ; Patient: Doesn't sound good, does it? ; Therapist: That was a CT scan which is a detailed one so that we could see what it is that we're likely to be talking about. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So this second scan has shown that there definitely is something on your pancreas gland. ; Patient: Really? ; Therapist: And when I say something, what we need to worry about is whether or not this could be a type of cancer. ; Patient: God. ; Patient: I didn't expect that. ; Patient: God. ; Patient: I'm only 47. ; Patient: Cancer. ; Therapist: And I'm really sorry to have to break it to you like this but I felt that it was important that as soon as I knew that I communicated that to you and that you knew what we were thinking as well. ; Patient: God. ; Therapist: So I mean I know that I've just dropped a big bombshell on you. ; Patient: Oh yes, God. ; Therapist: Have you got any questions at the minute? ; Therapist: Have you got anything that you've... ; Patient: Erm, what's the pancreas and if I have got cancer, what can they, can they cut it out? ; Therapist: Erm, it depends. ; Therapist: Basically your pancreas is a gland that sort of sits at the top of the abdomen as I said and it controls some of the sort of the hormones, the fluids that your body makes. ; Therapist: Erm, because it's at the back of the abdomen, often we don't know very much about it until it starts causing a bit of a problem like your pain that you've been getting. ; Therapist: So that probably explains why you've not had many other symptoms as well. ; Patient: Right, right. ; Therapist: Erm, the answer is I don't know what could be done about it but we need to ask a specialist what could be done about it. ; Therapist: What we usually do in this situation is ask a specialist to see your scan and I'll let them know today. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: To have a look at your scan and to see you and to have a think about what this could be. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Do they agree that it could be potentially cancer and how do we find out what it definitely is. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then from that what we do about it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I understand that I've just thrown a whole lot of information at you and that a lot of it is very worrying information. ; Patient: Oh yeah, God, I just hadn't expected that at all. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Erm, I mean is there anybody that you could, that you could bring in with you and we could have another bit of a chat maybe tomorrow when you've had a bit more time? ; Patient: I suppose I could, I'll ask my mum because I hope by myself. ; Therapist: Yeah ; Patient: Erm, no, I'll come by myself actually. ; Therapist: You sure? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: It'll just be easier. ; Patient: She'll just, you know, she'll just flat. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I mean I think it's important to say that we don't know for definite what this is. ; Therapist: We have to imagine that it is something like a cancer until we can prove what it is. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Erm, so we do everything very quickly. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And try and get some answers for you. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Erm, but we don't know any definite nothing certain at the minute. ; Therapist: Erm, but I do appreciate that I've just given you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Some scary news. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Erm, and they'll probably take a little bit of time. ; Therapist: Erm, so my door is open and I wonder if maybe we can get some answers. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Erm, I've taken the liberty of printing off a little bit of something about pancreatic cancer if that's what this is. ; Therapist: Erm, for you to have a bit of a read through. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Some of it's a little bit, a little bit scary and as I said we don't know as nothing certain yet. ; Therapist: But I wonder if you might want to have a bit of a read through of it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Before coming back to see me. ; Therapist: Erm, so what this does is it just explains a little bit about what the pancreas is. ; Patient: Right, okay. ; Therapist: A bit more detailed than I've been able to today. ; Therapist: Erm, and it talks about cancer in general. ; Patient: Mm hm. ; Therapist: And types of ways in which it can affect the pancreas and what sorts of treatments you can get. And then, how we diagnose it, different forms of scans ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you want to have a read through of this and then maybe, come back and see me tomorrow? ; Patient: Yeah I'll be back tomorrow, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah? Okay. ; Therapist: I'm sorry to have to break this news to you like this ; Patient: Okay, I'll see you tomorrow ; Therapist: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Age 47 ; Therapist Information : Name dr. Evers ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms abdominal pain ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech nad, mood  affect anxious, thought nad, perception nad, cognitive functions, nad judgement and insight intact ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in the session 1 problem patient had scan for gallstones, has ongoing abdominal pain. Found the possibility of cancer. 2 support the, reflecting the emotional impact of a potential cancer diagnosis. The doctor offers support and the possibility of involving family when patient expresses shock and concern upon hearing the news 3 treatment plan doctor planned for specialist consultation, further diagnostic steps, and potential treatment options, offered a follow-up appointment to discuss any questions or concerns. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Pancreatic cancer ; Next session details: Tomorrow

dialogue: Therapist: So Steph, I know you just want to go home. ; Therapist: And you don't want to be admitted. ; Therapist: However, I'm really concerned that you swallowed a whole bottle of pills last night because you were feeling down. ; Therapist: Do you think you're going to do that again? ; Patient: No, I'm feeling a lot better now. ; Patient: It was a stupid thing to do. ; Patient: I'm not going to do it again. ; Therapist: I'm still really concerned about you and I need to know that you're going to be safe when you leave here. ; Therapist: I need you to fill out the safety plan to ensure that you have strategies in place to cope when you're feeling down. ; Patient: I don't really feel like filling out a plan. ; Patient: I don't need a plan. ; Therapist: Well, I think that you do need a plan. ; Therapist: You obviously needed a plan last night when you swallowed that whole bottle of pills. ; Therapist: And I want you to fill out the safety plan to ensure you have strategies in place in case you feel like this again. ; Therapist: It's a condition of your discharge. ; Patient: I really don't want to. ; Therapist: This is really concerning for me, Steph. ; Therapist: Perhaps you need to be admitted. ; Patient: Fine, I'll fill out the plan. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So Steph, I know you probably want to get out of here and go home and that you don't want to be admitted. ; Therapist: It must have been a really scary experience for you. ; Therapist: I want you to know though that any time you're feeling unsafe or at risk of harming yourself, you're always welcome to come back to the emergency department. ; Therapist: I'm wondering what you think might have been helpful for you if this happens again. ; Patient: I don't think it'll happen again. ; Patient: I was feeling really down but I don't really want to die. ; Therapist: Must have been a really hard experience to go through. ; Therapist: I'm wondering if you think it would be helpful to have some kind of plan in place or some strategies if by chance you feel like this again. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What do you think might be helpful for you to think about or to do if you did feel like this again? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I guess I could have called someone. ; Therapist: Oh, so that's a good idea. ; Therapist: Who do you think you might have called? ; Patient: Maybe my Aunt Jenny. ; Patient: She's great. ; Patient: She's really easy to talk to. ; Therapist: So it's good you have someone in your life that you can talk to. ; Therapist: What do you think stopped you from calling her last night? ; Patient: It was so late. ; Patient: I didn't want to call at like 3 in the morning. ; Patient: It would have woken her and my uncle and all of my cousins up and they'd probably just be mad. ; Therapist: So you're worried about disturbing them. ; Therapist: I imagine that your Aunt Jenny probably would have been okay with you calling her given the circumstances and how you were feeling. ; Therapist: Do you think you'd be okay with maybe having a conversation with her about her being an emergency contact for you? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: I'm wondering maybe if I could bring your dad in right now and we could maybe all talk about this together. ; Patient: Yeah, okay. ; Therapist: That's okay? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Hi Tom. ; Therapist: Steph and I are just having a conversation about safety planning and I'm wondering if you want to join us. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So Tom, Steph and I were just talking about who she might contact in the future if she was ever to feel this way again and she mentioned her Aunt Jenny. ; Therapist: Yes, I think that sounds good. ; Therapist: Steph and Jenny are pretty close. ; Therapist: I'm wondering Steph, are there any other things you can think of that would help you in the moment if you're feeling this down again? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I haven't been doing the stuff I usually do for fun like reading or going outside or hanging out with my friends even. ; Therapist: She also likes going for walks late at night when she can't sleep or isn't feeling good but I'm just not that comfortable with that. ; Therapist: So that's concerning for you? ; Patient: It helps a lot. ; Patient: The fresh air clears my head. ; Therapist: I'm wondering Tom, is there anything that Steph could do to make you feel more comfortable with her going for a walk? ; Therapist: I guess. ; Therapist: If she were to let me know before she left and maybe text me part way through to let me know where she is and when she might be home, that would help. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Steph, is that an okay compromise for you? ; Patient: Yeah, I guess. ; Therapist: Okay, so we've talked about a few strategies today and sometimes people find it helpful to write them down. ; Therapist: I actually have a template for a safety plan so we could write down what we talked about. ; Therapist: The other option is you could use the notes section of your phone. ; Therapist: Do either of those sound helpful for you? ; Patient: Maybe using the notes section on my phone. ; Patient: I always have it with me. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Therapist: So let's recap what we talked about today.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name steph, sex female father accompanied her. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms sucidality chief complaint 1distress 2 reluctant to take medical help ; Crisis Markers: Yes, attempted suicide. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior scared; speech  nad, mood  affect anxious, thought negative, cognitive functions impaired, judgement and insight poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Supportive ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Issues discussed in the session 1 problem identified patient has a serious mental health crisis as she is having swallowed a bottle of pills due to feeling down. 2 safety planning the healthcare professional emphasizes the importance of having strategies in place for when she feels down again. Therapist suggest using the notes section of her phone, which she always has with her, to record her strategies. 3 techniques therapist uses a compassionate and understanding approach to validate feelings and encouraging an open communication. Asked to involve family members in the safety planning process. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Sucidality

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jackie, how are you doing today? ; Patient: Eh, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm okay, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I see that you have signed a release so I could talk to your mother and that she brought you in today. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What's going on there? ; Patient: Um, you know, they think I have a drinking problem. ; Patient: My family. ; Therapist: Your family thinks you have a drinking problem? ; Patient: Yeah, so what really started this was this past weekend, um, they came to pick me up for my cousin's bridal shower and, uh, I was drunk when they came to get me so I couldn't go and now everybody's pretty pissed at me so here I am. ; Therapist: So they asked you to come into the agency? ; Patient: Yeah, you know, I don't want them to all hate me or anything so I agreed to come. ; Therapist: Do you believe that you have a drinking problem? ; Patient: I mean I like to drink. ; Patient: I don't, you know, I think it's okay. ; Therapist: You think it's okay? ; Patient: Yeah, I like it. ; Patient: I like drinking. ; Therapist: Come on, do you mind if I ask you a few questions today to your drinking? ; Patient: Oh, that's fine. ; Therapist: So how often do you drink now? ; Patient: Um, pretty much every day I would think. ; Patient: I drink every day on the weekends for sure. ; Patient: Um, but like, uh, during the week I'll go to the, whatever the best local happy hour is, you know, I'll just go about what's going on. ; Patient: So I'll go after work and have some drinks. ; Therapist: How about on the weekend? ; Patient: On the weekend I kind of keep to myself, you know, um, so I'll drink a little for whatever I have at the house. ; Patient: But yeah, I don't really go out a lot on the weekend, mostly to stay at home and, you know, drink whatever I have there. ; Therapist: And how much are you drinking, let's say on the weekend? ; Patient: Um, it's hard to keep track I think. ; Patient: I'd say a couple cases over maybe like two or three cases of beer throughout the weekend. ; Patient: If there's something on sale, you know, at the liquor store down the street, I'll get like a bottle of vodka or something to go along with it. ; Therapist: Alright, how about during the week? ; Patient: Um, during the week I just stay at the bar for a few hours, maybe have like six or seven drinks, and then go home. ; Patient: I mean, I'll have a glass of wine when I get home. ; Therapist: Are you drinking more than you want to? ; Patient: Um, I guess so. ; Patient: I mean, I've kind of tried to make a plan to just stay on the weekends to drink some, and that hasn't really kept up because I like to go to the happy hours and stuff. ; Patient: So. ; Therapist: So you've tried to cut down before and... ; Patient: I have, yeah. ; Patient: ...are not able to. ; Patient: Yeah, it's not really happening though. ; Patient: I don't really see it happening. ; Therapist: Do you have cravings for alcohol? ; Patient: Um, yeah, you could say so. ; Patient: Well, yeah, when I'm at work I want to drink, and when I'm out doing stuff I want to drink. ; Therapist: Are you using exclusively alcohol, or are there other drugs involved? ; Patient: Um, right now just alcohol is legal. ; Patient: I was inpatient a couple times for cocaine, but I've stopped that. ; Patient: It's not really something I want to do anymore, so. ; Therapist: When was the last time you were inpatient? ; Patient: Um, about four months ago, five months ago. ; Therapist: Four or five months ago? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And at that time you used cocaine? ; Patient: Yeah, I was using coke and alcohol. ; Therapist: And alcohol? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And why did you stop using cocaine? ; Patient: Um, well, I graduated from college. ; Patient: I was kind of a partier in college, and then I had to get a job, and it's kind of, I had a fear of losing my job because of the cocaine, and I had to get a drug test and stuff, so that's kind of in the back of my mind with that. ; Patient: So, yeah, I think the treatment helped with that. ; Therapist: Do you crave cocaine? ; Patient: Um, no, mostly just alcohol. ; Therapist: Just alcohol? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: How about your work? ; Therapist: Are you having any trouble keeping your job or your performance at your job been okay? ; Patient: Um, I think I'm not doing tip-top of what I could be doing, but, you know, it hasn't really been a problem. ; Patient: I haven't been threatened to be fired or anything like that, but, you know, I'll come and leave every once in a while, but I sneak in, so nobody knows. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Any social problems because of the alcohol use? ; Patient: Um, me with my family kind of right now, yeah. ; Patient: I'm not really getting along with them very well. ; Patient: Um, my friends, though, when I go out with them during the week, we get along fine, but, you know, they're just not really as fun as they used to be, so sometimes... ; Therapist: Your friends? ; Patient: Sometimes they want to do stuff and go to the movies or whatever, and they get a little mad because I don't want to go. ; Patient: I'd rather go, you know, party somewhere. ; Therapist: So you're having some social problems. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Not so much with your friends a little bit, but more with your family. ; Patient: More with my family, yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I guess my friends aren't that happy with me, but I don't think it's a huge deal. ; Patient: My best friend, I haven't talked to in a couple days because she, uh, she was mad at me for not coming to dinner with her the other night because I would rather frank, and she didn't want to do that, so... ; Therapist: So there have been some problems with the... ; Patient: Yeah, I guess so. ; Therapist: With the friends? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you found that, uh, you're engaging in any activities that are physically dangerous because of alcohol? ; Patient: Um... I've gotten hurt a couple times. ; Patient: I mean, I've fallen down the steps, but I'm not going, like, skydiving or anything, you know, so... ; Patient: I mean, I did sprain my ankle a couple months ago because I fell down the steps, but other than that, I've been okay. ; Therapist: Do you find that, um, you have any exacerbation of symptoms that you have already, like any medical or mental health problems made worse by the alcohol? ; Patient: No, I would say I'm pretty healthy. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So... did you notice a point after you started drinking when you had to increase the amount that you drank to get the same effect? ; Patient: Oh, yeah. ; Therapist: When did that happen? ; Patient: Um... I think I kind of go through phases with it, you know. ; Patient: I'll drink a certain amount for a little while, then I'll notice, you know, I'm not even drunk anymore, so... I'll have to drink some more. ; Therapist: When was the last time you noticed that? ; Therapist: When you noticed you had to drink a lot more to get the same effect? ; Patient: I'd say, like, last weekend, you know, I was, uh, drinking a couple beers at my house and a few hours had passed and I drank probably, like, 10, 12 beers and I wasn't feeling anything, so... ; Patient: I started drinking a little faster and then I started, you know, feeling a little better. ; Therapist: How about withdrawal? ; Therapist: Do you have any symptoms of withdrawal when you stop drinking? ; Patient: Uh... ; Therapist: Like physical symptoms, anxiety? ; Patient: Well... I mean, I want some more, for sure. ; Therapist: Craving? ; Patient: Yeah, I crave some more, but I have a headache now. ; Therapist: Headache? ; Patient: Yeah, so... ; Therapist: Alright, Jackie, are you open to seeing a counselor here at the agency? ; Patient: Uh... I think that's what my mom really wants, so... ; Patient: So maybe I'll try it out once or twice and see what happens, but... ; Patient: I guess to make her happy, I will. ; Therapist: Alright, so you want to try it out? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I'll get you scheduled to see a counselor. ; Therapist: I want to thank you for telling me about what's going on and for answering my questions. ; Therapist: It's been helpful. ; Patient: Yeah, sure.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jackie; sex male; education graduate ; Clinical Identifiers: Counseling agency ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Strong desire to consume alcohol 2. Inability in controlling drinking behavior 3. Increased tolerance of alcohol 4. Headache ; History: Present history patient presented with complaints of alcohol consumption. He feels a strong urge to consume alcohol. He earlier tried to control it but his attempts were failed. Past history patient was hospitalised for taking cocaine and alcohol around 4 month ago; personal history he is having difficulty maintaining relationship with his family members and friends; substance use historyhe regularly consumes alcohol. He takes around 2-3 cases of beer on weekends alone and 6-7 drinks on week days post work. He earlier used to take cocaine but quit later after taking therapy to safeguard his job. ; Crisis Markers: High risk substance use ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood calm; affect broad; judgement personal judgment impaired ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients excessive drinking habits were discussed. He has been having strong desire to consume alcohol and her amount of drinking has also increased. He gets recurrent headaches when she doesnt drink. He has tried to resist her drinking but couldnt. His family recently went to pick him for a family function where he was found to be heavily intoxicated that his mother brought him to the agency. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F10. 2 mental and behavioral disorders due to use of alcohol; dependence syndrome ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Asking children and teens about potential traumas they may have experienced can be challenging, particularly for clinicians who don't have a focus in mental health. ; Therapist: But we know that these adverse childhood experiences are prevalent and significantly impact lifelong health. ; Therapist: So it's essential that all pediatric healthcare providers feel comfortable and competent to do a routine screen for these adverse childhood experiences. ; Therapist: In the previous video we saw demonstrated how a clinician can use the ACE screening questionnaire to interview a parent and determine a child's ACE score. ; Therapist: Dr. Lawson met with 10-year-old Sam and his mom Dana and did a routine physical checkup on Sam and had no concerns for him. ; Therapist: She was about to finish the interview when Sam's mother raised that he was having difficulties at school and she also noted that there were some stresses at home. ; Therapist: Dr. Lawson interviewed Dana first on her own and gave Sam an ACE score of 3 based on what his mother was reporting. ; Therapist: She now meets with Sam on his own to ask him the same screening questions and confirm his score. ; Therapist: Hi Sam, thanks for waiting. ; Therapist: I talked to your mom a little bit about some of the things that were going on at home and school. ; Therapist: And now I'm going to spend a few minutes with you asking you some questions, the questions I ask all the kids. ; Therapist: Some of them are going to kind of fit for you and some of them might not fit so well. ; Therapist: But if there's things that you're curious about I'm asking or if you have questions as we're talking then feel free to ask me about why I'm asking something or ask any questions, okay? ; Therapist: The first thing I wanted to check in about was how have things been going at home? ; Patient: Oh, okay, I guess. ; Therapist: Okay, you guess? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And it sounds like there's a lot of things that have happened, lots of stressors and lots of things that have happened. ; Therapist: How's your mom doing with all of that stuff? ; Patient: Okay, I guess she's fine. ; Therapist: She's fine? ; Therapist: Have there ever been a time where you feel like your mom isn't able to get out of bed or do the things that she needs to do? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: So she's getting out of bed and she's looking after you? ; Patient: Most of the time, yeah. ; Therapist: Most of the time? ; Therapist: What does most of the time mean? ; Patient: Well, she's mostly doing a lot of, well she's doing a lot of stuff so she's doing things pretty good, I guess. ; Therapist: What are some of the things that you might think she might do a bit better? ; Patient: Oh, maybe getting some dinner, maybe? ; Patient: Because sometimes I just have to get both Cheerios. ; Therapist: So sometimes you're not having dinner? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You're having Cheerios for dinner? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: How many times a week would you say that that's happening, that you're having Cheerios for dinner? ; Patient: Pretty much every day. ; Therapist: Pretty much every day? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And is your mom having Cheerios with you or are you on your own having Cheerios? ; Therapist: What's your mom doing? ; Patient: I'm mainly by myself. ; Therapist: You're by yourself having Cheerios? ; Therapist: And when you go to your fridge and you open it up, is there food in your fridge? ; Therapist: Have you ever had a time where there hasn't been enough food in your fridge? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: So there's food in your fridge? ; Patient: Unless I ate too much. ; Therapist: Unless you ate too much. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And have you been worried about having food? ; Therapist: Has that ever been a concern of yours? ; Therapist: It's getting pretty cold outside. ; Therapist: Do you have a coat and winter boots and things to make sure you're all set for the winter? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: My mom keeps saying that we might go to the mall or go shopping for one, but we never end up doing it because she's too busy with other things. ; Therapist: So how's your mom been doing? ; Patient: Okay, I guess. ; Patient: Pretty good. ; Therapist: Are there ever any times that she seems down or upset for days at a time? ; Therapist: That she hasn't been getting out of bed? ; Therapist: Or that she seems to be having a really tough time? ; Patient: She might be a little bit stressed because of Grandma. ; Therapist: Can you tell me more about what you mean by a little bit stressed? ; Patient: Well, they've been arguing and yelling a lot. ; Patient: So... ; Therapist: Who has Grandma and Mom? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: They've been arguing and yelling? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Can you tell me a little bit more about that? ; Patient: Well, they're just arguing about things. ; Patient: They're not very nice. ; Patient: I haven't listened to it very much. ; Patient: I just go to my room. ; Patient: So... ; Patient: It's not very nice. ; Therapist: And when they argue and yell, have there ever been times that you've been afraid that someone might get hurt? ; Patient: Once, maybe. ; Therapist: Once. ; Therapist: Can you tell me a bit about that time? ; Patient: Well, they were just getting really mean. ; Patient: Like, more than they usually would. ; Patient: Because it's happening quite a bit now. ; Patient: But... ; Patient: It wasn't too bad, I guess. ; Therapist: So the fighting between your Grandma and your Mom, how intense does it get? ; Therapist: Is it arguing or is it yelling, screaming? ; Therapist: And when they argue and yell, have there been times when anybody's been physical, used their fists or hands? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Any other way that they may have physically been fighting? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: What about throwing objects or...? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: And what happens to you when they're fighting? ; Therapist: Where are you? ; Patient: I just go to my room and try to ignore it. ; Therapist: So you're going to your room? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And kind of what happens afterwards? ; Patient: They kind of just stay away from each other for a while. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Stay away from each other. ; Therapist: So when they're fighting, what I'm hearing is it's words, that they're not physically hurting each other, and it gets pretty scary. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: When people talk to you, has anyone said mean things or hurtful things to you? ; Patient: Well, sometimes my Grandma's criticizing me a little bit. ; Patient: Like she'll tell me I'm not doing something right, but then won't help me with it. ; Patient: Like won't explain it. ; Therapist: So you're feeling criticized by Grandma? ; Therapist: What about Mom? ; Therapist: Has she ever said mean or hurtful things to you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Sam, has anybody touched your body in an inappropriate way or a way that you didn't like? ; Patient: What do you mean? ; Therapist: Has anyone touched your private parts or touched you in a sexual way? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Sam, does anybody in your house ever hit or spank you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: What about hurting your body? ; Therapist: Has anyone hurt your body? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So when I say hurt, I mean things like hitting, kicking, punching, scratching. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So no one's hurt you sexually or physically? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: With anyone in your house, has anyone been drinking or have you ever been worried about people drinking too much or getting drunk? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: What about other drugs? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: So you don't have any worries about your parents using drugs or alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: What about Grandma? ; Therapist: Anybody else in your family that you're worried about in that way? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So Sam, how do you feel in your close relationships? ; Therapist: Do you feel loved and cared about and special? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: You're shrugging. ; Therapist: What's that mean? ; Patient: Well, my mom pays more attention to my little brother and then when I try to talk to my mom if I want something, she won't really listen that well. ; Patient: She just kind of keeps doing what she's doing. ; Patient: And then might later ask me again, what did you want? ; Patient: Not a lot though, really, at any time. ; Patient: How would you do that? ; Therapist: So you're not feeling loved? ; Therapist: Is there any place in your life with any adults or with anyone that you're feeling loved? ; Patient: I'd like to be in my room. ; Patient: I don't really have anyone else, no. ; Therapist: So if you had a problem or you were hurt in some way or something was happening, who would you go to for help or what would you do? ; Patient: I wouldn't have anybody. ; Patient: I'd just go to my room and think. ; Patient: I just like being in my room sometimes. ; Therapist: And has anybody in your family ever been in jail or in prison? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So the stressors in your house and what's going on making your mom not be there for you as much. ; Therapist: What do you think are some of those stressful things? ; Patient: Well, probably because my grandma's fighting with her a lot and also my dad moving away because they were divorced a year ago. ; Therapist: Your mom told me that your dad and your mom aren't together anymore and that he's moved out to DC. ; Therapist: Do you see your dad? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: When was the last time you saw him? ; Patient: A year ago. ; Therapist: And is there a plan for you to see him? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: What I've heard is that there's some stressors and some things that are hard for you in your life and you talk to me about the arguing that's happening between your mom and your grandma. ; Therapist: That your dad has moved away. ; Therapist: That you're not always in the right clothes and you have to fix some of your meals. ; Therapist: And that you're not always feeling loved and special. ; Therapist: But you've also told me that nobody's hurting you in a physical or in a verbal or sexual way. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nobody's saying mean things to you. ; Therapist: That you're not worried about your mom emotionally and that she's not worried about her all the time, struggling more emotionally. ; Therapist: And that nobody you know is in prison or has been in prison. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And you don't have any concerns about drugs or drinking or in your home. ; Therapist: Sam, do you think some of those stressors are what's making it hard for you at school? ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: Probably, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Why do you think that might be? ; Patient: Maybe because I'm thinking about that and then I'm not thinking about what I'm doing at the moment and then I don't get very much. ; Patient: I don't get a lot done. ; Therapist: Yeah, that makes a lot of sense, Sam. ; Therapist: That when things are stressful at home that kids have trouble concentrating and it affects them at school. ; Therapist: So I'm going to talk to your mom more and we're going to try and figure out a way that I can help you and your mom with some of that stuff. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Therapist: So thanks for coming in. ; Therapist: Dr. Lawson's interview with Sam confirms that his ACE score is 3 as he endorses loss of a parent due to divorce, physical neglect and also a sense of emotional deprivation. ; Therapist: So we know that Sam is at elevated risk for a host of physical and mental illnesses beginning in adolescence that could persist throughout his life. ; Therapist: But Dr. Lawson's now in a position to meet again with Sam and his mother and collaboratively develop a focused and evidence-based intervention plan that should help change Sam's lifetime health trajectory. ; Therapist: Clinicians can visit the online trauma toolkit website for a list of resources on these evidence-based interventions which have been shown to be helpful for children like Sam and their families.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sam; sex male; marital status unmarried; education school appearing ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Difficulty concentrating in studies 2. Strained relations with family ; History: Present history patient has been having a difficult time at home as his mother and grandmother indulge in frequent fights. His mother pays less attention on him and so he feels less loved. He struggles with managing his meals on a regular basis as his mother is usually less available. He prefers being on his own and spends most of his time in his room. This all has been affecting his studies; family history his parents divorced a year ago and he hasnt seen his father ever since. He is living with his mother, grandmother and younger brother. His grandmother passes critical comments on him. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative but rapport could not be established. ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Paraphrasing ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient reason behind his difficulty in managing studies was addressed. He has been having a difficult time at home due to his mothers emotional unavailability and her frequent arguments with her mother which affect the patient a lot. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Sasha. ; Therapist: How you doing today? ; Patient: I'm all right, thanks. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Thank you for asking. ; Therapist: I understand that you've been having some difficulty with some symptoms. ; Therapist: Is that right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about what's been going on? ; Patient: Yeah, for the past maybe couple weeks, I guess, few weeks, I have these morning meetings once a week at work and I have to make a presentation. ; Patient: And every time I go to present, it's my turn and I start getting really nervous. ; Therapist: Start getting really nervous. ; Therapist: So, morning meeting at work and so does each person at the meeting present in a row? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: We all take turns. ; Therapist: You all take turns. ; Therapist: And when you start to feel nervous when it's your time to talk or before or after that? ; Patient: No, usually the kind at the start of the meeting because I know I'm going to have to. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: I've been to about 10 of us and I always seem to be one of the last few to go like six or seven kind of in line to present. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, there's around 10 people at the meeting? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And as luck would have it, you tend to be toward the end. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, can you describe what's happening, let's say, from the beginning of the meeting in terms of what you're experiencing? ; Patient: So, when I walk in, I'm usually okay and say good morning to everybody and then my boss calls me to order and that's usually when it starts. ; Patient: It kind of starts like maybe like butterflies in my stomach kind of. ; Patient: And then after he makes his report and then it just starts going around the room and my heart starts to beat faster, my palms get sweaty and I just start to feel really nervous. ; Patient: I've realized that I might be, I kind of, I start to tune out some of the other presentations because I start to become focused on how I'm feeling. ; Therapist: So, you're focused on the physical sensation being nervous and the mental sensation and you're not really hearing what they're saying? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Is that what they're saying? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, go on. ; Therapist: So, you have these physical symptoms, this nervousness, what happens then? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: By the time it's my turn to present, I start, I just, I'm almost like just almost shaking. ; Patient: I notice that my hands are a little off and so I'll keep my hands down like in my lap and just so that I don't want anybody to see them shaking like that. ; Patient: I have a paper in front of me that I just kind of read from but when I start reading, my voice is a little shaky and I kind of stutter and trip over my words and I just, I feel like I'm not making good presentations and that it's not looking good to my boss. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, in the moment when it's your turn to present, you're still feeling that same nervousness like that doesn't go away at all. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And you're trying to hold your body kind of still like almost like keep control. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And then your voice is kind of, sounds like crackly or breaking up as you're trying to present like bullet points like on a... ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Like an outline. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: What happens when you have read the last point? ; Patient: Well, when I'm done, it takes a little bit for everything to calm down but then I'm consumed by the idea that my boss thinks I did a terrible job and that he's regretting putting me in this position and that I can't make good reports or that I didn't report the right stuff, the right information to him and so it doesn't really go away. ; Patient: It's almost like my mind just shifts on what I'm anxious about. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, the nervousness, that stronger feeling of nervousness, that goes away. ; Therapist: It's replaced by a more general feeling of nervousness about how your boss will think of you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because of the presentation quality. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because as you're presenting and kind of staying still and your voice is crackling, he's picking up on that and you're aware of that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How long have you noticed these symptoms that appear in this way? ; Patient: You know, when I was an undergrad in college, I had to make some presentations from time to time and I would get nervous when I would make the presentations and I just, maybe most people are afraid of public speaking so I kind of thought that maybe that's what it was, you know, just doing a presentation in front of like 30 something people and so it didn't really bother me then. ; Patient: I figured it was just normal and I always got decent grades on my presentation so it never really bothered me. ; Patient: So I really feel like it's only been an issue in the last few weeks. ; Therapist: The last few weeks is when you noticed this. ; Therapist: You had some nervousness before presenting. ; Therapist: You were in college but you just kind of thought of it as normal. ; Therapist: It didn't really impair your ability to present. ; Therapist: It didn't affect your grades or anything. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you have any other symptoms that you think may be related or even unrelated to what's going on? ; Patient: I'm not sure if it has any bearing. ; Patient: My mom, she doesn't like to speak in public. ; Patient: I know I used to talk to her about how I feel nervous about making presentations in school and she would say, oh, you can buy it on as honey and so I don't know if that means anything. ; Therapist: So whatever you have going on, you think that maybe she has that going on too. ; Patient: Maybe. ; Therapist: The same set of symptoms at least. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean I've asked her, I've told her about this and she hasn't been in a situation where she's had to do this kind of presentations like in a small group like this and so I can't compare it to that but I mean she has said that she's gotten nervous before. ; Therapist: Any feelings of sadness or anything like that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Like after I make the presentation at work and then I do start feeling really sad, like I said, because then I feel like my boss isn't satisfied with my performance and that he's going to regret his decision to give me this position and so yeah, it definitely makes me sad. ; Patient: I feel disappointed in myself. ; Therapist: Do you have any substance use going on, alcohol, anything else? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I have a drink every now and then. ; Patient: It's very, very rare. ; Therapist: I know this is something recent for you but in these meetings so far, has the nervousness ever caused you to leave the room before they came around to your turn? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I've managed to control it I guess to where I can stay there. ; Patient: Like I said, I've zoned out sometimes when other people have been presenting and I feel bad about that too because I feel like they have important information to share with me and I should give them the same respect of paying attention but I become focused on what's going on inside like my heart beating and my hands and so I zone out on them sometimes but no, I push through it and I do my presentation. ; Therapist: Are you ever worried about what they're thinking about? ; Therapist: You mentioned what your boss could be thinking about you. ; Therapist: Have you ever worried about what the other workers at the table are thinking about you? ; Patient: Yeah, sometimes because I feel like I'm the newest member of the management team and so I feel like they're kind of like, what is up with this chick? ; Therapist: Why can't she get it together? ; Patient: But there's been one person who's been really supportive and she's been like, hey, you did great today and great information and things like that so that kind of helps me feel better but I guess at the end of the day to me, it's really my boss's opinion that matters because he's my boss. ; Therapist: Have you ever felt, you mentioned you were nervous at the beginning of the meeting. ; Therapist: Have you ever felt nervous well in advance of the meeting? ; Patient: When I'm preparing like that morning to go to work and it's one of those like, okay, I got this meeting at nine and I start to think about it like on my way into work but I don't start feeling anything until I'm actually in the room. ; Therapist: Alright, so you have this nervousness, it's fairly intense, pretty much only at these meetings. ; Therapist: It's been bothering you for a few weeks. ; Therapist: Something new, something a little frightening for you. ; Therapist: Alright, we'll get you set up with treatment. ; Therapist: I'll get you in to see somebody in the next few days if that works for you. ; Patient: Yeah, that'd be great. ; Therapist: And I appreciate you spending this time with me. ; Therapist: It's been helpful. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks, Sasha.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sasha; sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Tingling sensation in stomach 2. Palpitations 3. Trembling hands 4. Restlessness and inability to relax ; History: Present history patient has to give presentations once a week from last from few weeks where she gets nervous. As a result, right in the beginning of her presentation she feels a tingling sensation in her stomach followed by palpitations and sweating her palms. She gets nervous and her voice starts shaking and flow of the speech gets disrupted. Right after her presentation she gets consumed by the idea that she did not deliver a quality presentation to be appreciated by her boss and that he thinks she is terrible at her job. This overall feeling makes her feel sad; past history patient used to feel nervous while giving presentations in school; family history patients mother does not like to speak much in public ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cordial and rapport could be established; mood tensed; affect restricted thought content- reflected worry regarding her public speaking ; Psychotherapy Type: Mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients fear of public speaking along with her experience of giving a presentation was discussed. She has been feeling anxious before and while giving a presentation followed by a feeling of sadness due to the thoughts of scrutiny by her boss. Her mother has also been less vocal when it comes to public speaking. Patient experiences a tingling sensation in her stomach, palpitations, trembling hands and an inability to feel relaxed. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, I'm Jordan. ; Therapist: It's so nice to meet you. ; Patient: Hi, I'm Judy. ; Therapist: How are you doing? ; Patient: I'm pretty good. ; Therapist: Well welcome, sit down. ; Therapist: Have you ever been to a counseling session before? ; Patient: No, this will be my first time. ; Therapist: Well okay then, so just a little bit about us. ; Therapist: We're a counseling center and we work with people with a range of different things going on with them. ; Therapist: And between the two of us we can work through whatever is going on with you in your life. ; Therapist: But before we begin, I just wanted to let you know that everything you say here is confidential. ; Therapist: Unless you're intending to harm yourself or other people and then we're obligated to report it for their own safety. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yeah, that makes sense too. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So I also just want to forewarn you, today is going to be a lot of questions. ; Therapist: Just trying to get some background of where you're at and where you want to go. ; Therapist: Also, would it be okay with you if I write down some things as we talk? ; Therapist: Yeah, that's totally fine. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So to begin, can you tell me a little bit about yourself? ; Patient: Yeah, like I said, my name is Judy. ; Patient: I'm 42. ; Patient: I have two kids. ; Patient: Max, who's eight years old, and Chelsea, who is six. ; Patient: Max plays soccer. ; Patient: He's very active around the home. ; Patient: Like almost too active. ; Patient: And Chelsea is a little know-all, but keeps me in line. ; Patient: And kids are both very active, pretty good in school, get along pretty well, and they're good. ; Patient: They're good kids. ; Patient: Sweet kids. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: I'm so glad. ; Therapist: So I'd love to hear what's been going on from your perspective and why you're excited to come here today. ; Patient: Well, I have a lot of negative stuff going on in my life right now. ; Patient: I've been very stressed lately because I lost my job pretty recently. ; Patient: It was a rough time and I haven't been handling it very well according to my husband. ; Patient: And he told me that I had to come to counseling where he would leave me. ; Patient: So that's why I'm here. ; Therapist: I'm definitely glad that you came. ; Therapist: When did you notice this change in yourself or notice that this was a problem? ; Patient: Well, I lost my job about a month ago. ; Patient: I got laid off a month ago. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it seems like losing your job has really affected your relationship with your husband and family. ; Therapist: You said you have two other kids, that you love with them, right? ; Patient: Yes, I have two kids Max and Chelsea. ; Patient: I love them a lot and we live all together, the four of us. ; Patient: The children are wonderful, but I feel like I haven't been a great mom recently to them or my husband. ; Patient: I think that's unfair to me. ; Therapist: So that leads great into my next question. ; Therapist: What's your relationship with your husband like? ; Patient: Well, we've had our ups and downs like every marriage. ; Patient: I spend a lot of time with the kids. ; Patient: He works a lot. ; Patient: He's not very close with the kids. ; Patient: But I'm not as close with my parents. ; Patient: I'm very close with my mom. ; Patient: And she's been there for me a lot in the past. ; Therapist: Interesting. ; Therapist: And how long have you been married for? ; Patient: Just seven years. ; Therapist: And what do you like to do in your free time with your family? ; Therapist: Do you spend time with them? ; Patient: Yeah, I go to the gym a lot. ; Patient: That's more of an individual activity for me. ; Patient: It's something that releases a lot of my stress. ; Patient: And that's kind of how I, I don't know, it's part of who I am. ; Patient: But with the kids, I like them and I drive them all over the place all the time. ; Patient: I like to practice, I like to practice everything. ; Patient: So there's not a lot of time for me to really have time with my kids. ; Patient: But I don't know, I like to, you know, we read together every night. ; Patient: I try to make time for the kids. ; Patient: And I take them to the beach when it's warm. ; Patient: You know, there's a lot of things that we do together. ; Therapist: Good, good. ; Therapist: Do you find you can draw support from your family? ; Therapist: You mentioned your aunt, but... ; Patient: Well, I don't really want to warn the kids because they think they're so young. ; Patient: And I think they know that something's up, but I don't really know to what extent they know. ; Patient: But I am closer to my aunt. ; Patient: She's always been there for me. ; Patient: But my husband and I have had a rough patch recently since I lost my job. ; Therapist: So, when you're stressed, you sometimes go to your aunt, but do you turn to people for comfort? ; Therapist: Or do you have an activity that helps you calm down or another method that helps you cope? ; Patient: Like I said, I have been going to the gym a lot, but I haven't been doing that as much recently. ; Patient: Maybe, I'm not really sure why I haven't made time for it. ; Patient: I haven't really felt like myself recently. ; Patient: But a lot of times, I turn to other things more than people. ; Therapist: What kind of things do you mean? ; Patient: Like substances, drugs and alcohol? ; Patient: Yeah, I've never used them before, but I feel like it helps me relax, calm down. ; Patient: And a lot of times, it's something that I feel like I need to be, I guess, relaxed. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you find that's affecting your family? ; Therapist: Your relationships with them or the way you interact? ; Patient: It didn't for a while. ; Patient: But like I said, about a month ago was a turning point. ; Patient: And when I lost my job, I do feel very ashamed. ; Patient: I made a horrible mistake the other day. ; Patient: I can't believe I'm saying this, but I drove with them in the car after I had a few drinks and they got pulled over. ; Patient: I felt like I endangered my family. ; Patient: I felt like I was being a bad mom and that was a really big life to me. ; Therapist: That must have been pretty scary for you. ; Therapist: But if you think of it this way, it could be a turning point. ; Therapist: And you now notice what you're doing wrong and how you can improve it. ; Therapist: So it's progress that you're admitting that and that you do need to improve on certain things. ; Therapist: Do you take any other medications? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What medications? ; Patient: Oxycodone. ; Therapist: And why do you have a prescription for that? ; Patient: Well, I had surgery a few years back and I got fulfilled. ; Patient: I didn't really finish all the pills, but I've been taking them recently when I feel like I need to. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And how often do you take them? ; Patient: I've taken three over the course of a month, but I know that I shouldn't be. ; Therapist: How do you feel when you take them? ; Patient: It's numbing and it allows me to relax and escape from the issues in the home and workplace. ; Patient: I guess not really a workplace anymore, but I know that I shouldn't be doing what I'm doing and I know that it's wrong. ; Patient: And I guess that's why I'm here. ; Therapist: How has your family ever had a history of drug abuse problems and drinking? ; Patient: My dad, I think, was an alcoholic for a while, not really diagnosed. ; Patient: I grew up with a lot of that in the home. ; Patient: A lot of just genuine parents didn't mesh too well or a lot of infighting in the home. ; Patient: And the older I get, the more that I think that it might have been alcohol related on my father's part. ; Patient: My mother definitely not. ; Patient: My father though, and I believe that his father had a problem similar to that as well. ; Therapist: And is it the first time you found yourself turning to it? ; Patient: A few times in college I found myself depressed, confused about growing up, getting a career. ; Patient: I wasn't an addict in college, but I would do things with the intention of feeling better and forgetting. ; Patient: I think that's kind of something that's been beneath the surface for a while. ; Patient: When I find myself stressful, I can sink back into that. ; Therapist: Have you ever experienced any form of sexual assault or abuse that maybe made you turn to alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Are you having trouble eating or sleeping? ; Patient: Eating, yeah, not as much or as healthy as I have before, but sleeping absolutely because of stress. ; Patient: I find myself not sleeping as well. ; Therapist: Yeah, that definitely happens with stress. ; Therapist: And what's a typical day like for you? ; Patient: Well, lately my husband's been taking care of the kids more because of last week and the incident with getting pulled over. ; Patient: He doesn't trust me with the kids, which I guess they understand. ; Patient: He doesn't trust me to drive kids places because of last week, so he usually will take them to school and I'll make him late for work and that makes him upset. ; Patient: And there's an argument there. ; Patient: When I wake up, I'll have a drink, so I'm not too hung up from the night before. ; Patient: Then I watch my show, I get the mail, and usually there's a bill, so I have a few more drinks. ; Patient: And then I try to start dinner, but it's usually hard because I'm pretty intoxicated, but I start dinner and usually at the night is the letter of a shit show and the kids are frustrated and you figure it out. ; Therapist: And are you feeling sad or down in addition to being stressed? ; Patient: I'm pretty sad. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And when you're sad, do you turn to your faith? ; Therapist: Have you been praying a lot? ; Patient: Some I used to, but I don't as much anymore. ; Patient: It's hard to believe that somebody's watching over me with all this negative stuff. ; Therapist: Does other things give you hope besides your faith? ; Patient: The kids. ; Patient: Watching them play together and be together really gives me a lot of hope. ; Patient: I love seeing them do what they love to do and I love it when I know that what I do can enable them to enjoy their activities. ; Patient: But it's been hard to do that recently because I drive them to school, I've been taking them to activities because my husband's been doing this for me. ; Patient: So it's getting kind of empty-fills with them getting into the family. ; Therapist: Thank you for sharing that. ; Therapist: So we can start to meet on a regular basis and try to work through all these things together. ; Therapist: From what I've collected, from what you kind of just told me, you're really stressed about losing your job and so you want to find different ways to cope with your stress. ; Therapist: And then also try to rebuild the trust in your family, with your husband, your kids that they may have lost during the driving incident last week. ; Patient: Sounds a lot like what I want to do. ; Patient: I hope that you're able to help me with that. ; Therapist: So in order for this to be most effective, let's brainstorm some small steps we can work on. ; Therapist: Maybe make a list together and it can be very small unless it's not too overwhelming at first. ; Therapist: So for instance, to work on the drinking thing, we can start by cutting down the number of drinks slowly today. ; Therapist: And it can be really hard to just stop cold turkey because you can get withdrawal symptoms or it may make you even more stressed out. ; Therapist: So I want you to be able to be confident in the goal you're setting and in yourself. ; Therapist: So can you do one last drink each day or something like that. ; Therapist: So what would you like to achieve from our work together in the future, by the end? ; Patient: Yeah, I hear what you're saying. ; Patient: I understand. ; Patient: I guess I don't want to stop moving completely. ; Patient: But it sounds like a very logical solution at this point. ; Patient: It doesn't sound like something I'd be able to do at this point immediately. ; Patient: We can maybe get there. ; Patient: I'm not really sure if we can completely get there. ; Patient: And then after that, I'd really like to fix my relationship with my family. ; Patient: So if I go to my husband, we can patch things with my parents too. ; Therapist: So let's start with a goal regarding drinking. ; Therapist: What do you think is a reasonable thing for yourself? ; Patient: I can start having four drinks a day, maybe four maybe. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: That's a good one. ; Therapist: Then in a few days you can try having three, and two, and one, until you don't need to turn to alcohol for comfort, and so on and so forth. ; Therapist: If you need a different way to find comfort, you can try stress relieving activities. ; Therapist: So what would be a good activity for you to do? ; Patient: I think I could try journaling, maybe drawing or painting. ; Patient: I did a lot of art in college. ; Patient: I'd really like to get back into that and I would just call it a day. ; Therapist: That's a really great idea. ; Therapist: Then in the future, what are you thinking regarding your career? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I don't think anyone's going to want somebody as dressed up as me right now. ; Therapist: What was your old job again? ; Patient: I was a staff captain. ; Therapist: Well, you don't need to jump right back into work again. ; Therapist: That can be a way in the future, or maybe a month or two. ; Therapist: If you think about it in the future, what would be your goal? ; Patient: I guess I'd like to get back in the game, but I think more important for me is that I patch things up with my family. ; Patient: But I do need to try making money again to support the family. ; Patient: It's not logical for me to assume that I can go a long time without it. ; Patient: That's why I want to fix my issues, get back in the job, and see what I can do. ; Therapist: What kind of things do you think could help rebuild the trust within your family? ; Patient: I could block out some time each week to really spend a long time with each of my family members, my kids and my husband. ; Patient: Kids I don't think really understand what's going on, so I don't have to work as hard with them, but I would still love to. ; Patient: I just really do need to work in relationship with my husband, go back to what things we used to do together, and see what we can do to get back there. ; Therapist: A way you could do that is try family therapy or couples counseling. ; Therapist: Would you be interested in something like that? ; Patient: Yeah, that's definitely something we could do. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So, I'm very happy that you came to talk to me today. ; Therapist: From what I heard, it sounds like losing your job has been incredibly stressful for you. ; Therapist: And you turned to substance abuse to try and relieve some of that stress. ; Therapist: Do you feel a little bit better after talking to me? ; Patient: I absolutely do. ; Patient: I feel like the weight has really been lifted off my shoulders, and the fact that somebody is going to be in charge of my recovery, I think is huge. ; Therapist: We'll definitely be working hand in hand, so you're in charge of your recovery, but I'm definitely here to help you along the way. ; Therapist: I really am looking forward to our next session together. ; Patient: Me too. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So, until our next session, I want you to try and journal every time that you're feeling upset or like you need to drink, stress, and then bring your journal and we can go through and find the times you felt like you needed substance to help you. ; Therapist: And in addition to that, maybe try and cut back on your drinking, maybe one less glass or something of wine or anything for now. ; Therapist: And then next time, let me know how that goes. ; Patient: Yeah, I can totally make sure of that. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So, I want you to know that I really do believe in you and that you can get through this. ; Therapist: And if you continue to come to our sessions, we really can work together to accomplish these goals that we just discussed. ; Patient: Thanks. ; Patient: I hope so too. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Have a good day. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name judy; age 42 years; sex female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting counseling centre ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name jordan ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Low mood 2. Alcohol consumption 3. Decreased sleep ; History: Present history patient lost her job a month ago. She has been having a rough time in her marriage due to the same. Her husband tells her that she hasnt been handling things quite well because she drove her children while being intoxicated and got pulled over; family history patient lives her husband and two children. Her son is 8 years old and her daughter is 6 years old. She has been married for last 7 years. She spends most of her time with her children and is very close to them. She also shares a warm relationship with her aunt; substance use history she has started consuming alcohol regularly and misusing medications sometimes. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood dysphoric; affect restricted; judgment personal judgement impaired. ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Paraphrasing, journaling ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient recently lost her job.
