She has started consuming alcohol everyday and also takes a medication oxycodone which was prescribed to her for a surgery she underwent sometime ago. She is sometimes consuming it to feel cal and relaxed. She earlier used to rely on gym to workout to feel better but not has been regular with it too. Her goals for the therapy were later discussed. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Client has been told to control her drinking and maintain a journal until next session. She may also opt for a couple therapy to fix things with her husband. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Alright, Carmelo, I want to take a couple of minutes and go over the skill and anger that you filled out when you got here. ; Therapist: You had mentioned that some people in your life have kind of commented and they said, you know, maybe you ought to look into thinking about whether or not you have some issues with anger or not. ; Therapist: And that's one of the reasons you're here. ; Therapist: And I'm hoping that this will help sort of identify specific issues related to anger that might be problematic for you. ; Therapist: And so this is really feedback meant for you. ; Therapist: You can do whatever you like with the information. ; Therapist: It's just for you to consider it. ; Therapist: And so let's go through each area. ; Therapist: And there are a number of questions here and a number of sort of different anger dimensions. ; Therapist: And I think the place we're going to start is if you look at all the questions that you answered, it comes up with something called a total score, which is just kind of looking at everything together. ; Therapist: And when we look at the total score, you scored quite high, actually. ; Therapist: You scored in a range that we would sort of call the 99th percentile, which means, yeah, which means that your anger is at a level greater than 99% of the population of men your age. ; Patient: Are you kidding me? ; Therapist: You know, that's kind of hard. ; Therapist: That high. ; Therapist: Kind of hard to hear it that way. ; Therapist: It kind of surprised you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Well, I didn't think I was going to rate that high. ; Patient: I mean, I figured a lot of people was in my category, but I would have figured that I was probably in about the 60%, 75. ; Therapist: Just a little above average. ; Patient: Wow. ; Patient: That's way up there. ; Therapist: It's a little bit high, and it might indicate that really anger does get you in trouble at times in terms of relationships and causing them. ; Therapist: So you've recognized that? ; Patient: I've always recognized it. ; Patient: I've seen it. ; Patient: I've tried to deny it a lot of times, but then I've recognized it that I know I have issues. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So this kind of just highlights that and puts a number on it in a sense. ; Patient: So that's where the studies have been done. ; Therapist: Yeah, right. ; Therapist: So you're kind of comparing how you answered the question to the general population of the folks your age, but you're really in the top 1% of scores. ; Therapist: I didn't think I was that bad. ; Patient: I've got a lot of serious problems. ; Patient: I mean, the same thing that they do to me, I do to them. ; Patient: So a lot of times I'm surprised, especially in the environment that I live in, that I haven't gotten shot or stabbed or killed yet. ; Patient: I mean, it should definitely have happened, and I'm surprised it hasn't. ; Therapist: Because getting angry, saying things to people, not thinking things through can really put you at risk. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Patient: Same things I can do to them for anger me to that point. ; Patient: It's the same thing as me getting them back for what they've said before. ; Patient: So it could go in vice versa aspects. ; Patient: They could kill me, I could kill them.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name carmelo; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Session for assessment of anger ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Increased anger ; History: Present history patient has been told by people that he may be having some anger issues which he, despite realising, kept denying. He came to seek therapy for the same as he has been facing trouble in his relationships ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood confused; affect broad ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Purpose of assessment anger ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients test results were discussed which reflected a very high score on anger. Patient expressed his realisation for always denying that he has anger issues. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: I'll show you how you're doing today. ; Patient: Great, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: So you're doing great? ; Therapist: I noticed today your brother brought you in and he had some concerns about how your mood has been. ; Patient: I mean, I don't know why because my mood has been awesome. ; Patient: For like a week I've been getting so much done, you know, at work, I finished both reports that I've been working on. ; Patient: Even at home, like I've had tons of time to clean my house and get caught up on actually making my house what I want it to be. ; Patient: And just working on it in general and it's clean and I mean, I haven't had any issues. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're feeling pretty good? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you have been for about a week? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do you feel like your sleep habits have changed? ; Patient: I mean, they have. ; Patient: I haven't been sleeping as much. ; Patient: I haven't needed it really. ; Patient: I only need a few hours it seems like but it's been fine because I haven't been tired, I haven't been, you know, irritable or anything during the day and at night I get a few hours of sleep but for the rest of the time I'm like, you know, either working on work or my house or whatever so I mean, I'm sleeping less but it's not an issue. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're sleeping less but you don't feel tired at all? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: You feel okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself more easily distracted by anything? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Things around you? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: How are things done at work? ; Therapist: How about at home? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, so my dining room, I've been like, new china and stuff like that so I've gotten everything set up. ; Patient: You know, I hadn't finished unpacking all my boxes from when I moved in so I've gotten all the boxes unpacked. ; Patient: You know, even like things like placemats and whatever, like it looks like a home now and I'm really liking what I'm doing. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're accomplishing a lot. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Now, when your brother had brought you in, he had mentioned some shopping and that's one of the things he was concerned about. ; Patient: Yeah, well, so on the weekend, I had gone ahead and went shopping and I kind of went on a shopping spree and I had bought, like I said, my new china and I had gotten some kitchen utensils too and a couple things for around the house, like home decor. ; Patient: And I called him because I had ran out of space to take everything. ; Patient: I was at the mall so I was hitting a lot of different stores. ; Patient: And I had run out of space to put everything in because I really wanted to actually get a new dining room set, like tables and chairs and maybe a cabinet. ; Patient: He has an SUV, so I called him to see if he could come and so I could purchase the items, but he said he wasn't, he couldn't come out. ; Patient: I guess he kind of said he was worried about you spending that much money, which I don't, you know, I don't know why he would be just from me calling him, but I think that's why he was concerned. ; Patient: But he didn't come. ; Patient: I didn't get the dining room set or anything. ; Therapist: You remember how much you spent? ; Patient: I don't know exactly because there's lots of different stores, but you know, I have a couple different credit cards. ; Patient: The one credit card I used was declined by the end. ; Patient: So it was probably, you know, I didn't need to get the dining room set. ; Patient: I could have used a different credit card, but obviously it's been enough. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you spent more than you usually would spend in a trip to the mall? ; Patient: Well, you know, I never really go on shopping sprees. ; Patient: I never like treat myself like that. ; Patient: So I mean, yes, but I, again, like I haven't, you know, I needed all those things that I got from my apartment. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a time in the past when you felt this way where you felt really good? ; Patient: Not like this, no. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: It's the first time. ; Patient: Like I just feel like, you know, life's falling into place right now. ; Therapist: Life's falling into place. ; Therapist: So you're feeling pretty good. ; Therapist: You feel like things are going your way. ; Patient: I do. ; Therapist: You're getting a lot accomplished. ; Therapist: Any sadness or anything like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Any change in appetite? ; Therapist: You seem to have a good amount of energy. ; Therapist: Any feelings of worthlessness? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Nothing. ; Therapist: Any thoughts of death or dying? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Drug and alcohol use? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about medical conditions? ; Patient: None. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a time in the past when you felt depressed? ; Patient: I mean, I have been depressed in the past, yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: But I mean, I feel like that's, I feel like I was almost a different person then. ; Patient: And I feel like, you know, I haven't had any of those symptoms, you know, and I feel like it's a new me. ; Therapist: It's a new you? ; Patient: Yep. ; Therapist: So do you know what happened with the depression in the past? ; Therapist: Like, did you end up in the hospital or being treated some other way? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: There's just no treatment? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I mean, I've talked to people before about being depressed, but I was never hospitalized for it. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: But you believe you were depressed? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Now or back then, did you see or hear things that other people couldn't see or hear? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Not now or back then? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right, Sherry, answering these questions has been helpful to me. ; Therapist: I appreciate it. ; Therapist: I'm going to get you over to see a counselor in just a few moments. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I know that you're feeling pretty good, but I'd like them to talk to you for just a bit. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Thank you, Sherry.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sherry, sex female; accompanied by his brother ; Past Session Information: Follow up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms elevated mood and impulsivity. Chief complaints 1 increase in activity 2 reduced sleep 3 financial irresponsibility ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior hyper; speech fast, mood  affect good, thought fast, perception, cognitive functions impaired, judgement and insight poor ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 mood and impulsivity patient feels increased energy levels engages in shopping impulsively. 2 sleep reduced sleep and not experiencing tiredness during the day. 3 attitude feels heightened self-esteem and optimism like life is falling into place and describes herself as a new me. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Bipolar ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor.

dialogue: Therapist: Hey Erica, how are you doing today? ; Patient: Good, thank you. ; Therapist: You're doing good? ; Therapist: I was hoping today we could revisit the two chair technique. ; Therapist: We used it a few sessions ago, you might remember. ; Therapist: I knew in the last session, I felt like we were kind of getting to a point where we identified a conflict. ; Therapist: You know what I'm referring to? ; Patient: What do you mean kind of between part of me that wants to settle down, but then part of me that also wants to pursue my career and what I'm doing? ; Therapist: So we have a part that wants to settle down and a part that wants to keep going with the career. ; Therapist: So for this two chair, what I'd like to do is in the chair where you're seated now, this will be the emotional self, in this case the side that wants to pursue the career. ; Therapist: From what I saw before, that seems like we're more... ; Patient: That's what I really want, yes. ; Therapist: You're more emotionally connected, that's what you want. ; Patient: Yeah, that's what I want. ; Therapist: So this will be the side of you that has the needs and the wants and more the emotion. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So that's who you'll be in this chair. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Therapist: In the other chair, let's have that critic that's inside, that internal critic that's advocating for settling down, for getting married, for having kids. ; Therapist: In a way it represents a societal pressure. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do those two sides seem separate to you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You feel like you can be the emotional self here and the internal critic there? ; Patient: I think so. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I think you remember how this works. ; Therapist: You'll be talking to, in this case, the internal critic. ; Therapist: So the internal critic's on the side of settling down, getting married. ; Therapist: And then when you're ready to have the critic respond, you'll switch to that chair and respond to the emotional need-driven and wanting self. ; Therapist: Make sense? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So whenever you're ready, go ahead and speak directly to the internal critic. ; Patient: I want to finish what I'm doing and I want to finish what I started. ; Patient: I've worked so hard on my career path and I'm so close to finishing. ; Patient: And I want to finish for me. ; Patient: I want to accomplish those goals that I've set for myself. ; Patient: It's something I'm passionate about. ; Therapist: So you made your statement. ; Therapist: Are you ready to switch? ; Therapist: Okay, go ahead and switch. ; Therapist: So now you're the internal critic. ; Patient: There's always time to pursue a career, but I need to focus on what's expected of me at this time. ; Patient: I'm the best age for having kids. ; Patient: I have a loving boyfriend who is ready and wants to get married and settle down. ; Patient: And you are being selfish by just following a path that you can take at any time. ; Therapist: So the internal critic cues in the emotional side, in this case the career side, being selfish. ; Therapist: And notice your posture is very linear and you're upright. ; Therapist: And notice you kind of put your hand out a little bit when you were talking. ; Therapist: Try to think of the internal critic's body movements. ; Therapist: Try to act that out a little bit. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I think it's accusations. ; Patient: I just want to tell the emotional part that it's being stupid. ; Patient: You're not acting in the best interest of everyone else. ; Patient: You want to jump at it. ; Therapist: You want to jump at the emotional side? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So that's the internal critic. ; Therapist: Are you ready to respond back to the internal critic from the emotional side? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So the internal critic is just called selfish, among other things. ; Therapist: This is your response. ; Patient: It feels like I'm being attacked. ; Patient: And I don't think it's wrong to think about myself and what I'm truly passionate about. ; Therapist: Let me interrupt you. ; Therapist: So your hands, they're pointing back toward the career emotional self. ; Therapist: What can you do with your hands that really embody what you want to communicate to the internal critic? ; Therapist: Is there anything else you'd want to do? ; Therapist: Right now they're pointing toward you. ; Patient: They're pointing towards me to protect myself from what the critic is saying. ; Patient: I just want to push that back towards the critic. ; Therapist: When you use that motion, you're pushing the internal critic away. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So I don't need to feel guilty. ; Patient: I don't need to feel selfish for wanting to follow my dreams. ; Therapist: Does the internal critic have something to say back? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: I think the critic... ; Patient: I'll try. ; Patient: I'll try. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you've now pushed the emotional side, pushed the critic away. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: And I think the critic feels like it understands where the emotional side of me is coming from. ; Patient: Like I can recognize why it's so important and why working so hard is worth that sense of accomplishment that's going to come with it and how it's going to, in the long run, help provide for all these extra things that I want to... ; Patient: like my family in the future. ; Patient: I can see that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So the internal critic is... ; Therapist: Now you have your hands down here is the internal critic. ; Therapist: Is the internal critic less angry, less assertive? ; Patient: Less pushy. ; Therapist: Less pushy. ; Patient: Less pushy. ; Patient: Yeah, it's not as critical, truthfully. ; Patient: I feel like the pressure isn't weighing on either's shoulders. ; Patient: You know what I mean? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So the critic is more separated now, maybe a little bit, but also has a different outlook. ; Patient: More quiet. ; Patient: It's not like always yelling at me. ; Patient: Because I think it... I mean, sometimes it might still say something, but not in the urgency that it had before. ; Therapist: So the critic has lost some of its vigor and determination. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So move back to the emotional and then just face toward me. ; Therapist: What have you gained here through your communication back and forth with the internal critic? ; Patient: I feel calmer. ; Patient: I feel like the critic has always been a part of me, but that part of me is more... ; Patient: It's not as assertive. ; Patient: It's not as intense right now. ; Patient: It's calm. ; Patient: I think that the emotional part of me was able to win the argument, per se, because that's what I want. ; Therapist: So at the end of this conflict, after we split into the two parts here, at the end of this conflict is eventually a decision. ; Therapist: It's a decision to pursue a career or settle down. ; Therapist: Do you feel you gain more clarity in that decision? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Because I feel like I can stay on... my decision is and has been to stay on my career path, but now I feel less guilty for doing it. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So that's really been your decision all along, but the internal critic was harassing you this whole time. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Harassment is a good word. ; Therapist: Today you were able to shove that internal critic back a little and allow that internal critic to see how strong you feel with the decision you've made. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Is that accurate? ; Patient: Very much so. ; Therapist: Do you feel it was a helpful technique for you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: I think that separating the two sides helped me realize which one felt stronger. ; Therapist: So it was able to give you some clarity? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, let's... I want you to reflect on what's happened here between now and the next session. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I guess kind of a lot happened and it seems like you've gained clarity for your decision and then we'll pick up with the next session and see how things have progressed with... ; Therapist: See if that internal critic is still harassing you or if it kind of stays back and if you have more peace with the decision. ; Therapist: Does that sound like a plan? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Thanks, Erica. ; Therapist: I'll see you next week. ; Patient: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name erica, sex female ; Past Session Information: Follow -up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting complaint guilt and confusion chief complaint 1 internal critic and conflict 2 confusion ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nomral; speech, mood  affect, thought confused, judgement poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Emotion focused therapy by gestalt; dynamic supportive analytical; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Two chair technique ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem client feels internal conflict between pursuing her career goals and settling down to start a family which cause emotional tension and uncertainty. Feels guilty if she is prioritizing her career over settling down. 2 technique therapist introduced two chair technique to examine her internal dialogue which helped her gain insight into her conflicting desires and a sense of inner peace regarding her decision-making process. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Cmd ; Next session details: Next week

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Victor, I'm Dr. Sawyer. ; Therapist: Victor, can you tell me how old you are? ; Patient: I'm 20. ; Therapist: You're 20. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Where do you live? ; Patient: At home. ; Therapist: You live at home? ; Therapist: Who do you live with? ; Patient: Um, my mom, my dad, my sister. ; Therapist: Okay, so you live with your mom, dad, and sister. ; Therapist: Um, what do you do for work? ; Patient: I go to a co-op. ; Therapist: Okay, so you came to me to see me because I'm a doctor. ; Patient: I didn't come to you. ; Patient: My mom and dad and my sister drove me here. ; Patient: I didn't want to come. ; Therapist: Okay, are your mom and dad and sister here? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Okay, so I'll let you go back to them in a few minutes, but let's just get through a few questions. ; Patient: I want to get done now. ; Therapist: So Victor, tell me, how's your sleep been? ; Therapist: What about, have you been experiencing any lack of joy? ; Patient: Yes, I have. ; Patient: My teachers have been mean to me. ; Patient: My educational assistants have been mean to me. ; Patient: They always put me in timeouts. ; Patient: I'm really pressured. ; Therapist: Victor, are you going to calm down? ; Patient: I will not calm down. ; Therapist: Victor, if you don't stay in your seat, I'm going to have to call security. ; Patient: I never yell. ; Patient: This is the first time I'm yelling. ; Patient: This is the first time I'm pouring out my feelings on you. ; Therapist: You're yelling at me right now and I need you not to yell. ; Therapist: Are you on any medications right now? ; Patient: My mom and dad and my sister are on medications. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Yes or no, are you on any medications? ; Patient: Yes, I am. ; Therapist: Okay, I need you to bring me a list of your medications later. ; Therapist: So I'm going to give you a prescription for an antidepressant medication. ; Therapist: Can you bring it home to your mom and show it to her and then get it filled? ; Patient: I'll take that. ; Patient: It's none of your business. ; Therapist: Okay, so I'm just going to go to my computer and put it in and then my receptionist will print you off the medication. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Therapist: So good luck, Victor. ; Therapist: Hi, Victor. ; Therapist: I'm Dr. Sawyer. ; Therapist: Hi. ; Therapist: I'm a psychiatrist. ; Therapist: Do you know what a psychiatrist is? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So a psychiatrist is a doctor who deals with people who are feeling sad or mad, different feelings that they might have. ; Therapist: We'll talk for a little bit and we'll talk about some things that might have been difficult in your life over the past little bit. ; Therapist: And our goal is to try to make things, see how we can make things a little bit easier for you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: When I'm at school, I feel like they're not doing anything. ; Patient: They're not listening to me about how my feelings are. ; Therapist: So you feel pretty unheard. ; Patient: I feel unheard at school. ; Patient: My parents and my sister are hearing me. ; Therapist: So you said you've been feeling pretty sad. ; Therapist: How long have you been feeling sad for? ; Patient: Well, there's one teacher. ; Patient: I won't give out any names, but she doesn't listen to me. ; Patient: Okay? ; Patient: She just tries to keep me down. ; Therapist: How long have you had this teacher for? ; Patient: About four years. ; Therapist: Four years. ; Therapist: So have you been feeling sad for this entire four years or a shorter period of time? ; Patient: Shorter period of time. ; Therapist: So has it been a couple weeks, a couple months, a couple days? ; Patient: A couple months. ; Therapist: So Victor, I want to tell you some of my thoughts of what I think is going on, but I want to invite your sister in because I need to find out a little bit about your medical history. ; Therapist: So I'm just going to get her and then I'll come back, okay? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So I've been talking to Victor and he's been telling me about how he's had less interest in things, he's having trouble sleeping, he's feeling sad all the time. ; Therapist: And it does sound like he's been suffering from what we call a major depression. ; Therapist: And there's a couple of treatments that I want to talk about. ; Therapist: Do you know what medications Victor is on? ; Therapist: Yeah, so I actually brought a list because there's quite a few. ; Therapist: I can certainly give you all. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: Okay, so on this list it says about sort of what medical illnesses he's had and hospitalizations and surgeries as well. ; Therapist: There's a couple of treatments for depression. ; Therapist: One is medication and one is also doing some interventions within the school and within the family. ; Therapist: And there's a lot of things to think about, but it seems like things in the school have been really not going well. ; Therapist: And that's been a major contribution to his sadness.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name victor, sex male, age 20, patient came with mother, father and his sister ; Therapist Information : Name sawyer, psychiatrist ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms depressed chief complaints lack of joy anger outburst sadness trouble sleeping ; History: History of medical illnesses and hospitalizations for surgeries. ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior cooperative; speech disorganized, mood  affect dull, thought negative, perception, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient experiences significant stress and feelings of being unheard at school. He feels his teachers and educational assistants are mean to him and put him in timeouts, contributing to his feelings of pressure and sadness. He shows displays anger and frustration during the conversation. Also feels lack of joy and interest, trouble sleeping, and lack of interest in things. 2 reluctance to seek help patient was brought to the appointment by his family against his will, indicating reluctance to seek help and a possible lack of understanding or acceptance of his mental health issues. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sherry, how you're doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: You're doing okay? ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some symptoms which have been bothering you a bit. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what you think is going on? ; Patient: I've been feeling really low and I think I might be depressed. ; Therapist: You think you might be depressed? ; Therapist: Have you ever felt this way in the past? ; Patient: I mean years ago I had some of these similar things but I didn't really think about it much and this was going on for like, I've been feeling this way for like a month and I think something's wrong. ; Therapist: You've been having feelings of sadness, hopelessness? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I haven't been able to sleep. ; Therapist: Trouble sleeping? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: This has been going on for a month? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you noticed any change in your ability to experience fun or pleasure? ; Patient: I haven't really thought about it but I mean I still have fun sometimes but I just notice that most of the time I'm sad. ; Therapist: Most of the time you're sad but you still have fun? ; Therapist: Have you lost an interest in pursuing things that are fun? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I mean I still try. ; Patient: I try to distract myself. ; Patient: Like if I notice that I'm just feeling really low or even if I can't sleep at night, I'll go do something that I like doing to pass the time. ; Therapist: Any change in your appetite or weight in the last couple of weeks? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I haven't really been eating that much and I've actually lost a few pounds. ; Therapist: Lost a few pounds? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you mentioned the sleep disturbance. ; Therapist: You've not been sleeping as much as you'd like to. ; Patient: Correct. ; Patient: It's really hard for me to fall asleep and sometimes I'll just lie there for hours at night and it's awful because then I'm tired all day because I didn't sleep at night and when I get home it's time for bed again and I still can't fall asleep. ; Therapist: So that's been affecting your energy level? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you feel restless or the opposite, kind of like slowed down having either one of those feelings? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Have you been having any feelings of worthlessness? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: No, I mean, you know, like not really, no. ; Patient: Like I don't feel worthless. ; Patient: I just, you know, I just, I'm still sad though. ; Patient: I don't know why I'm sad. ; Therapist: How about your concentration level? ; Therapist: Any changes there? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's hard to concentrate at work and in general even at home because I just feel so tired, not sleeping and sometimes I just get distracted by like, you know, like I'll be overcome with emotion and I, out of nowhere, like it's hard for me to pay attention to what I'm doing if I'm getting distracted by those thoughts. ; Therapist: Have you been having any thoughts related to death or dying? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So these symptoms you've been describing have been causing limitations in your functioning in what areas? ; Patient: Well, at work. ; Therapist: At work? ; Patient: At work. ; Patient: At home too. ; Patient: I want to play with my cat. ; Patient: I usually play with my cat for like an hour every night just because, you know, I'm at work all day but I haven't, I've been having trouble like even doing that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: So I would say, and then even like my relationships too, like my social life, it's been affecting it. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Any drug or alcohol use? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: None. ; Therapist: How about any medical conditions? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing. ; Therapist: Do you ever see or hear things other people can't see or hear? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Has it ever happened to you? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Never. ; Therapist: Do you feel now recently or ever, you had a state where you were too happy, like had a lot of energy and... ; Patient: Like mania. ; Therapist: Like mania, yeah. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that ever. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Has there been any major event in the last month or maybe before that that you think might be causing this? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Patient: Nothing significant happened to make me feel this way. ; Therapist: Nothing you think would cause depression or anything? ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: All right, Sherry. ; Therapist: I'm going to get you in to see a counselor here. ; Therapist: It'll just take a couple days to get you in. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I want to thank you for answering these questions for me. ; Therapist: This has been helpful. ; Patient: You're welcome.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sherry; sex female ; Past Session Information: Follow up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms depressed chief complaints 1 sadness 2 sleep disturbance 3 decrease in appetite and weight 4 difficulty in concentration ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior dull; speech slow, mood  affect low, thought negative, perception, cognitive functions, judgement  poor and insight intact ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1problem patient feels sad and hopeless for about a month, having troubled sleep, affecting her energy levels and ability to function during the day. Her appetite has also decreased, and weight has reduced. 2 work life difficulty in concentrating at work and home due to feeling tired. She struggles to engage in activities. She feels that her depression may be more intrinsic or related to underlying factors rather than external stressors. 3 readiness for therapy shows willingness to see a counselor for more help. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression ; Action Plan : Assigned to a counselor

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Emma, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing good, thanks. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thank you for asking. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some symptoms that have been bothering you lately. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about that? ; Patient: Well, I just moved into an apartment and it's the first time that I'm on my own. ; Patient: I kind of had heard that someone got robbed and ever since then I'm kind of nervous about my apartment getting robbed. ; Therapist: Someone who's robbed near where you live? ; Patient: Yeah, someone in the same complex. ; Patient: So sometimes when I'm sleeping I'll wake up in the middle of the night and I'll think did I lock the door? ; Patient: Is the door unlocked? ; Patient: And I can't fall back asleep. ; Therapist: How long does it take you to fall back asleep? ; Patient: Sometimes it takes maybe an hour or two. ; Therapist: And what are you thinking about during that time? ; Patient: I'm just worried that I left the door unlocked and sometimes I'll hear sounds and I think maybe someone's in the apartment or I just get nervous. ; Patient: I just get scared that the door's unlocked. ; Therapist: That sounds scary. ; Therapist: You said a couple hours, you stay awake. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's a while. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So this is troubling for you. ; Therapist: Have you ever gotten up and checked the door? ; Patient: No, I stay in bed and I just try to, but I just think about it. ; Therapist: All right, so you just keep thinking about it. ; Therapist: Does it get worse as that time goes on or does it get better? ; Therapist: What happens? ; Patient: It gets worse. ; Patient: I mean I try to fall back asleep and I stay in bed and I just think maybe I did leave the door unlocked and then I just keep thinking that maybe it is unlocked. ; Therapist: So it kind of keeps cycling through the same. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you ever do anything to try to get those thoughts to go away like focusing on something else? ; Patient: Well, I have like a ceiling fan above me, so sometimes I'll just like count how many times it goes around and just try to distract myself from thinking about it, but I still think about the door being unlocked. ; Patient: Sometimes it helps. ; Therapist: All right, so you have a fear that somebody is going to enter or break into where you live and you're staying up at night thinking about whether the door has been secured. ; Therapist: That's been troubling you. ; Therapist: Anything else? ; Patient: Sometimes if I'm leaving for work, I'll get to my car and I'll think I left the hair straight neuron and I'll think to myself, should I go back? ; Patient: I don't know what to do and I'll just like kind of debate whether or not I should just go double check. ; Patient: I'm just worried that if I left the straight neuron, something that would happen. ; Therapist: What do you think might happen? ; Patient: If I left the straight neuron, something, if I have like clothes or something and it's on a cloth, like that could burn or if it's, I just don't want anything. ; Patient: I don't want the place to burn down. ; Patient: That's what I'm nervous about. ; Therapist: When you leave, you're thinking about, it was a hair straightener? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You're thinking about whether you unplugged it or not or turned it off or not? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How long those thoughts go on for? ; Patient: Normally I think about it before I get into my car and I'll be like, well maybe I should just go just to make sure I unplugged it and I turned it off and then sometimes during the day I'll be at work and I can't focus just because I'm thinking about, I'll come back and I'll see my apartment burned down because I left the straightener plugged in. ; Therapist: So I remember with the door you're saying that you struggle with those thoughts but you don't get up and check the door. ; Therapist: Have you ever come back and checked to see if something was left to want? ; Patient: No, I haven't but I just, I think about it. ; Patient: Like what if I did leave it on or plugged in? ; Therapist: So you're worried, anxious? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Afraid? ; Patient: Yeah, definitely, all afraid. ; Therapist: And how often does this happen, like the cycle of thoughts? ; Patient: Probably throughout the day. ; Therapist: So every day? ; Patient: Every day, yeah. ; Therapist: And how long has this been going on? ; Patient: Ever since I moved I guess into the apartment, so about I guess a year. ; Therapist: So this has been going on for a year? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And in that year timeframe has it become any worse? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How did it start out? ; Patient: It started out with just, you know, I would go to bed and I would wake up in the middle of the night and think to myself, did I lock the door? ; Patient: I'm pretty sure I locked the door. ; Patient: And then I would just be fine. ; Patient: I could go back to sleep and be like, no, I remembered I locked it. ; Patient: But then as it progressed I really, I would wake up multiple times throughout the night and I would, it would just keep me up. ; Therapist: As you thought about it. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right, I want to ask you a few other questions to try to help me figure out what's going on. ; Therapist: Have you ever been diagnosed with any condition, like a mental health condition? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about a medical condition? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Never? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Have you ever used alcohol or any other substances? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And has this been the first time in your life you've experienced these symptoms? ; Therapist: Like starting a year ago up until now? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Never? ; Therapist: Anything like this before? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Emma, I'm going to get you in to see one of our counselors here. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I appreciate you spending this time with me. ; Therapist: It's been helpful for me to try to understand what's going on. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks so much.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name emma, sex female ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms obsession and fear chief complaints 1 anxiety 2 disturbed sleep 3 lack of concentration 4 negative thoughts ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech, mood  affect tensed, thought negative, perception disturbed, cognitive functions impaired, judgement and insight poor ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 fear patient is fearful related to the security of her apartment. She has intrusive thoughts obsessions for the same which lead to significant distress and lead to disruptions in her sleep and daily activities. 2 problem her issues impacted her daily life, sleep patterns, difficulty concentrating at work, and preoccupation with safety-related concerns. 3 acceptance patient acknowledges the distress and willing to take help by a counselor. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Ocd ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor

dialogue: Therapist: Hi , how you're doing today. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some symptoms which have been bothersome. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about those? ; Patient: The main thing is I'm just sleeping all the time. ; Patient: I'm really tired. ; Patient: You know, I'm tired when I have to go to work and then I go home and I just sleep a lot and I think it's abnormal. ; Patient: I haven't been eating as much lately. ; Patient: I've lost a bit of weight and it's just affecting my life so I just want to come in. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you have excessive sleep. ; Therapist: You feel like what is excessive sleep? ; Patient: Like just hours. ; Patient: I'll get home from work and I'll take a three-hour nap and then I'll wake up and do something that I enjoy but then it will be bedtime again and I'll be ready for bed even though I took a nap and I'll sleep in at any chance I can. ; Patient: I don't wake up early or anything. ; Therapist: And you mentioned your appetite as well. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I just, I don't know if it's just because I'm sleeping so much I'm not eating but I just like when I wake up it's not like, well I'm hungry, nothing. ; Patient: Like I just. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How long have these symptoms been present? ; Patient: I mean I would say I've noticed it in the last two weeks or so. ; Therapist: Over the last two weeks? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I've noticed that it's been getting worse. ; Therapist: Out of, I'd say one week, how many days do you have these symptoms? ; Patient: Probably every day. ; Therapist: Every day? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: All right, so I'm going to ask you some other questions related to this, okay? ; Therapist: Just provide me the best answer you can. ; Therapist: In the last two weeks have you found yourself depressed, sad, hopeless, anything like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Have you lost interest in activities that used to be fun for you? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No, I mean I still like all the things I did, like all my hobbies, I like hanging out with friends and stuff. ; Patient: Sometimes it's hard for me to remember to make plans with people and I just end up sleeping instead, but I genuinely enjoy it still. ; Patient: I'd like to go and see people do those things. ; Therapist: Do you ever feel agitated in terms of movement, like you can't stop moving or find yourself trying to resist moving? ; Patient: I guess. ; Patient: I guess like not so much I can't stop moving, but I do try to like stop. ; Patient: Yeah, I guess I do try to like stop myself from fidgeting. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's been happening? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any changes in terms of your level of energy? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean like I said I'm tired all the time. ; Patient: Sometimes I just can't get up and late to work just because I haven't had the energy to get up and stop sleeping and wake up. ; Therapist: Alright, so the excessive sleep has affected your level of energy? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about any type of feeling of worthlessness or anything like that? ; Patient: I mean I guess yeah, I mean I'm not, it sounds harsh, but I'm not really a valuable person really. ; Patient: I don't have a very important job or anything. ; Patient: No one really depends on me. ; Therapist: You don't feel yourself as valuable? ; Patient: I mean no, not really, but it is what it is. ; Therapist: How long have you felt this way? ; Patient: You know for a while, you know, and you know when you don't contribute very much. ; Patient: So it is what it is. ; Therapist: How about your concentration? ; Therapist: Have you found any changes there in your ability to concentrate? ; Patient: At work, yes, definitely. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Because I'll be tired and yawning and even when it comes to like outside of work I guess I'll forget to make plans with friends or forget, I don't know, little things, just little things that I do forget a lot and it's hard for me to pay attention to movies. ; Patient: I don't know if it's because I'm tired or not, like I just... ; Therapist: Do you have trouble focusing? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you ever have any thoughts of death or dying? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: You mentioned that these symptoms have been causing problems at work. ; Therapist: Any other areas where they've been causing you trouble, like limiting your functioning? ; Patient: You mean like, like social life? ; Therapist: Social life, relationships, life at home. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean I live on my own and you know like sleeping all the time, like I don't see anyone else and you know it's hard to meet new people if I was looking for a relationship. ; Patient: Yeah, I would say it affects it because I'm not like putting myself out there or anything and you know I forget or I'll sleep instead of making plans with friends on a Friday night so that can't be good. ; Therapist: How about substances? ; Therapist: Do you use any alcohol or drugs? ; Therapist: You know like that? ; Patient: No, I mean I'll drink socially but I haven't really. ; Patient: Done that. ; Therapist: How about medical conditions? ; Patient: None. ; Therapist: None? ; Therapist: Do you ever see or hear things that other people can't see or hear? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Have you ever had that happen? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a period in your life where you're having it now where you're extremely happy and have a lot of energy? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Has that ever happened? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Alright, Sherry. ; Therapist: I'm going to refer you to see a counselor. ; Therapist: I'll just schedule it in so you can see them in the next couple days if that works for you. ; Patient: Yeah, that works fine. ; Therapist: That works fine. ; Therapist: I appreciate you answering these questions. ; Therapist: This has been helpful. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Marital status unmarried, name sherry, sex female ; Therapist Information : Psychiatrist ; Past Session Information: Follow up session, referred to a counselor. . ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms feels depressed and fatigued. Chief complaints 1 lack of energy 2 worthlessness 3 change in appetite and weight loss 4 hopelessness 5 excessive sleep ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior tired; speech slow, mood  affect low, thought negative, cognitive functions slightly distorted; judgement and insight poor, intact. ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1lack of energy and fatigue patient experiences excessive sleep, tiredness all the time. She has symptoms of depression, such as fatigue, low self-esteem, and difficulty concentrating. 2 decreased appetite and weight loss patient has decreased appetite and has lost weight recently. 3 self-esteem patient feels low self-worth, consider herself valuable and doesnt feel like she contributes much. 4 difficulty concentrating sherry struggles with concentration, both at work and in her personal life, possibly due to fatigue. 5 social relationships her social life and relationships got also affected and relationships. Its hard for her to make plans with her. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor after a couple of days. .

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jessica, how you doing today? ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Therapist: You're okay? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some difficulty with some symptoms lately. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Tell me about that. ; Patient: Well, I've been having a lot of anxiety. ; Patient: Just been stressed out lately. ; Patient: Irritable. ; Patient: You name it, I have it. ; Patient: The thing that's been troubling me the most though are these memories that don't seem to go away. ; Patient: No matter what I do, I just keep remembering this event and it's really taken a toll on me. ; Therapist: So you're having anxiety and a lot of other symptoms and you're having intrusive memories. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about the event? ; Patient: Well, I was in a car accident a couple months ago and it was a pretty bad accident but I was okay. ; Patient: I was injured. ; Patient: My car was messed up really bad. ; Patient: The driver of the other car, I think they were injured pretty bad, more severe than I was. ; Patient: And I just can't seem to get that accident out of my mind. ; Therapist: Does it keep replaying that accident? ; Patient: Yes, over and over. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about how you're experiencing that? ; Patient: Well, I could be just in the kitchen making a pot of coffee and all of a sudden I'm back there in the accident. ; Patient: I'm back in the car with the airbags deployed and sirens coming from a distance. ; Patient: I try to shake that feeling and I just can't. ; Patient: And that just overwhelms me so much that I can't do anything. ; Patient: I just have to go and sit down and I'm stuck in the house just scared to do anything. ; Therapist: So these times when you're reliving the accident, does something trigger that or does that happen just on its own? ; Patient: Sometimes things trigger it and sometimes they just come out of nowhere. ; Patient: I could be watching a movie and there's a bad car accident and I start thinking about it or I could be just doing nothing and the memories, they just come back full force. ; Therapist: So this has been clearly causing you distress. ; Patient: A lot. ; Therapist: Has it been interfering at all with relationships? ; Patient: Well, yes, I would say. ; Patient: I haven't been able to go out with my friends. ; Patient: I just don't want to do anything. ; Patient: My friends are always trying to get me to go out and get things off of my mind and I just don't have a desire to. ; Patient: I don't really want to be around anyone. ; Therapist: Do you find that your mood is irritable or any anger at first? ; Patient: All the time. ; Therapist: That happens frequently? ; Patient: Yeah, I'm on edge a lot. ; Therapist: Do you feel like your behavior has become reckless, like taking more chances? ; Patient: Somewhat. ; Therapist: Somewhat? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about your memory of the accident? ; Therapist: Is it constant or does your memory change, like you lose some of that memory? ; Patient: Well, there are times when, where it's as clear as a bell and then other times people ask me details about the accident and I can't remember a thing. ; Therapist: You can't remember any of it? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: So the memory kind of comes and goes. ; Patient: It does, yes. ; Therapist: Who do you hold responsible for the accident? ; Patient: Well, everybody tells me that I shouldn't but I hold myself responsible for it. ; Patient: I mean, I try to go in a different way, home from work one day. ; Patient: It was a way that I've never gone before and, you know, somebody cut me off and I slammed into them but if I didn't go that way, I would have never gotten into the car accident. ; Therapist: Did the other driver get a ticket from the accident? ; Patient: I think he did. ; Patient: I think he got a ticket for reckless driving or failure to yield or something but, I mean, ; Patient: if I wasn't on that road, then neither of us would have been in the accident. ; Therapist: So you still blame yourself? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about your emotional state? ; Therapist: Since these symptoms have started, has it been mostly unhappy or down, neutral, anytime when you're happy? ; Patient: No, nothing seems to make me happy anymore. ; Patient: I'm just always depressed. ; Therapist: Your mood's always down. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about with driving? ; Therapist: Like, so have you been avoiding driving or have you driven since the accident? ; Patient: I have but I don't if I don't have to. ; Patient: Like, I definitely avoid going places like if I'm making dinner and I'm missing an ingredient, then I'll just go without it before driving to the market. ; Patient: I just I don't want to be behind the wheel of a car. ; Therapist: So you're avoiding it but you have driven. ; Patient: I have. ; Therapist: Tell me about the experience when you go to drive. ; Patient: Oh, boy. ; Patient: So I have to almost prepare myself hours in advance because it's so hard for me to get out the house. ; Therapist: In terms of anxiety or what's going on? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: I'm just having like knots in my stomach and, you know, shortness of breath. ; Patient: My chest is pounding. ; Patient: I'm just fearful. ; Patient: Just it's a lot. ; Patient: It's very overwhelming. ; Therapist: It's very stressful. ; Patient: It is. ; Therapist: Do you find that when you are driving that you are more aware of what other cars are doing and what you're doing in your car? ; Patient: Yeah, probably more so now than ever. ; Patient: I'm just always looking out, making sure that I don't cause another car accident. ; Patient: I'm driving slower. ; Patient: I'm, you know, I'm waiting longer to switch lanes. ; Patient: It's just, yeah, definitely. ; Therapist: You're more aware of your surroundings. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Therapist: So when something surprises us, there's a natural response or startled. ; Therapist: This is called a startled response. ; Therapist: And everybody has that. ; Therapist: Have you noticed that that's changed for you since these symptoms have started? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How's it changed? ; Patient: Anything. ; Patient: Everything startles me anymore. ; Patient: The doorbell ringing, the phone ringing, just, you know, somebody getting up to move their chair. ; Patient: Any little sound that just has me like looking over my shoulder to see what's going on. ; Therapist: And you find yourself jumping? ; Patient: Yeah, a lot. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about your ability to concentrate? ; Therapist: Has that changed at all? ; Patient: It has. ; Patient: It decreased a lot. ; Patient: I haven't really been able to concentrate on anything. ; Patient: I have things all over my house where I've started things and moved on to something else because I can't concentrate on one thing. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about sleeping? ; Therapist: How are you doing with sleep? ; Patient: Not too good. ; Patient: I'm not getting a lot of sleep at all these days. ; Patient: I'm up all hours of the night sometimes. ; Patient: I just wake up for no reason. ; Patient: Sometimes I'll wake up out of a dream just scared. ; Patient: I'm just... I'm not sleeping well at all. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So a lot of challenges with sleep. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Do you use any drugs or alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: How about medical problems? ; Patient: Never. ; Therapist: I like that. ; Therapist: Are there times from when these symptoms started when you feel kind of separated from your own body? ; Therapist: Like it's like an unreal experience? ; Patient: I've had a couple experiences like that. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about those? ; Patient: Well, there was one time I was at work and we were sitting in the cafeteria and just all of a sudden everything seemed to start going in slow motion. ; Patient: And I could hear people talking but it sounded very slow. ; Patient: It was like, it's hard to describe but I could see everything but it just wasn't moving at a normal pace. ; Patient: I kind of felt like I was watching a movie almost. ; Patient: And that's happened at least two or three times. ; Patient: And I didn't really understand what was going on. ; Patient: A friend of mine told me, she said that I was kind of like spaced out and she was like snapping her fingers in front of my face and I could see her but I couldn't really hear what was going on. ; Patient: And then I just like snapped out of it. ; Patient: And everybody was sitting around staring at me and they were talking about what was going on and I had no idea what was happening. ; Patient: But it was very embarrassing. ; Patient: They were watching me like I was a movie. ; Therapist: This has happened a few times? ; Patient: Yeah, in a couple different locations. ; Patient: One time I was at work, one time I was at school and these things just happened out of the blue. ; Therapist: How about a time when you felt like the world became unreal? ; Therapist: So you're not detached from your body but the world becomes unreal or dreamlike or distorted. ; Therapist: Have you ever had that happen? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: It's more being separated from your body, more that feeling? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you mentioned the time slowing down? ; Patient: Yeah, very, like slow motion. ; Therapist: Slow motion? ; Patient: Yeah, like you were watching a movie in slow motion. ; Patient: The sound and everything was just dragging. ; Therapist: Jessica, I'm going to get you in to see a counselor here if you're okay with that. ; Patient: Yes, I think that would be okay. ; Therapist: I appreciate you taking the time to explain these symptoms. ; Therapist: I know they're distressing for you and for taking the time to answer my questions. ; Therapist: It's been helpful for me to help figure out what's going on and help manage your care. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Patient: I appreciate your help. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jessica; sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Repeated reliving of the trauma 2. Intrusive flashbacks 3. Detachment from others 4. Episodes of pounding heart and shortness of breath 5. Low mood 6. Hypervigilance associated disturbance decreased sleep, difficulty concentrating ; History: Present history patient met with an accident a few months back when she was driving. She took a different way to her home where another car crossed her and both the vehicles bumped leaving the passengers injured. Patient was not hurt much but the people in other the car were injured. Patient blames herself for the incident however according to what others tell her is that it wasnt her fault and the others passengers had got the ticket for causing the accident. Patient often feels as if she is reliving that incident with or without the presence of any triggers. She is also become hypervigilant and and feels detached from others. She often experiences shortness of breath and a pounding heart. She usually has a low mood and has been sleeping less; substance use history she doesnt consume any psychoactive substance. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood dysphoric; affect restricted; thought content reflected guilt; insight grade 4. ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient told about the accident she met with a few months back which bothers her even now. She gets flashbacks of the event which aggravates her other symptoms. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F43. 1 post-traumatic stress disorder ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Glad you came in today. ; Therapist: How's it going today for you? ; Patient: Um, I'm just kind of the same as it's been for the last few months. ; Patient: Um, not getting any better. ; Patient: Still feeling pretty down. ; Therapist: Well, from last week when we talked, I mean, kind of talk about your situation, getting injured on the job, and if we're losing your job, you kind of get in the way you didn't want to do anything, and sleeping a lot. ; Therapist: And then your wife left you and took the kids. ; Therapist: I just went very hard on you. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And so, when I had you take that inventory, um, answering all those questions, I kind of scored that, and in fact do have pretty severe depression. ; Therapist: So... Yeah. ; Patient: I think I already knew that. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Not a surprise. ; Patient: I guess it's nice to get validation on that. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So what I thought we might do today, if it's okay with you, is, um, there's a therapy I'd like to try with you to kind of address your depression. ; Therapist: It's called cognitive behavioral therapy. ; Therapist: I don't know if you've ever heard of that. ; Patient: I think I may have heard the name before. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'll describe it a little bit to you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So if we can kind of work on that therapy to kind of help your depression, and I'm thinking this might impact a lot of areas in your life, getting to work and relationships and stuff, so you kind of focus on the depression right now. ; Therapist: And then I'd like to, after I've talked about that and some situations where you're feeling depressed, if we can... ; Therapist: I want to give you some tools maybe to take home this week to kind of talk about the situations of your depression and thoughts and feelings and stuff, and then so next week we can have some concrete stuff to think about. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that sound okay with you that we do that today? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I don't want to try anything, so... ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Well, that's a big part of it. ; Therapist: Your willingness to try is a big key part in cognitive behavioral therapy because you're willing to do the work to get better. ; Therapist: So... Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Let me tell you a little bit about the cognitive behavioral therapy. ; Therapist: Sometimes it's called CET, just those initials. ; Therapist: And it takes an individual, a situation that's happening with an individual, a thought that automatically comes into the mind of that individual, how it makes them feel, and then how they respond because of that feeling. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Therapist: So we'll take an example, like, tell me about the last time that you were feeling depressed. ; Patient: Uh, I'd say probably this morning. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What was going on this morning? ; Patient: You know, I just woke up. ; Patient: I think it was like 10 o'clock or so and just couldn't get out of bed. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you woke up and couldn't get out of bed. ; Therapist: What's the first thought that came into your mind? ; Patient: Um, I think at first I thought, you know, why would I get out of bed? ; Patient: There's no reason for me to get out of bed. ; Patient: I mean, my wife's calling. ; Patient: Don't really have many friends anymore. ; Patient: Don't have a job. ; Patient: You know, what's the point of getting out of bed this morning? ; Therapist: How'd that make you feel about yourself? ; Patient: Worthless, I guess. ; Patient: I mean, like, I don't really even matter. ; Patient: I just made me feel really, really bad and worthless. ; Therapist: Because of that feeling, what would you do? ; Therapist: Were you able to get out of bed or just stayed in bed? ; Patient: Stayed in bed until I came here. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I was in bed most of the day. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm going to congratulate you for getting out of bed and coming here today. ; Therapist: That's a big step. ; Therapist: I'm glad you're here. ; Patient: Me too. ; Therapist: Do you often have those feelings when you're a person of worthlessness? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'd say most of the time. ; Patient: That's how I feel. ; Patient: That's kind of what causes it, I think. ; Therapist: And typically, is your response to that feeling stay in bed or... ; Patient: I mean, if I'm... Emogalizes you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, if I'm in bed at the time, then yeah, I won't get out. ; Patient: I mean, sometimes I'll be on the couch and start thinking and feeling like that and then I'll just... ; Patient: I won't move. ; Patient: Just kind of just... lay there. ; Therapist: Let me ask you, Tommy. ; Therapist: Can you remember a time when you weren't depressed? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, before the accident worked. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Lots of times. ; Patient: And spending time with my kids. ; Therapist: Tell me a little bit about those times. ; Therapist: When you can remember before the accident, when you were experiencing some depression. ; Patient: Um... I mean, I'd be laying in bed in the morning. ; Patient: My kids would run, jump, and wake me up and kind of irritate me a little bit. ; Patient: But, I mean, I love having them do that. ; Patient: Get up and make pancakes and have a big long breakfast. ; Patient: And then, if it was on the weekend, then we'd go do something fun like go to the park or go see a movie or something like that. ; Therapist: Can you remember how you felt back then? ; Therapist: How'd you feel when those activities were going on? ; Patient: I just felt good. ; Patient: I just... I mean, I felt loved by my kids and I loved them. ; Patient: It was just great. ; Patient: I just felt good. ; Therapist: Did it kind of feel like the opposite of worthless? ; Therapist: I mean, they needed you and you felt good and you felt loved and you felt engaged in their life. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It was the opposite of what I feel now. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So, sometime when you have these worthless feelings and not being able to get out of bed, do you think it would help you to think about times when you felt pretty good about yourself? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, I guess I've never tried that before. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I don't know if it'll work. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: I'd be willing to try. ; Therapist: I'd be kind of willing to try that. ; Therapist: So, maybe when you're feeling down, can't get off the couch, can't get out of bed. ; Therapist: I think of some times when it was different for you. ; Therapist: You were in a different situation. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: But, and you certainly didn't feel this way. ; Therapist: You didn't feel this way because you felt loved, engaged. ; Therapist: Important part of you. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's fun. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What about when you were working? ; Therapist: How did you feel about yourself at work? ; Patient: Well, I worked in a factory and we made car parts and stuff and I don't know. ; Patient: I felt like I was doing something. ; Patient: I mean, I was making parts that were going to go in a car, which then someone would use to drive to their job or drive their families. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: So, I felt like I was doing something. ; Patient: Like, I had a purpose. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Then the accident happened and I lost that. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: And that's when I started to feel worthless. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: I'm glad you can still feel or remember some times when you felt that you did have a purpose and you felt loved and valued. ; Therapist: And I know with depression, it's hard to get up and get out of bed. ; Therapist: That's some of the, and a lot of people will say, you know, if I, I'm going to wait until I feel better and then I'm going to get up and I'm going to get out of bed and then I'm going to do. ; Therapist: A lot of times with depression, what you actually have to do, you have to get up out of bed and do something and then you feel better. ; Therapist: And I know it's kind of hard to do that with these feelings that you're feeling right now. ; Patient: Yeah, but I mean, I think that makes sense. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: You said? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And sometimes it's helpful to have something scheduled or planned. ; Therapist: Right now in your, in your life, tell me some things that you might enjoy doing. ; Therapist: Might, could think about be worth getting out of bed in order to do. ; Patient: Um, I would say seeing my wife and kids, but I don't know if that's really an option right now. ; Patient: Um, I always loved fishing. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah, I always, always enjoyed doing that. ; Therapist: When was the last time you went fishing? ; Patient: Uh, it was a long time ago. ; Patient: I mean, right before the accident happened. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Are you recovered enough from the accident in which you could go fishing? ; Therapist: Is that a reality? ; Therapist: Is that something that you could do? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I think I could. ; Patient: Okay, great. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So fishing is something that, that would be an important. ; Therapist: Are there any other activities or meeting with people? ; Therapist: And those remind me, is your wife out of town and your kids consider it a little bit more difficult to maybe see them on a regular basis? ; Patient: Yeah, they're out of town. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Other activities besides fishing that you might enjoy doing or being with people or things you enjoy doing or need pleasure in life? ; Patient: I mean, I used to get together with my buddies and we usually had like a cookout or something at somebody's house and watch football or sit around and talk. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Um, yeah, we always, I mean, we all had family so as kind of, we'd all get together and just kind of get away for a little bit. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: That sounds fun. ; Therapist: Is that something that might be able to be planned or you might be able to have a get together with at least one if it's not the whole group, you know, one or two of your old buddies? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I think, I think we could do that. ; Patient: I mean, I just hadn't talked to them forever. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Patient: I mean, when I, after the accident, since I've been feeling so down, I haven't really made any effort with them at all and they kind of tried at first but then I just never followed up with any of them. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: But I mean, I guess I might be willing to try. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's another good suggestion. ; Therapist: As far as what do, is there an activity you should do even by yourself, either playing an instrument or listen to music or exercising or watching movies or something that gives you pleasure that you don't necessarily need, I mean, fishing is a good one. ; Therapist: I know you don't really need anybody else for but I'm just thinking in case your buddies were busy, I'm thinking of another thing you might want to do that brings you pleasure or something. ; Patient: I mean, working out was always something that I did. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And how did that make you feel when you worked out? ; Patient: Well, during the workout, I got tired. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: I always felt really good afterwards. ; Patient: Afterwards, okay. ; Patient: Yeah, like I had done something. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: I was like, I need to come up with something. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: So, yeah, working out is definitely something I used to do a lot, get a lot out of. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Now, those are some good suggestions of things that you might want. ; Therapist: It's, you probably need to start out slow in scheduling some things but it's nice to have, if you can, something on your agenda every day in order for you to get out of bed for. ; Therapist: It might be a workout. ; Therapist: It might be going fishing. ; Therapist: It might be calling a buddy to schedule something or it might be hanging out with a friend. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, Tommy, I'd like your goal this next week and you can write it on this piece of paper right here, kind of journal about it. ; Therapist: You know, put the date and go ahead and put, I'd like you to have some, you can first talk about maybe when you're in bed and can't get out. ; Therapist: You can write about your thought, the automatic thought that's coming into your mind, you know. ; Therapist: I'm in bed and the automatic thought is? ; Patient: There's no reason for me to get out of bed. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: No reason to get out of bed. ; Therapist: And then you use the word worthless, whatever that automatic thought that comes in your mind, write that down. ; Therapist: And then write down how that makes you feel. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And then you mentioned often your action or your response to that feeling is just to stay in bed. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So, I'd like for you to go ahead and log those emotions when those situations occur, you know, the situation, the thought, the emotion and your reaction to it. ; Therapist: But another thing I'd like for you to do is if you can schedule one event a day, alright, that you would enjoy doing. ; Therapist: And it could be a phone call, it doesn't have to be getting that. ; Therapist: And give yourself a break. ; Therapist: Know that this is going to be difficult and you're going to start out slow and you're going to work up to it. ; Therapist: But just one event a day. ; Therapist: I want you to log as well, you know, where there is. ; Therapist: I called my kids or I called my buddy to schedule something or I went to work out. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And I also would like for you to write down how you felt about yourself after you did that. ; Therapist: After the phone call, how you felt about yourself. ; Therapist: After the workout, how it made you feel. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: After you got together with your buddies. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So go ahead and document this progression and then log the different activities that's here. ; Therapist: And then we'll talk about it next week. ; Therapist: And we can talk about what's, you know, these automatic thoughts and then any of these activities. ; Therapist: And if any of these activities are actually helping. ; Therapist: It might take a while, Tommy. ; Therapist: You have to be patient with the process, be patient with yourself and other people. ; Therapist: I mean you mentioned a while ago that your buddies, you know, they tried connecting with you and it was maybe difficult. ; Therapist: And they'll probably be glad that you're wanting to reengage with them. ; Therapist: So that might be an encouragement to you as well. ; Therapist: So is this something that you can work on this week? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Does it feel overwhelming or? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I mean I feel good about that. ; Patient: I mean it's just going to be different. ; Patient: But like I said I'm willing to try whatever I need to right now. ; Therapist: I think that's a good part of this, the willingness to try. ; Therapist: And the patience that's going to be the process and take time. ; Therapist: But we'll go through this step at a time and we can talk about it and see what's working and what's not working. ; Therapist: And we can make changes on it. ; Therapist: But I think this CBT really helps you think about, you know, what's going on and why am I feeling this way. ; Therapist: You know, identifying the thoughts in your mind and why I might be thinking of this and why I'm reacting because of this. ; Therapist: And you might even rate your emotion and say, yesterday I felt, you know, my feeling of worthlessness on a scale from 1 to 100 was 90. ; Therapist: But today it's actually 80. ; Therapist: And maybe next week it might be 70. ; Therapist: So if you want to add a particular number to associate your, the association with that feeling of worthlessness, if you want to kind of put a value on it. ; Therapist: And we can kind of see how that adjusts with time. ; Therapist: That might be helpful. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: That sounds like it would be helpful. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: We'll talk about that next time. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Thank you.
