dialogue: Patient: I don't want to talk to you anymore. ; Patient: You're all the same. ; Patient: All of you. ; Patient: I have been wasting my time. ; Patient: I have been wasting my time. ; Patient: You're all the same. ; Patient: All of you guys are exactly the same. ; Patient: You ask me to come in and just... ; Patient: I don't want to talk to you anymore because I come in here and I talk and I talk and I talk and I talk and I don't get anything out of it. ; Patient: You're all the same. ; Therapist: When you say we're all, you mean... ; Patient: You're all of you. ; Patient: All of you. ; Therapist: All therapists? ; Patient: All therapists. ; Patient: All of you guys are exactly the same. ; Patient: You're all the same. ; Patient: No matter which one I've been to, I always go thinking, I'm going to get helped, I'm going to get helped, and then I get nothing out of it. ; Patient: I'm wasting my time. ; Patient: There is no point in me coming back here anymore. ; Patient: There really is no point because you're all exactly the same. ; Patient: You all sit there just like you're sitting here right now. ; Patient: You all sit there just like that and you just stare at me. ; Patient: You just stare at me and you don't do anything for me. ; Patient: You don't help me. ; Patient: There is no help. ; Patient: There's just talk, talk, talk, talk, talk, talk, talk, and I never get anything out of it. ; Patient: So what's the point? ; Patient: There's no point in me coming here anymore. ; Patient: There really is no point. ; Therapist: Okay, I mean, I'm having a couple of reactions to what you're saying. ; Therapist: One is that you're saying you're all the same. ; Patient: You are all the same. ; Patient: You are all the same. ; Patient: I've been to four of you guys. ; Patient: Nothing is working. ; Patient: Nothing is working. ; Patient: You're all the same. ; Therapist: I'm feeling just lumped in with everybody else right now. ; Patient: Well, you are because you're all the same. ; Patient: Of course, you're lumped in with everybody. ; Patient: I'm not going to single you out. ; Patient: I'm not going to make you single you out because you're all not doing anything. ; Patient: You don't do anything. ; Patient: There's all this abstract metaphysical stuff and there's no concrete, this is the way to fix it. ; Patient: This is the goal. ; Patient: There's nothing. ; Patient: So what's the point? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I mean, is there something specific right now that I could say or do that would give you what you're wanting or needing? ; Patient: How do I go from point A to point B? ; Patient: How do I get better? ; Patient: How do I fix what's going on? ; Patient: I mean, that's the reason I came here, right? ; Patient: I thought that was the reason I came here. ; Patient: It was to fix things. ; Patient: Make things better. ; Therapist: So you want a step-by-step description of how? ; Patient: Well, something. ; Patient: I need something to grab onto. ; Therapist: You need something to hold onto? ; Patient: I need something to grab onto. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: See, my sense is that you sort of desperately want something to grab onto to give you some sense of hope. ; Therapist: I really want to be able to give you something, but it feels like there's something about the kind of intensity of your sort of demand or plea right now, which makes it difficult for me to really sort of respond in a way that's going to give you what you need. ; Therapist: Or a better way of putting it is I have a sense that the kind of thing that you want or you're needing has to kind of come out of an organic process between the two of us. ; Therapist: And there's something about the sort of intensity of your desperation, which makes it difficult for you to really be open and receptive to whatever I have to give. ; Patient: That's just the way I am. ; Patient: I always come out like that. ; Patient: I always ... It's the way I get things. ; Patient: It's the only way I get things. ; Patient: It's the only way I know how to be. ; Patient: I come out one of two ways. ; Patient: I come out either full throttle, just full tilt. ; Patient: Just come at them and just do it that way. ; Patient: Or I don't do anything at all. ; Patient: So it's like I'm one way and it's not good enough. ; Patient: And I'm the other way and it's not good enough. ; Therapist: So it's like damned if you do and damned if you don't. ; Patient: Damned if I do, damned if I don't. ; Patient: If I go one way at everybody, it doesn't seem to make a difference one way or the other. ; Patient: And then if I'm just quiet and just falling with the crowd, it doesn't matter either. ; Therapist: It sounds like it feels like you only have two choices. ; Therapist: You can either approach the situation kind of on the attack with both guns blazing. ; Patient: That's a good way to describe it. ; Patient: Both guns blazing. ; Therapist: Or the alternative is to kind of go along and compromise yourself in some way. ; Therapist: Of those two, which feels better or which feels worse? ; Patient: The both guns blazing always feels better. ; Patient: Because if I go at somebody with full force and hit them over the head and just go at them, even if they turn away, it doesn't really matter. ; Patient: Because I've already said my piece and said what I had to say. ; Patient: But if I don't say anything and I just sit back and don't do anything, then it just gets me as angry as the both guns blazing. ; Patient: So it just eats me up. ; Patient: But it eats me up in here and I get even angrier than if I just blurt it all out and get it all out. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Yeah, I can imagine that. ; Therapist: At least if you're going in there with both guns blazing, there's a way in which you can kind of feel okay about yourself in some way, even though you're not getting your needs met. ; Therapist: But somehow they're sort of giving in. ; Therapist: It's like you're giving away part of yourself in some way. ; Therapist: It seems to me that the dilemma is that you have no good way of getting your needs met right now. ; Therapist: You sort of desperately need something. ; Patient: There's no middle ground. ; Therapist: There's no middle ground. ; Therapist: So I'm not sure exactly what that middle ground is right now, but I'm willing to work with you to really work on discovering what that middle ground is. ; Therapist: Does that seem worthwhile? ; Patient: I have to. ; Patient: I have to find a middle ground. ; Therapist: What are you feeling right now? ; Patient: Just it bothers me. ; Patient: I can't go one way or the other. ; Patient: I try to do one thing and I can't do it. ; Patient: I try to do it the other way. ; Patient: I can't do it. ; Patient: I'm just stuck. ; Therapist: There's a real kind of sadness there and maybe a hopelessness. ; Patient: I don't know what to do. ; Patient: It feels like there's nothing I can do. ; Patient: There's just no good way of doing it. ; Patient: It almost feels like what's the point? ; Therapist: Yeah. You look at me, in the sense of what's going on for you ; Therapist: It's almost as if you're asking for something. ; Patient: I need something. ; Patient: I can't get it myself. ; Therapist: You know, I hear that. I hear that. ; Therapist: I hear your desperation and I hear your sadness and your pain and your hopelessness. ; Therapist: I'll do my best to help you.

dialogue: Patient: I don't know, like, it's uncomfortable because it sucks. ; Patient: Like this therapy is just like, I'm not getting anywhere. ; Patient: Like it's just not like doing anything. ; Patient: So yeah, it's uncomfortable to talk about because it's just like, I don't know. ; Therapist: My sense is that you were trying to say something and then you just kind of almost like gave up there. ; Patient: Well, I don't know what, I'm trying to talk about it. ; Patient: And I don't know what else like you want me to do. ; Patient: I told you that I'm not feeling like I'm getting something out of the therapy. ; Patient: I feel like I'm being pretty clear, but I guess I'm not. ; Therapist: Are you feeling angry at me? ; Patient: I mean, I'm feeling angry that the therapy isn't working. ; Patient: Like I've been saying. ; Patient: I'm feeling angry that like I'm still in the place that I'm in, even though I've been trying. ; Patient: I'm like just feeling like pissed in general, you know? ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So, you know, I understand that you're pissed in general, but are you angry at me? ; Therapist: I mean, it sounds to me, my sense is that you're feeling angry at me right now. ; Therapist: If you are, I really want to know about it. ; Patient: Well, I mean, I guess there is a part of me that's like a little, yeah, a little angry that you're not helping me. ; Patient: I came as therapy because I wanted to feel better. ; Patient: And yeah, I mean, I guess I am feeling angry that that's not like what I'm getting from you, even though that's what I'm trying to get. ; Therapist: So, yeah, you're sounding really exasperated to me. ; Therapist: How does it feel to tell me about this? ; Patient: It feels hard. ; Patient: I mean, I'm, it feels hard to say that I'm angry. ; Patient: It's like not a feel, it's not a comfortable thing to say or not a comfortable thing to feel. ; Patient: It's just like makes me like, it's not, it's just like, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, you know, I don't want to push you too hard, but can you say any more about what you're, what's uncomfortable about this? ; Therapist: I mean, I do understand that it's uncomfortable. ; Patient: I mean, it's not something I would like ordinarily say to someone that I'm angry at them. ; Patient: So it feels like, I feel like I'm kind of anxious now, like even saying it, like, I don't want you to think I just like, that it's like your fault. ; Patient: It just like feels like I'm like, that's something I'm really not supposed to say. ; Therapist: So I mean, part of it sounds like is you're concerned that I'm going to feel like you're blaming me. ; Patient: I mean, yeah, I guess. ; Patient: I don't want to do that, but yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: But it is hard to feel like this, I feel like I'm alone in this therapy that like, I've been coming here and trying and I'm just not like getting anything from you. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So that, that sounds really important, right? ; Therapist: It sounds like you're, you know, it's hard to say this to me, but you're, you know, you're feeling angry at me. ; Therapist: Maybe you're feeling disappointed. ; Therapist: You're feeling all alone. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Like you can't even really talk with me about this. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It feels really hard. ; Patient: I want to be able to. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I'm really glad that you're, you know, that we're talking about this and you're able to tell me more. ; Therapist: How are you feeling about, about, you know, talking about it? ; Patient: I mean, I'm still feeling a little anxious, but I mean, I think it's, but it feels better that it's like out there, I guess that I've like said it and I think maybe that helps. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So at least it's out there. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So maybe we can go from here.

dialogue: Therapist: Hello, Kathy. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You okay? ; Therapist: I know when you spoke last time, you had some goals that you want to talk about this time. ; Therapist: Are you ready to do that? ; Patient: I need to, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: What do you have in mind? ; Patient: I just keep thinking about losing this weight and I just, I really want to do it. ; Patient: I just can't get there and I don't know why. ; Therapist: So you're frustrated. ; Patient: It's so ridiculous. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Frustrated trying to lose the weight. ; Therapist: Now you had said before that you had a specific number of pounds in mind, specific amount of weight to lose. ; Therapist: Do you still have that in mind? ; Patient: I would like 20 pounds. ; Therapist: 20 pounds. ; Patient: I mean, I would like more, but I've tried to do more in the past and I don't even get past a couple of days. ; Patient: So if I can do 20, that would be great. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: What have you tried before and what do you think got in the way? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I guess it wasn't convenient. ; Patient: I want to do it and it means a lot for me and my family. ; Patient: I think I'd be a lot healthier. ; Therapist: It's important to you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: But just like something always gets in the way, you know, and then I lose focus. ; Patient: I'm not very good at staying focused on stuff like that anyway. ; Patient: So. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So loss of focus. ; Therapist: So you start trying to lose the weight and your focus gets disrupted. ; Patient: And I forget and then I make, you know, spaghetti casserole for six people and then I eat a lot of it and that's carbs and cheese and fat. ; Patient: And then I, you know, we'll eat what my kids don't eat. ; Patient: And then it's just like, I forget that I'm supposed to be making healthy choices. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you know how to lose weight and you know you can lose weight, but your focus is a little off when you're trying and that's causing the problem. ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Could we break that goal of losing 20 pounds down into smaller units like say five pounds? ; Patient: Do you think, well maybe. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Um, cause I've never, I always just keep like the chunk of weight, you know, ahead of me. ; Patient: I don't break it into smaller income. ; Patient: It's not my work. ; Patient: I mean, I don't know how I'd have to stay on top of it though. ; Patient: Weigh myself every day. ; Therapist: Is that something you can do? ; Patient: I'm so busy. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Or once a week. ; Patient: I probably do once a week. ; Patient: Put a sticky note somewhere or something. ; Patient: You know, maybe. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I want to try. ; Patient: I'm going to say yes cause I want to try it. ; Therapist: So you mentioned the loss of focus is one problem. ; Therapist: How about motivation? ; Therapist: Do you feel motivated to move through all those steps like five pounds and five pounds and so on? ; Patient: Right now? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: I think I would need something to keep me going, you know, week to week. ; Therapist: A little bit of something extra to help you stay motivated. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Sometimes when your kid does their homework early and you can give them a special treat for dessert, that helps keep it going. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So some sort of activity or item that you enjoy that you could reserve for when you reach that goal of say the first five pounds. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I would love, I mean, I'm just, I've been so embarrassed, you know, lately. ; Patient: So I feel like I just, if I can find something that keeps me motivated, that would be great. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do you have a activity or item in mind that we could put in place as something you could reward yourself with? ; Patient: Like after the first five pounds? ; Therapist: Well, there's a few ways we could do it. ; Therapist: We could do that. ; Therapist: So you reach five pounds and then you can give yourself that reward. ; Therapist: Or it could be for something you do every day if that day you're successful in eating the way you want to eat. ; Therapist: What do you think would motivate you more? ; Patient: Maybe something every day? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: So I remember, you know, I just get so distracted by other stuff. ; Patient: There was something every day that maybe I put out almost like a goal at the end of the day or something. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: You know, if I made the right choices. ; Therapist: Yeah, so you know each and every day as you're trying to lose weight, you're aware when that day comes to a close if you had a successful day or a less than successful day. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: If you had a successful day, then you could engage in an activity or receive an item that we work out in advance that you know would motivate you. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: And that could be, you know, maybe watching like a favorite TV show. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: You know, because I don't watch TV at night because I'm so busy, you know, cleaning up and everything. ; Patient: Maybe I could just take some time for myself because I did something good. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: You know, and just watch a TV show. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So let's do that. ; Therapist: On a day, you know, toward the evening when you know you have had a successful day, by what time would you know in the evening? ; Patient: Probably as I'm preparing dinner. ; Patient: If I prepare a good dinner or if I prepare fun food for my kids but I don't eat it, like chicken nuggets and french fries and stuff, I would know, you know, maybe by like six or seven. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Let's say seven. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So by seven p.m. ; Therapist: at that point, in terms of the day being successful or less than successful, you know. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: By seven p.m. ; Therapist: you're aware. ; Therapist: And at that point, if you have met your goal, then you have a TV show that you maybe have recorded on the TV or something you would watch. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And if you were not as successful, you would. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So it'd be like something to keep you motivated throughout the day because you really want to watch that show. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: It'd be a lot of fun. ; Therapist: You think that structure, that kind of behavioral strategy would give you enough motivation to have successful days through this process? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I'm not a fan of it, honestly, but it would probably beat the way I feel right now. ; Patient: Anything's kind of better than carrying this, this frustration around. ; Patient: So I'm willing to try anything and I'll try to remember. ; Patient: Like I said, I'll write it down, you know, have it in the kitchen, have it on a note at seven p.m. ; Patient: You know, how did I do today? ; Therapist: Yeah, this is something you could also track, right? ; Therapist: You could write down days that were successful, days that were less than successful, and we could look at if there's any patterns. ; Therapist: Maybe weekends are harder, weekends are easier, you know, or something where we can identify days that have maybe more triggers or where you're less motivated. ; Patient: Yeah, I didn't think about that because, right, every day would be different. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: There's a potential for every day to be different with what you're exposed to and what temptations in terms of different foods or what your schedule is like. ; Therapist: Maybe if you're busier, it's easier. ; Therapist: So we can look at those different patterns and we can add levels to this plan. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But for now, we'll go with the TV show that you'll watch sometime after seven. ; Therapist: So at seven, you'll evaluate how you did, and then sometime after that, watch the show. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: That's like a plan? ; Patient: So that's leading up to the five pounds. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: That's just day by day. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Take this in five pound increments four times to get to your goal of 20 pounds. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Does that sound good? ; Patient: So far so good, yeah. ; Therapist: We'll give that a shot and we'll take a look at the pattern that emerges. ; Therapist: So record everything, right? ; Therapist: So write everything down. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So you'll see around seven is a good time when you know what kind of day you had. ; Therapist: Write down kind of what happened that day and whether you had success or not and bring that in. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I'll see you again in a week. ; Therapist: So that'll give you seven days to work with. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we'll look at that log of events and we'll reevaluate each week. ; Patient: So I could start tonight? ; Therapist: Start tonight. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So we'll give that a shot and I'll see you in a week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Thanks. ; Therapist: Thanks, Kathy.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name kathy; sex female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. dialogue: Therapist: Hello, Mr. Batsby. ; Patient: Hello. ; Therapist: My name's Dr. Vanita Gavies. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And I'm one of the psychiatrists who works here. ; Patient: Right, OK. ; Therapist: OK, can you tell me what's brought you here today? ; Patient: Yeah, well, I was referred to you by my GP. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: And he referred me to you because, erm, well, my wife thinks I'm drinking too much. ; Therapist: Right, I see. ; Therapist: And do you think you're drinking too much? ; Patient: Er, well, I... Yeah, I... Looking at it from her point of view, I suppose I do like a drink, yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Maybe we can just explore that a little bit more. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: How much would you say you drank in a day? ; Patient: Now? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Oh, it's crept up over the years. ; Patient: Erm... ; Patient: Well, I suppose if I'm... If I'm honest, er, yeah, I drink about a bottle of vodka a day. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how long have you been drinking that much for? ; Patient: Well, as I say, it's crept up, erm, er, a few years now. ; Therapist: A few years. ; Therapist: Can you make it a bit more specific? ; Therapist: Two years, three years, five years? ; Patient: Well, I mean, as I say, it's crept up. ; Patient: I mean, initially I just used to have a couple of drinks after work. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Cos I got a pretty responsible job and, erm, I just found a drink calmed me down, you know. ; Patient: And, erm, then I got more responsibility and I found a bit more alcohol helped me, so, yeah. ; Patient: Yes, I'm drinking about a bottle a day now. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you'd say you've had about the last two years, three years? ; Patient: Yeah, about that. ; Therapist: About that, OK. ; Therapist: And do you drink anything else apart from vodka? ; Patient: Yeah, erm, after work I normally go to the pub and, er, I have two to four pints of bitter or lager. ; Therapist: Right, OK. ; Therapist: And would that be every day? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Well, especially, you know, Monday to Friday when I'm working. ; Patient: But at weekends I normally go down the local pub and I have a few at lunchtime. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And how much is a few? ; Patient: OK, only about two to four pints. ; Therapist: Right, ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And then, so, on a weekday, you take about, you have about two to four pints after work and then you come home and drink about a bottle of vodka? ; Patient: Yeah, well, no, well, I don't come home and drink a bottle of vodka. ; Patient: I drink, erm, I drink during the day. ; Therapist: So would you drink throughout... Not when I'm working, mind you. ; Therapist: Not when you're working? ; Patient: Apart from lunchtime. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: Not when I'm at work. ; Therapist: So when do you start drinking during the day? ; Therapist: Erm... ; Therapist: On an average day? ; Patient: Well, after I'm up and dressed and have me breakfast at home. ; Therapist: Right, ; Therapist: so after breakfast. ; Therapist: And again, when did that start? ; Patient: A couple of years ago. ; Therapist: A couple of years ago, OK. ; Therapist: And what about the weekend? ; Therapist: Is it the same at the weekend? ; Patient: Mm. ; Therapist: And would you drink, you go to the pub at lunchtime at the weekend, would you drink more than a bottle of vodka during the day at the weekend? ; Patient: Er, no. ; Therapist: It would be about the same, would it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And are there ever regular times when you drink more than what you've told me? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: There aren't? ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And is it just beer and vodka, would you drink wine? ; Patient: No, I don't. ; Patient: We used to drink wine, my wife used to, when we had an evening meal together, sometimes we had a bottle of red or a bottle of white together, half a bottle. ; Patient: But since she started complaining that she thought I was, you know, really shoving it down my throat, er, she sort of nailed that on the head, so we don't do that any more. ; Therapist: And would you say you have to drink more to get the same effect from the alcohol? ; Patient: Yeah, the same calming effect, yeah. ; Therapist: Same calming effect? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you ever have days where you don't drink, or periods where you don't drink? ; Patient: Mm-hm. ; Therapist: When was the last time you had that? ; Patient: Er, a few months ago now, when she really had had a go at me and I thought to myself, well, maybe I'll give it a try again. ; Patient: It wasn't the first time, but erm... ; Therapist: How long did that last for? ; Patient: Oh, about three days. ; Therapist: Three days. ; Therapist: And in that time, did you experience any, any physical feelings at all? ; Patient: Yes, I did. ; Patient: I mean, I was shaking, I got very shaky, I got... I was on edge all the time, I, I was not working properly and I was sweating. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: And I just felt absolutely lousy. ; Therapist: So you had to take time off work? ; Patient: No, I didn't take time, I couldn't, I didn't dare take time off work. ; Patient: I just said I had a bit of a cold. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Erm, but erm, I thought to myself, well, I can't carry on like this. ; Patient: And so I had a couple of large vodkas. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And that, that made you feel better? ; Patient: And that got me back on the straight and narrow. ; Therapist: Did you ever feel, do you ever get those similar sorts of feelings in the morning when you wake up? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You do? ; Patient: Nowadays, yeah. ; Therapist: And what, what happens when you have the drink in the morning that makes you feel better? ; Patient: Yes, it does. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: If you don't have that drink in the morning, what happens? ; Patient: Well, ; Patient: by the time I get to work, I just feel, again, I feel pretty shaky and very on edge. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: And as I say, I don't touch it when I'm at work because I've got a pretty responsible job. ; Patient: And I don't, as I say, I don't touch it at work. ; Therapist: And you work as a bank manager? ; Patient: I do, yeah. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Has anyone, has anyone commented apart from your wife about your drinking? ; Therapist: Have you ever had any more serious health problems from your drinking? ; Therapist: Have you ever seen the doctor or had, sometimes people get loss of memory or fits, very serious shakes, they need to go into hospital. ; Therapist: Have you ever had anything like that? ; Patient: No, no, no, no, no, no, no, I've touched it with nothing like that. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And have you ever seen, you went to your GP? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Did you do any physical health tests at all? ; Patient: He does some blood tests. ; Therapist: And did that show anything at all? ; Patient: He said the liver wasn't too good. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: And then because of my, you know, my wife threatened to leave me basically. ; Patient: That's what got me to see the GP. ; Patient: And he did some blood tests and he said, your liver's, you know, and he told me I've got to cut it down a bit. ; Therapist: What did he say about? ; Patient: And then he said he was going to refer me to somebody to talk about it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And how did you feel about that? ; Patient: Well, I wasn't exactly over the moon when he suggested it. ; Patient: But, well, I suppose, you know, if it's a choice of coming to see you and then or my wife leaving me, I came to see you. ; Patient: I don't want to lose you. ; Therapist: So I can see that it's had quite an impact at home. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What about outside the home? ; Therapist: How's your drinking affected jobs or anything else? ; Patient: It ; Patient: hasn't affected my job. ; Therapist: What about relationships other than your wife with family, friends? ; Therapist: Well, any other serious consequences? ; Patient: I suppose, yeah, I have to go to family dues and dragged along there. ; Patient: But I mean, I don't. ; Patient: I mean, I avoid mixing with my work colleagues socially. ; Patient: I find that bores me because, you know, if I'm in the pub with them, I've tried it once and I found I needed a drink. ; Patient: And, you know, I thought, well, I'm going to put me foot in it if I carry on like this. ; Patient: And I left early and I just make excuses. ; Patient: I don't socialise with them anymore. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Thanks for coming to talk to me today. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name batsby, sex male ; Referral Information : Referred by gp ; Therapist Information : Dr. Vanita gavies. ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms, alcohol addiction chief complaints 1 fear of losing his wife 20 unable to control the alcohol addiction 3 social withdrawal 4 withdrawal symptoms ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech organized, mood  affect fearful, thought, cognitive functions normal, judgement and insight intact ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in the session 1 alcohol addiction patient has a significant amount of alcohol daily and experience withdrawal symptoms when attempting to cut down or abstain from alcohol. He describes using alcohol to manage stress and anxiety related to his job responsibilities 2 impact on relationships and social functioning patients addiction has impacted his relationship with his wife, who has threatened to leave him. He admits to avoiding socializing with work colleagues and family gatherings. 3 health patient has identified liver abnormalities and advised him to cut down on his alcohol consumption. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety and substance use

dialogue: Therapist: So you mentioned before that when you wake up in the morning, you don't want to go to work. ; Therapist: What's going through your mind? ; Patient: I'm going to have to, you know, hear what my coworkers have to say about what's going on. ; Patient: I might make another mistake. ; Patient: Who knows if I'm going to find out that something terrible happened to these kids when I go back to work. ; Patient: I guess a lot of stuff like that. ; Therapist: So looking at the one, I'm going to make a mistake, this kind of connects to what we were talking about before. ; Therapist: This is the uncertainty. ; Therapist: You're not sure of your own skills. ; Therapist: And you're afraid of an error that's going to be costly. ; Therapist: So when you think that thought, I'm going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: So this is when you're in bed before you start your day. ; Therapist: And you have that thought. ; Therapist: What happens right then? ; Patient: I feel more anxious. ; Patient: You know, I think about like what could happen to somebody else if I make a mistake, like kids going to the wrong home or, you know, not being with their parents when their parents, you know, were not doing anything wrong. ; Patient: And I just feel really like overwhelmed and it gets hard to breathe and I just want to go back to sleep and not have to face anything. ; Therapist: So there's an emotional consequence and then the behavior is you don't want to get out ; Therapist: of bed. ; Patient: I've been late a lot more lately because I have trouble getting out of bed. ; Therapist: And when you're staying in bed, are there more thoughts coming up? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean if I don't go back to sleep, then I have more thoughts like, you know, well, I need to go to work. ; Patient: If I don't go to work, then I'm going to be late. ; Patient: Then people are going to notice me and they're going to be thinking about what happened and thinking there's something wrong with me and that she's not good enough to do her job. ; Patient: You know, I don't want people to know how stressed out I am because then they're going to doubt my abilities just like I do. ; Therapist: So this is really weighing on you and you've identified these thoughts that seem to be connected with feelings that are unpleasant and behaviors that are unpleasant, but also maybe not useful, that are impeding. ; Patient: Yeah, they're keeping me from getting to work and stuff like that. ; Therapist: So we have a reference point for later on as we continue counseling. ; Therapist: I'd like to scale this problem, like maybe I'll scale one to ten, where ten represents feelings that are nearly unbearable, right? ; Therapist: And one not really a problem. ; Therapist: How do you feel on that scale? ; Therapist: Where do you rate yourself right now? ; Patient: Right now in this moment, probably like a five. ; Therapist: That's right around the middle. ; Patient: Yeah, like I'm really stressed out but I'm not, like when I'm in bed, like I can't get out of bed, that kind of thing. ; Therapist: How would you rate yourself when you're in bed before you go to work? ; Patient: Probably like an eight. ; Therapist: Is that as bad as it gets? ; Patient: With this feeling, it's about as bad as it gets, maybe sometimes it gets to a nine. ; Patient: You know, I still feel like I can function but it's really, really difficult. ; Therapist: So an eight, sometimes a nine, and right now five. ; Therapist: So still not feeling great. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And if you had to pick an emotion that was standing out above the rest, in the anxiety, sadness, sense of dread, what would be the worst right now? ; Patient: Right now, probably anxiety. ; Therapist: So a five, on a scale of one to ten, that anxiety should be standing out more.
summary: Past Session Information: Follow -up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety chief complaints 1 doubt 2 fear 3 functional impairment ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech fast, mood  affect dull, thought unclear cognitive functions impaired, judgement poor and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging cognitive restructuring problem solving ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 anxiety patient experiences significant anxiety related to his job and making mistakes. 2 self-doubt feels uncertainty about his own skills and abilities and of being judged by coworkers and supervisors. 3 problem feels stressed, and overwhelmed with sad and negative thought patterns which lead to anxiety and avoidance behaviors like being late for work and difficulty in completing tasks. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Ms. ; Therapist: Watson. ; Patient: Nice to see you again, Dr. Goldblum. ; Therapist: I'm glad you came back in. ; Therapist: I've got the results now of the blood work that we did after your checkup. ; Therapist: Before we go over any of that, I really wanted to find out from you how things are going and what you're concerned about. ; Patient: Well, I'm curious about them because I haven't been very well, right? ; Patient: I haven't been feeling very well. ; Patient: Last week I threw up some blood. ; Therapist: Is that the first time that's happened? ; Patient: Yeah, the first time. ; Patient: I threw up blood last week and then again yesterday. ; Patient: There's something bad going on. ; Patient: I know there's something bad going on. ; Therapist: What do you think is going on? ; Patient: Well, cancer, right? ; Patient: I think I probably have cancer. ; Patient: I'm not doing very well. ; Patient: I'm just not doing very well. ; Therapist: Look, let's try to figure some of this out, okay? ; Therapist: When you said you were throwing up blood, were you throwing up bright red blood? ; Therapist: Was it little spots, big spots? ; Patient: It was almost filling the toilet. ; Patient: It wasn't that much. ; Patient: It was enough that I could see it in the toilet when I was throwing up. ; Therapist: Did you have any other symptoms? ; Patient: Well, I was feeling sick and I had headaches. ; Therapist: What time of day was this? ; Patient: I have headaches a lot throughout the day. ; Therapist: But the throwing up the blood? ; Patient: That was in the morning and then again the other time it was sort of later in the day. ; Patient: I also wake up in the middle of the night and I'm just covered in sweat. ; Patient: I know that's another cancer thing. ; Therapist: Well, look, I can understand why you're worried, all right? ; Therapist: Because throwing up blood is scary and waking up soaked in sweat in the middle of the night, that doesn't feel right either. ; Therapist: Let me ask you a couple of questions that might help explain things. ; Therapist: When did you have your last drink? ; Patient: Actually, just before I came here. ; Therapist: Okay, so that was earlier this morning. ; Therapist: What did you have? ; Patient: I had orange juice and I had some vodka in it. ; Patient: It's the only thing actually that like steadies me enough to get out the door. ; Patient: I don't go out that often, but you know. ; Therapist: So tell me how it helps you. ; Patient: It just steadies me. ; Patient: It steadies me. ; Patient: Like I'm, you know, I'm shaking all the time. ; Patient: I'm just like. ; Therapist: So over the course of a day, in order to steady yourself, in order to feel calmer, how many drinks do you end up having? ; Patient: Five? ; Patient: Maybe. ; Therapist: Singles or doubles? ; Patient: I don't measure. ; Patient: I think so. ; Therapist: Is it mainly vodka? ; Patient: Sometimes if I'm feeling really like my stomach is really upset, I'll drink cider. ; Patient: So that's cider or vodka. ; Therapist: And do you ever get that feeling in the morning that some people describe that they wake up feeling so edgy they need a drink to calm down? ; Patient: It's like the only thing that works for me. ; Patient: It's the only thing that works to. ; Therapist: So in the past week, do you think you've been drinking more? ; Patient: In the last week? ; Patient: Not so much. ; Patient: Maybe the last couple of weeks, maybe. ; Therapist: Has it been daily? ; Patient: Oh, yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So the longest you've gone without a drink in the last month would be how long? ; Patient: I don't know, actually. ; Patient: I mean, I don't know. ; Patient: I've got, you know, I've got a lot going on, right? ; Patient: So my sister is in Boston. ; Patient: She's got cancer. ; Patient: And I know, like, I should be calling her, and I can't do that. ; Patient: My mom is really sick, and she's horrible. ; Patient: And I'm the only one who can go see her. ; Patient: And I go see my mother, and she just yells and screams at me. ; Patient: And she's got emphysema. ; Patient: And it's just... ; Therapist: And so for all of those things, the alcohol helps? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And does it ever happen, sort of by the end of the day, that you have trouble the next day remembering what happened? ; Patient: I guess. ; Patient: I mean, you know, my days don't differ that much. ; Patient: But I, you know, I'll fall asleep in front of the television, and then... ; Patient: I'm not seeing lots of people. ; Patient: So I, you know, there's not big events in my life that I would be remembering. ; Patient: I just, you know, and especially now that I'm feeling so not well, that I... ; Patient: Yeah, there's not much that I would have to remember. ; Therapist: Have you tried at all to cut down on your drinking? ; Patient: I did. ; Patient: You know, I had a boyfriend who, you know, was sort of casual coming over. ; Patient: And he basically said he couldn't be with me anymore because I drank too much. ; Patient: And so I tried. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I tried. ; Therapist: It's hard. ; Patient: Well, yeah. ; Patient: And then he laughed. ; Patient: So who cares, right? ; Patient: I mean... ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Who cares? ; Therapist: But have you found yourself feeling guilty about the alcohol? ; Patient: I feel guilty about my sister. ; Patient: I feel guilty that I can't, like I just can't, I can't even call her. ; Patient: Like I can't, right? ; Patient: So if I could pull it together, then I could... ; Therapist: Because what I understand from what you're telling me is that the drinking helps meet a certain need for you in terms of trying to hold things together with all this stuff going on. ; Therapist: And it meets a need in terms of trying to keep you calmer. ; Therapist: But at the same time, it's getting you into trouble. ; Therapist: It's getting into trouble in terms of relationships. ; Therapist: But it's also the most likely explanation for why you've been throwing up blood. ; Patient: Is it? ; Therapist: Why the lab results that I've got are consistent with an amount of alcohol that's too much for your body to handle. ; Patient: Really? ; Therapist: Really. ; Patient: And that means, ideally, that we're going to work together to find a way to do something about it.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name ms watson; sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name dr goldblum ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Trembling in body 2. Vomiting blood 3. Difficulty controlling alcohol consumption 4. Recurrent headaches ; History: Present history patient has been consuming alcohol and now finds it difficult to control or reduce this consumption. She feels guilty about not being able to call her sister or visit her mother to take care of her; family history patient has a sister who lives in boston and has been diagnosed with cancer. Her mother is diagnosed with emphysema. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cordial and rapport could be established; mood dysphoric; affect restricted ; Psychotherapy Type: Type pct; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient expressed her difficulty controlling alcohol consumption leading to further disturbances in social life and taking care of the family. She was concerned of having cancer as she has been throwing up blood and having recurrent headaches. Her blood test reports revealed that her body is unable to handle her current alcohol consumption. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: How many times have you gone to work and made a mistake? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, I guess none technically, none that have been something I've gotten trouble for or anything like that. ; Patient: Sometimes it's hard to tell because you don't always hear from people afterwards. ; Patient: You can't really tell was it a mistake or not, but I guess none that have had any major consequences. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So none, but there might be a few small ones that you just never found out about. ; Therapist: So less than a tenth of a percent of the days you go in? ; Patient: Probably. ; Therapist: Very small. ; Patient: Yeah, really, really small. ; Therapist: So the probability of the statement that you're making being true is pretty low. ; Therapist: The statement, the thought rather, that I'm going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: Probably not supported by the evidence. ; Patient: Yeah, I guess that's true. ; Therapist: So the automatic thought is not accurate and not useful. ; Therapist: It's got a couple of strikes against it, but it is the thought you're having, so let's deal with it. ; Therapist: I'm going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: So what could you tell yourself as the first part of the adaptive response, which acknowledges that fear? ; Therapist: That's realistic, that acknowledges that fear of making a mistake. ; Patient: I guess everybody makes mistakes? ; Therapist: Everybody makes mistakes. ; Therapist: I could make a mistake today, but it's unlikely? ; Therapist: That also be accurate? ; Therapist: So everybody makes mistakes. ; Therapist: I could make a mistake, but it's probably not going to happen. ; Therapist: It's not that I'm going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: So you're going to have that automatic thought either way, likely for a while, until you start to apply these adaptive responses. ; Therapist: So this is what we're working on, is your response. ; Therapist: So everybody makes mistakes, I could make a mistake, but it's probably not going to happen. ; Therapist: And what could be the next part, which is realistic but also positive, that can help get you past the reaction of being late in the morning? ; Patient: I'm a good case worker and I need to do my job so I can help other people and it's going to be okay. ; Therapist: Okay, so there's a few elements in there. ; Therapist: It's going to be okay, I need to do my job, I help people, all those are true. ; Therapist: So applying, now even as you say this here with me, as you say it's going to be okay and I need to do my job. ; Therapist: What reaction are you having right now? ; Patient: I mean it feels a little better, it's hard to, you know, I still feel like it's dangerous, I might make a mistake, but I guess it helps a little bit. ; Therapist: Can you see yourself being able to, in the moment, and I realize this is difficult, but in the moment of having that automatic thought, having that worry come in, can you see yourself applying this self-talk? ; Patient: Yeah, I think I probably will because now it will be hard to have those thoughts and not think of you and think, okay, I need to calm myself down a little bit because we've been talking about it for so long. ; Therapist: And you've already used self-talk on your own before you even knew about these strategies. ; Patient: Yep, that's true. ; Patient: And it did help in the past. ; Therapist: A lot of the, or I should say some of the effectiveness of this is based on your ability in that moment to take a step back and follow the training. ; Therapist: Just like many professionals, professionals depend on their training to help them make the correct intervention, correct decision. ; Therapist: So think of this kind of like something you've learned in a training. ; Therapist: This is a self-talk, it's pre-packaged, it's ready to go. ; Therapist: You can even have it written down. ; Therapist: It doesn't have to be short, it can be like a paragraph or more if you wanted. ; Therapist: And it's a matter of following the protocol. ; Therapist: So you have the automatic thought, it's easy to descend into worry and fear. ; Therapist: You're just looking to grab a moment in there and apply this treatment, this strategy. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Therapist: Sometimes it's likely, well most of the time I think you would be able to do this, sometimes you probably won't. ; Therapist: And it's important in those moments to not get discouraged. ; Therapist: So you can have a self-talk for that too. ; Therapist: And like Dr. Groundy said, it was likely that once in a while I wouldn't be able to do this. ; Patient: Yeah, it's not going to work every time. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yeah, that makes a lot of sense. ; Therapist: So it's the chaos of life, right, and the chaos of emotions that sometimes interfere. ; Therapist: The more times you have success, that seems to be tied with a better chance of improving and reduction of symptoms. ; Therapist: But allow yourself failures as well. ; Therapist: It's what I would expect from anybody trying to untangle all these feelings and thoughts. ; Therapist: There's not going to be a perfect connection between an automatic thought and applied self-talk. ; Therapist: So be easy on yourself as you try this. ; Patient: That makes sense because if you could just flip a switch, I would only have to have one therapy session. ; Therapist: It would be in good shape. ; Therapist: So it's a little more difficult than that. ; Therapist: But overall, these strategies are fairly straightforward, and you can definitely learn them, and you can definitely do them. ; Therapist: I want you to have that confidence. ; Therapist: It's normal to have mistakes occur, and to not always do it as you need to, or as you want to. ; Therapist: But in the end, overall, you should be able to apply them, and actually it will get easier in the future to develop your self-talk for different thoughts.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name dr grande ; Past Session Information: Nil ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Excessive worry about making a mistake ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; thought content- preoccupation with thoughts of making a mistake at work; mood anxious; affect constricted; insight grade 4 ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Validity testing, cognitive restructuring ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient disused their apprehension about making a mistake. Cbt techniques were used to make them understand things better and deal with the issues effectively. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Tiffany, how you doing today? ; Patient: I'm alright. ; Therapist: You alright? ; Patient: I'm alright. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some recent difficulties. ; Patient: The thing with the cops. ; Therapist: You had some involvement with the police? ; Patient: I was so blown out of proportion. ; Patient: Stupid neighbours were having a party. ; Patient: And I'm trying to be asleep. ; Patient: It's like 10-11, you know, I'm trying to wind down. They're having a party. ; Patient: I go over there, yell at the door. Yell through the door, yo, I'm trying to be asleep, bring it down some. ; Patient: No response. ; Patient: So, I let myself in, with a little force, but I let myself in. ; Patient: They're all up. ; Patient: I just confront who's ever there. ; Patient: Who's having this party? ; Patient: Everybody's just like, everybody's ignoring me. ; Patient: So, I just go over, take the stereo, open the window, throw it out the window. ; Patient: Then, there may have been people walking by. ; Patient: This woman swear she was walking by. ; Patient: Says, I almost, said, I almost hit her. ; Patient: But to me, she called the cops. ; Therapist: So, what story were you on? ; Patient: Maybe third floor. ; Therapist: Third floor. ; Therapist: So, you threw the stereo out the window and it landed on the ground? ; Patient: It did not. ; Patient: It was nowhere near that woman. ; Patient: She was way across the street, but she says, I almost hit her. ; Patient: So, whatever. ; Therapist: So, she called the? ; Patient: She called the police. ; Patient: Said, I was out of control. ; Patient: And then, the people from the party had a nerve to go down when the cops got there. ; Patient: And they agreed with her. ; Patient: They said, I came, they said, I broke him, but I just came in. ; Patient: But anyway, they said, I threw the stereo out. ; Patient: And then, the police are threatening to put me in jail and they're threatening to press charges. ; Patient: And now, it's just ugly, but it's blown out of proportion. ; Therapist: You feel it's blown out of proportion? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Has anything like this happened before? ; Patient: Not with the police or anything. ; Therapist: How about anything where you found your anger kind of strong? ; Patient: Well, maybe. ; Patient: There was the time it was my daughter. ; Patient: She's 16 years old. ; Patient: You know how teenagers are? ; Patient: They don't listen. ; Patient: She wasn't listening. ; Patient: She has a smart phone, brand new smart phone she got for Christmas. ; Patient: You know, out of my money from my pocket. ; Patient: Brand new smart phone, got for Christmas. ; Patient: I'm up here. ; Patient: Hello, it's time for your homework. ; Patient: Did you do your homework? ; Patient: She's just gabbing on the phone. ; Patient: Not listening. ; Patient: I took the phone, threw it out the window. ; Patient: Broke, shattered. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: But, psh. ; Therapist: And how long ago was this with the phone? ; Patient: Four or five months ago. ; Therapist: Four or five months. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So do you find that you're angry often? ; Patient: I wouldn't say I'm angry often. ; Patient: I just think is if people did what I wanted them to do, what I wanted them to do it, I wouldn't be so upset as much. ; Therapist: So you find yourself upset on occasion? ; Patient: On occasion, but again, it's just if people would listen. ; Patient: Like, I don't know if it was last year or the year before, I don't know when it was. ; Patient: Like, it was one of those Thanksgivings and just my whole family's around, you know, Thanksgiving, watching football. ; Patient: I'm cooking dinner, you know, busy all in the kitchen. ; Patient: Everything's hot and whatnot. ; Patient: I've got this whole gourmet meal made. ; Patient: My brother's there, his family's there, you know, my husband's family's there, everybody's there. ; Patient: Everybody, it's time to eat. ; Patient: Everybody, it's time to eat. ; Patient: They think this football game is more interesting than my food. ; Patient: I spent all day making this. ; Patient: So it's like, you know, just went, took the TV, thought about throwing it at my brother. ; Patient: He's 45 years old. ; Patient: He should be listening, you know. ; Patient: But just threw it on the ground, smashed it. ; Patient: Now you will listen. ; Patient: I stood there, screamed for a little bit, got it all out. ; Patient: I felt so good to get it out. ; Patient: I stood there, screamed, they're all staring, but they ate. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you planned to throw the TV or just something came up in the moment? ; Patient: It just happened. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm not planning or anything, but I just want them to eat, you know. ; Therapist: It was more of a spur of the moment thing. ; Patient: A spur of the moment, completely a spur of the moment. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: But it got their attention. ; Patient: They ate. ; Therapist: It got their attention, the TV, it had been broken. ; Therapist: So? ; Therapist: All right, so this has, your anger and some of your behaviors caused some recent trouble with the law. ; Therapist: That's why you're here. ; Patient: Everything, like I said, is blown out of proportion. ; Patient: There's no need for police, no need for the courts or anything. ; Patient: It's like... ; Therapist: But now they're involved and you feel like counseling might be helpful. ; Patient: If I want to keep my job, yes. ; Patient: I can't go to jail. ; Patient: I'm like, I can't face any charges. ; Patient: I can't do that. ; Patient: So counseling would be helpful in that regard. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: But I don't see it as a problem. ; Therapist: You don't see the anger as a problem? ; Patient: Uh-huh. ; Patient: I don't see what everybody's talking about. ; Patient: My husband says I have these anger issues. ; Patient: My kids say I throw a tantrum like a two-year-old. ; Patient: But I don't see, I don't see it. ; Therapist: You're just not seeing it? ; Patient: I don't see it. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you have any history of medical problems, mental health problems? ; Patient: Nuh-uh. ; Therapist: You ever use drugs or alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: Clean as a whistle. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it seems like you are open to the idea of counseling. ; Therapist: I'd like to get you scheduled with one of our counselors. ; Therapist: I'll get you in a couple days if that works. ; Patient: That'll work. ; Patient: It's gonna have to work. ; Therapist: I appreciate you answering these questions. ; Therapist: This has been helpful, and I'll get you set up with the counselor. ; Patient: All right.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name tiffany, sex female, marital status married ; Past Session Information: Intake ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anger issues chief complaints impulsivity ; Current Mental Status Examination: Mood  affect agitated, perception denial, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient has recurrent episodes of anger, leading to destructive behavior, such as throwing a stereo, a smartphone, and a tv, conflicts with her teenage daughter and extended family. 2 defense mechanism despite the destructive episodes, patient does not acknowledge having anger management problems and sees her reactions as justified. 3 motivation patient seeks counseling to avoid legal consequences and maintain employment rather than a recognition of personal issues. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anger outburst ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor ; Next session details: In couple of days

dialogue: Therapist: Do you have on your presentation, do you have so many bullet points you want to cover? ; Patient: Yeah, like an outline sort of thing. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Would it help to time the deep breathing with reviewing each one of those bullet points? ; Patient: I never thought about that. ; Therapist: I don't know how many bullet points you'd have in a presentation. ; Therapist: Maybe you'd have 10 or 20? ; Patient: Something like that, yeah. ; Therapist: Depending on how long it is. ; Therapist: So maybe you, as you start to review a certain bullet point, as you're trying to get it into your memory and think about it, you breathe in really deeply and then as you continue on you just let out that breath really slowly. ; Patient: Like a rhythm sort of. ; Therapist: Yeah, I could do that. ; Therapist: And then you go to the next bullet point and do the same thing. ; Patient: Never thought about it that way. ; Therapist: I'm just thinking it'd be some way to structure so you would get in so many breaths. ; Patient: So I wouldn't forget, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, something that kind of becomes a habit. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Just make sure you keep your bullet points at a length that would work. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Not a few paragraphs. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: But just a few seconds each so you can get a good deep breath. ; Therapist: Or you could, if you did have a longer bullet point, you could have obviously several breaths. ; Therapist: But just some rhythm that you could kind of grab onto something concrete. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because I know that in that moment things are probably, like you mentioned, zoning out. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: It becomes very easy to lose your anchors. ; Patient: Yeah, exactly. ; Patient: And just get really foggy, almost dizzy. ; Therapist: Yeah, so if you can remember, you know, for a particular bullet point that you want to take three deep breaths, that might be something you can really grab onto. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And would kind of cut through that fogginess of something you could still do. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: When's the next presentation in that class that's coming up? ; Patient: The next one I believe is next Friday. ; Therapist: Is that the next presentation you have in all the classes? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And that's next Friday. ; Therapist: Do you know where you are in the order, like for presenting? ; Patient: I think I'm actually third in this one. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: So not first. ; Therapist: Not first. ; Therapist: And this one's how many minutes? ; Patient: Like 15 or so. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: It's a little shorter than 20 minutes. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So 15 minutes, so you have about a half hour, maybe a little more if there's time to switch out of kind of sitting there. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And potential time where you could be anxious. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: But also potential time when you could be reviewing, denotes your bullet points, and breathing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And saying to yourself that kind of self-talk that they're not really paying attention to me anyway. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Because that might help reduce that anxiety. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What's one thing you could say to yourself when you're up there? ; Patient: I guess I could say that in general I do pretty well. ; Patient: One bad grade I think going to make me doesn't mean that I don't deserve to be here. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So the self-talk up there could be I deserve to be here. ; Patient: Maybe I've prepared enough. ; Patient: You know that I know that I've prepared and I'm a good student. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I've prepared enough. ; Therapist: I'm a good student. ; Therapist: I do deserve to be here. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Is that something it would be helpful to write down and have as part of your notes that you can... ; Patient: Yeah, I think it would actually. ; Therapist: You can recite that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Internally as you... ; Patient: Because it's not long, I think I could. ; Patient: It would be easy to remember and I could just like maybe put it down on one of my note cards in front of me or something. ; Therapist: And how much do you believe that those statements are true? ; Patient: I think, you know, sitting here now I believe them. ; Patient: In the moment sometimes it's a little hard to believe because I convince myself otherwise. ; Patient: But I think I actually believe that that's true, that I do deserve to be in the program. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Those self-talk items, you believe them to be true. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But you recognize in the moment, and I want you to be aware of this, you might not believe them as much. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But remember that, you know, we worked on them. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: You came up with them. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you believe them now. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So try to keep that in your mind as you start to doubt yourself. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you're ready to recite them. ; Therapist: It's easy, I realize it's easy to form these plans. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But in the chaos of the anxiety and the worry it's harder. ; Therapist: So the more tasks you can make concrete and that you can write down and you can rehearse, I think the better off you'll be. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I would like to see you, your presentations next Friday. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I would like to see you right before that, so it will be about a week before that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you have any questions? ; Therapist: These are items you can rehearse still, even without the presentation, the self-talk and ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: the breathing and of course preparing. ; Therapist: But do you have any questions between now and then, do you think? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Patient: I think it makes sense. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you understand kind of the plan to Yeah. ; Therapist: attack that anxiety symptom? ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I think what you kind of suggested before, like maybe practicing my deep breathing, like maybe now, like when I'm calm and getting into a habit of deep breathing, like I'm more apt to also remember it then. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So, good. ; Therapist: So you have some kind of behavioral pieces. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: The focus on studying, the breathing and some cognitive pieces, the self-talk we talked about. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: The seated and that you use when you're at the podium. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And actually presenting. ; Therapist: All right, good. ; Therapist: So I'm glad we have a plan going forward. ; Therapist: I think that you did a really good job today helping kind of untangle all this and figure out what's going on. ; Therapist: And I appreciate that you were able to really connect with the symptoms and the thoughts and kind of realize how they're related. ; Therapist: And I feel like this is something that's going to serve you well as you move through this. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: So I'll see you in a week. ; Patient: Okay, thanks. ; Therapist: Thanks, Hazel.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Sandra. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm okay, I guess. ; Therapist: Just okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you some questions and give you some problems to solve. ; Therapist: Please try to answer them as best as you can. ; Therapist: What year is this? ; Patient: 2014 ; Therapist: 2014? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What season of the year is this? ; Patient: Summertime. ; Therapist: Summertime? ; Therapist: What is the date today? ; Patient: May 10th. ; Therapist: May 10th? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What is the day of the week? ; Patient: Thursday. ; Therapist: What month is this? ; Patient: May. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what country we're in? ; Patient: Delaware. ; Therapist: What county are we in? ; Patient: Delaware. ; Therapist: What is the name or the address of this building? ; Patient: Say that again. ; Therapist: What floor of the building are we on? ; Patient: Bottom one. ; Therapist: Bottom floor? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I am going to name three objects. ; Therapist: After I've said them, I want you to repeat them back to me. ; Therapist: Apple, table, penny. ; Therapist: Can you repeat them back to me? ; Patient: Penny. ; Therapist: Let me go again. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Apple, table, penny. ; Patient: Apple, table, apple. ; Therapist: Let me try again. ; Therapist: Apple, table, penny. ; Patient: Apple, table, penny. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Remember what they are because I'm going to ask you to name them again in a few minutes. ; Therapist: Now I'm going to give you a word and ask you to spell it forward and backward. ; Therapist: The word is world. ; Therapist: First, can you spell it forward? ; Patient: Can you say it again? ; Therapist: The word is world. ; Patient: W-U-R-A-D. ; Therapist: Now, can you spell it backward? ; Patient: What was the word again? ; Therapist: The word is world. ; Patient: D-R-W. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What were the three objects I asked you to remember? ; Patient: Table, world. ; Therapist: What is this called? ; Patient: Bracelet. ; Therapist: Bracelet. ; Therapist: What is this called? ; Patient: Marker. ; Therapist: I would like you to repeat a phrase after me. ; Therapist: The phrase is no ifs, ands, or buts. ; Patient: No ifs, ands, or buts. ; Therapist: Read the words on this page and do what it says. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: Are you right-handed or left-handed? ; Therapist: Left-handed. ; Therapist: You're left-handed? ; Therapist: Take this paper in your left hand, fold the paper once with both hands, and put the paper down on your lap. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can you pick up the notebook beside you? ; Therapist: Can you write any complete sentence on that piece of paper for me? ; Therapist: Can I see the sentence? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Hang on to the pen there. ; Therapist: Here's a drawing. ; Therapist: Please copy this drawing on that same piece of paper. ; Patient: Copy it? ; Therapist: Copy it on the same piece of paper. ; Patient: On this one? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Can I start over? ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: Can I take a look at it? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: That concludes this assessment. ; Therapist: Sandra, I want to thank you for your participation. ; Patient: Thank you.

dialogue: Therapist: Okay, so I wrote a prescription for an antibiotic for Aiden that should help with the ear infection, but in looking through the chart, I mean, it seems like he's had six or seven of these just in the past year or so. ; Therapist: That's really a big problem. ; Patient: Yeah, it's pretty stressful for both of us. ; Patient: I think it's really upset. ; Therapist: Well, one of the primary risk factors for multiple ear infections in kids is actually smoke exposure. ; Therapist: Are you smoking? ; Patient: Yeah, I do smoke, but I don't smoke around him. ; Patient: I try really hard not to smoke around him. ; Therapist: Well, the fact that he's having these ear infections is indicating to me that he is being exposed to smoke, and so what can you tell me about that? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, I try really hard not to smoke around him. ; Patient: I don't smoke in the car. ; Patient: When he's home, I go outside to smoke. ; Patient: I mean, I know it's bad, and I know it's bad for him, so I don't want him to be around him, so I try really hard. ; Therapist: I really need you to quit smoking, both for your health and for Aiden. ; Therapist: Did you know smoking around your child is associated not only with ear infections, it could get to the point where you have to put tubes in his ears pretty shortly here, but also things like vitamin C deficiency, cavities, like dental cavities, behavior problems, asthma, other upper respiratory infections. ; Therapist: It's really putting him at a lot of risk. ; Therapist: In addition to that, kids of smokers end up smoking themselves. ; Therapist: Do you want him to grow up to be a smoker? ; Patient: No, but I don't smoke. ; Patient: I've thought about quitting, but it's really hard, so I just don't know how to do it. ; Therapist: Well, now's the time to quit. ; Therapist: It's really gotten to the point where you can't keep smoking, not only for him, like I said, but also for you. ; Therapist: You're putting yourself at risk for lung cancer, for emphysema, for oral cancers, for heart disease, for all kinds of things. ; Patient: I know, I know. ; Patient: I've heard. ; Patient: People have told me before, I've heard all that. ; Patient: I just don't know how to do it. ; Patient: How am I supposed to quit? ; Patient: It's so hard. ; Therapist: Well, there's all kinds of things you can use now. ; Therapist: It's not as hard as it used to be. ; Therapist: You can use nicotine replacement. ; Therapist: There's patches, there's lozenges, there's gum, there's the inhaler, there's nasal spray. ; Therapist: We can talk about medications. ; Therapist: You can try Chantix. ; Therapist: You can try Zyban. ; Therapist: There's quit smoking groups you can go to. ; Therapist: There's hotlines you can call. ; Patient: I just don't have time for any of that. ; Therapist: There's no reason why you shouldn't be able to quit. ; Therapist: This is really important. ; Patient: I understand that. ; Patient: I know it is. ; Patient: I mean, everybody has problems, right? ; Patient: It's just really, it's really, really hard. ; Therapist: Well, what can be more important to you than the health of your child? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: I really need you to tell me that you're going to quit smoking. ; Therapist: This is really important. ; Patient: I'll go look at all those things and I'll find, I guess I'll try to find something and I'll talk to my doctor about it. ; Therapist: Okay, well I think you really need to think about this seriously. ; Therapist: Like I said, it's really putting yourself and your child in danger. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Whatever. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay.
