dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: Was the feeling itself the worry about not being prepared interfere with preparing? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: It's really hard. ; Patient: So like when I'm in the middle of being worried, it's really hard for me to focus. ; Patient: So I can't focus on like what I need to do because I feel like my mind is on a lot of different things and I can't focus on exactly what I should be doing. ; Patient: It's just like I'm worried about all the different aspects. ; Therapist: Alright, so your ability to concentrate through the hard work of preparing. ; Patient: Yeah, to like focus my energy on the right things. ; Patient: I'm just like wasting time worrying. ; Therapist: Alright, so this excessive worrying and all this interfering of preparing, all this goes on right up until you're getting ready to present? ; Patient: Yeah, and then like while I'm presenting. ; Therapist: So let's talk about that. ; Therapist: Let's go into the actual day of presenting. ; Therapist: So we have this excessive worry coming in. ; Therapist: It's interfering with your ability to prepare. ; Therapist: It's distressing for you. ; Therapist: Now it's what in class, these presentations are in class. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you're in the classroom. ; Therapist: Do you, are you the only one to present during that class or does it rotate through several people? ; Patient: It depends on the presentation. ; Patient: Sometimes there's like one or two other people that have to present that night depending on like how long the topic is. ; Therapist: Alright, well let's use the last time you present in that class as a tempo. ; Therapist: What was the order? ; Therapist: Like what order did you go in there? ; Patient: The one, well the one that I really messed up I think I was first, but usually like I'm like second maybe. ; Therapist: Okay, so for this example let's say you're the second. ; Therapist: So you're sitting in the classroom and another student is presenting. ; Therapist: What's going through your mind then? ; Patient: I feel like I am totally zoned out. ; Patient: Like I'm not even paying attention to what that person is saying because I'm so worried about how I'm going to mess it up. ; Patient: You know, I'm starting to like be sweaty, like my hands are clammy, my heart's starting to race a little bit and I'm just totally zoned out on what they're doing. ; Patient: I'm just you know worrying about what's going to happen when I get up there. ; Therapist: Alright, so in that moment as you're seated you're not really watching their presentation as much because you have these strong, or somewhat strong physical symptoms. ; Therapist: You have your heart racing a bit you said, sweaty palms, you're zoned out. ; Therapist: Have you ever felt the need, desire to like run out of the room? ; Patient: Yes, it's funny you should say that. ; Patient: I was a little bit hesitant to mention that but I kind of, I do, I feel like I need to find an excuse to like use the bathroom or I just need to get out of there. ; Therapist: Yeah, so what do you feel is most pressuring you to leave the room? ; Therapist: Like what symptom? ; Patient: I would say that just like my anxiety and my heart rate are starting to increase and I feel like I just need to get out of there. ; Therapist: What thoughts going through your mind right then? ; Therapist: Like so let's take that kind of most severe moment when you're, let's just say we're still before the presentation. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So you're sitting at the desk and your heart rate's elevated and you're not focusing on what they're doing, you're zoned out, your anxiety is high. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What thought is going through your mind right then? ; Patient: I think I'm thinking like I'm going to bond this anyway so I might as well just you know not go through the stress of having to do it. ; Patient: Like I've already in my head I know that it's going to end badly. ; Therapist: So I've already, I've already failed? ; Patient: Right, so there's no sense in getting up there and maybe if I don't get up there you know, I guess it couldn't be any worse so I might as well just leave. ; Therapist: Are you embarrassed that the professor or other students will see that you were really anxious? ; Patient: Yeah, I don't want, I figure if I leave then people will just maybe think I was sick or whatever and it'll be a better situation if I just left than having to see me up there you know sweating and all this, these other symptoms that I have when I actually get up there. ; Patient: It would be better just to leave before that starts. ; Therapist: Okay, so better to be thought ill that you just had to leave because you're sick. ; Patient: Yeah, or have them wonder what happened then to just be up in front of everybody you know. ; Therapist: Have a severe anxiety in front of everybody and then they can see. ; Patient: Very embarrassing. ; Therapist: Yeah, that would be, that would be a very undesirable outcome for you. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So as you're debating that thought, like if that's coming to your head and you're thinking I just need to flee. ; Patient: Yeah, I just got to get out here. ; Therapist: What happens there? ; Therapist: So we're maybe, what maybe 15 minutes before you present? ; Therapist: So tell me about that. ; Therapist: So you have that thought, you want to flee. ; Patient: Right and I'm looking at the clock and saying you know like how much more time in this presentation before I have to go, like should I go, should I not go, what are the consequences of running out you know and kind of playing out which would be worse. ; Therapist: Have you ever had to run out? ; Patient: Once I went to the bathroom to try to like calm myself down or talk to myself or you know like cool off my face. ; Patient: But I came back. ; Therapist: And you presented. ; Patient: Yeah and then I presented. ; Therapist: Alright so you, you survived one of the more stressful. ; Patient: Yeah, I almost felt like I was going to be ill. ; Patient: I was so stressed that day. ; Therapist: That was very, very tough on you. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: That particular day. ; Therapist: You did survive it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, it was just very unpleasant. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So now we're, now we're right about to where it's time to get up and present. ; Therapist: Right, so let's say in this scenario, if you haven't fled but you had those thoughts. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you're anxious and you have some physical symptoms going on. ; Therapist: You get up and it's time to present. ; Therapist: What's the sequence from this point on? ; Patient: So typically like I go to load my presentation. ; Patient: At this point like I have my new cards or whatever in front of me. ; Patient: I am like shaking at this point. ; Patient: I am so, I don't know if it's scared or worried or maybe a combination of everything and I'm just like sweating. ; Patient: My heart is racing. ; Patient: Like I almost feel dizzy. ; Patient: I'm just so stressed out about what's going to happen and then you know I'm starting to speak and then the presentations are usually like 20 minutes or so. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: So I have to stay up there for the duration and I'm just like you know sweating and then I'm wondering like are people looking at me or people, can people see it? ; Patient: You know am I going to forget something? ; Therapist: So the, so the thoughts are I wonder if they can see how anxious I am. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: I wonder if I'm going to do poorly on the presentation. ; Patient: Right or they think I've been lazy and I didn't prepare or are they going to think that you know I'm dumb or I don't know you know what I'm doing? ; Patient: What are they going to think about me? ; Therapist: So they might, they might think less of you as a person. ; Patient: Right or like be judging me. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So there's a number of concerns that kind of go into your mind in that moment. ; Therapist: So when does it start to turn around? ; Therapist: So you start presenting, it's 20 minutes. ; Therapist: You initially get up there and get your presentation up on the, like the projection monitor, something like that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: When does it start to turn the corner? ; Patient: It depends. ; Patient: Sometimes I settle down a little bit but then usually like that, I get some sort of rhythm I think and then, but then I get anxiety again until I get my grades. ; Patient: Do you know what I mean? ; Patient: And I'm like until, cause I feel like I'm going to do poorly until that happens. ; Therapist: When do you receive the grades? ; Patient: Sometimes like she usually doesn't give them that day, but like often like the next day or the day after. ; Therapist: So does that intense anxiety that you're having while you're presenting last all the way to now? ; Patient: No, it's definitely like dissipates once I can like go sit down. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, so the, so the next big drop off for symptoms would be when you're done the presentation. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: When eyes are maybe no longer on me, they've moved on to somebody else. ; Patient: So I figure like, okay, they forgot about me. ; Patient: I'm safe for right then. ; Therapist: But then there's this other worry of now we have to see what the grades are going to be. ; Patient: And I convince myself that I did poorly. ; Therapist: So the thought that's going through your mind is I'm going to receive a bad grade. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And that everyone saw me, you know, sweating and all these symptoms that I have, everyone is judging me.
summary: Therapist Information : Name grande ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety and fear chief complaints 1 embarrassment 2 preoccupation with thoughts of potential failure 3 fear of judgement 4 negative self-talk ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior cooperative, mood  affect anxious, thought negative, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Dynamic supportive analytical ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive thought challenging cognitive restructuring ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Problem patient worries about not being prepared and struggles to focus due to their mind being preoccupied with various aspects of the presentation like fear of judgement. Feels anxiety which manifests physically through symptoms like a racing heart, sweaty palms, clammy hands, and dizziness. He feels zoned out, desires to escape, and fears to be perceived as unprepared, lazy, unintelligent, or incompetent. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: How you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing all right. ; Therapist: Doing all right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm feeling a little bit better. ; Therapist: Feeling a little better? ; Therapist: I know you've been down for a while. ; Therapist: What's going on? ; Patient: I just feel like everything's going to be okay. ; Therapist: This is unusual for you because usually you come and talk to me, cut down, depressed. ; Therapist: Something changed recently? ; Patient: I just feel like I've found the solution and I know what I'm going to do. ; Patient: I'm not really worried about my depression so I guess I'm feeling a little bit better about it. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about the solution you found for depression? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I know we've talked about it before. ; Patient: I think that I'm going to commit suicide. ; Therapist: You want to commit suicide? ; Therapist: Do you know how you did that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I have some pills in my house in the medicine cabinet and I'm going to take those. ; Therapist: When do you plan on doing this? ; Patient: Probably a couple days from now. ; Patient: I have some things to get in order. ; Patient: I want to arrange things and make sure that everything's in order and then I'll do it. ; Therapist: What kind of things do you need to arrange? ; Patient: I want to make sure that all the documents my husband's going to need, that they're in a place that he can find them. ; Patient: I'm not going to tell him but I don't want to make things more difficult for him. ; Patient: Just that kind of thing. ; Patient: Make sure that everything's in order so that when I'm gone everybody has what they need. ; Therapist: Jill, you've been seeing me for almost a year now and you know by telling me this that I'm going to act to stop you. ; Therapist: I'm going to try to stop you from killing yourself. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I want to do it. ; Patient: I think in the end it's what's going to make things better. ; Patient: But I guess there's still a part of me that doesn't want to die, doesn't want to do that to my family. ; Patient: So I guess I'm telling you because I'm not 100% resolved and I guess I wanted to talk it over. ; Therapist: You seem pretty serious though about your timetable and your plan. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, it's like when you plan to go on a weekend trip. ; Patient: You're pretty sure you're going to go but if the weather's bad you might not. ; Patient: So I think, you know, I'm pretty sure. ; Therapist: Is there anything that can stop you? ; Patient: Um, I don't know. ; Patient: I don't, I think, I mean, I feel pretty sure about it. ; Therapist: Do you feel like it's the depression or something else that drove you to this decision? ; Patient: I feel like, I feel like it's just, you know, the same old things that I was worried about before. ; Patient: You know, the depression and, you know, my relational issues, my job, like the stuff that gets me down. ; Patient: And, you know, it just clicked and it was like, you know, I've thought about it before but like I feel like I'm going to feel better. ; Patient: I feel like it's just going to, I'm going to feel better so. ; Therapist: As you said, it's a solution. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I feel like you come with a solution. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright, now we've talked about this issue in the past, right? ; Therapist: And when you've come in feeling this way, kind of resolved to harm yourself, we sent you over to the hospital. ; Therapist: I know that's not your favorite place but when you go there for however long, it's been usually about five days, you come out feeling a lot better. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you feel like this time would be different? ; Patient: Well, I feel like in the past, you know, I've been thinking about killing myself seriously but now I'm not as scared of it. ; Patient: So I don't really want you to put me in the hospital because then I won't be able to do it. ; Patient: And before I was scared so I wanted you to put me in the hospital but now I just want to get it over with and so I really don't want you to do that. ; Therapist: So, like, it's like a part of you saying that you don't want me to stop you but yet you came in here and you told me. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So a part of you seems to be maybe not quite sure. ; Patient: I guess there will always be a part of me that's a human, you know, that's scared to die and I care about you, you know. ; Patient: I know you're my counselor but like we've had a relationship and we talk about these kinds of things and I felt like I owed it to you to, you know, be honest with you about how I was feeling because we've had that relationship in the past. ; Patient: And so I guess I came here because of that and because I felt like I just wanted to talk it over, you know, before I did it because, you know, I come to you to talk about what I'm thinking and so I felt like this would help me like gain the final clarity that I needed. ; Therapist: Has it helped you gain any clarity? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I guess I see that you're saying that like I really need to go to the hospital. ; Patient: I guess I was hoping a little bit that you would be happy for me that I was feeling better but I think that you want me to go to the hospital so I don't know. ; Patient: It makes me think about whether it's the right decision, you know. ; Therapist: You mean the suicide? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Sometimes, you know, you've been with me like I said about almost a year now and you've been depressed much of that time and it's not unusual when somebody thinks they've found a solution to depression. ; Therapist: Even if that solution is something that I am against like suicide that their mood would become elevated because you see an end to the pain. ; Therapist: There's other things we can do and have done in the past to try to get you out of pain. ; Patient: But we have done them in the past and I didn't feel better and now I am feeling better so, you know, I just want you to accept that. ; Therapist: But I'm not going to. ; Therapist: It's my obligation that I'm happy to fulfill to try to keep you alive. ; Therapist: I've seen you this way before and I know it may not seem this way now but when you came out from the suicidal thoughts and the feelings you did well for weeks, sometimes months at a time. ; Therapist: You're seeing really just the darkest when you're in the... ; Patient: Yeah, but I'm feeling better now. ; Therapist: Temporarily. ; Therapist: Sometimes you feel you've found an end to the pain. ; Therapist: Which I understand. ; Therapist: I mean I understand you're feeling better but you're feeling better because you plan on killing yourself. ; Therapist: And we've talked about how devastating that would be to your family, right, to your friends. ; Therapist: You have all these goals in your life. ; Patient: Yeah, but I'm just torturing them with my sadness. ; Patient: I'm just making their lives miserable. ; Patient: I don't understand how it's going to help them for me to stay alive. ; Patient: You know, I'm worth more. ; Patient: They can have my life insurance and, you know, I won't make them suffer anymore. ; Therapist: So your logic is that if you end your life, you'll free them from having to deal with you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It feels like the right thing to do. ; Therapist: As you know, I mean, you've signed releases. ; Therapist: I've talked to your husband, your parents. ; Therapist: They repeatedly said that despite sometimes the challenge of dealing with your depression, they would much rather have you alive. ; Therapist: Why would they say that? ; Patient: I think that they're scared of the pain of losing me but I know that they'll feel better eventually. ; Therapist: So they'll get over the grief. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I understand. ; Patient: And I think that they'll understand that I needed this. ; Therapist: You know, I've been doing this for a while, right? ; Therapist: I think we've come to have a good relationship. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And I would hope that I've earned your trust and your value in my opinion. ; Therapist: Can I share with you something that I know about suicide? ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: You open hearing it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: There's a lot of ways that people die, right? ; Therapist: And it's really what eventually will happen to us all. ; Therapist: It's hard for me to imagine a way more devastating than suicide. ; Therapist: Meaning when somebody dies of an illness or a car accident or any other type of tragic accident, people grieve, right? ; Therapist: But there's usually not a blame assigned to that. ; Therapist: I mean, they don't feel guilty. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Therapist: They feel sad because they've lost the person but they don't feel responsible for that person's death. ; Therapist: Suicide is different. ; Therapist: When somebody commits suicide, their family and friends feel responsible. ; Therapist: They have no answers to all the questions that they have. ; Therapist: They can never get answers. ; Patient: I'm going to write them a note and tell them everything and tell them it's not their fault because it's not their fault and I just want them to be happy without me. ; Therapist: So you believe the note will take away all that pain? ; Patient: No, but I think that it will help them realize that they shouldn't feel guilty like you're saying. ; Therapist: It will mitigate that pain? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I can tell you from experience that notes don't really help. ; Therapist: If anything, it's another artifact that they can agonize over. ; Therapist: I know it's hard to see from your perspective because you're kind of resolved to this and you feel stuck in the pain and you want out, but they will miss you and they will agonize for the rest of their lives because they lost you. ; Therapist: And it's a special horrible type of agony that comes with feeling responsible for causing someone's death. ; Therapist: And I know you don't want that. ; Patient: I just want to feel better. ; Patient: I just don't know why you can't let me feel better. ; Therapist: I know it's frustrating and I know it's hard to understand. ; Therapist: The times when you've gone to the hospital before, you have felt better. ; Therapist: Your outlook was completely different. ; Therapist: Not 100%, but it was completely different when you came out. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: I mean you're still a little down, but nowhere near the depression where you'd want to hurt yourself. ; Therapist: Is it possible that if you go to the hospital this time, you could come out feeling better again? ; Patient: Yeah, it's possible. ; Therapist: I'm going to make arrangements to get you over to the hospital. ; Patient: I don't want to go to the hospital. ; Therapist: I know. ; Therapist: I know you don't. ; Therapist: And we've had this conversation before. ; Therapist: I realize that you're not happy with some of the conditions there, but you usually talk finally about the groups. ; Therapist: You usually do well in the groups. ; Therapist: And typically, well every time you've been to the hospital you come out feeling better. ; Therapist: I know it's not what you want to hear. ; Therapist: I know you want me to be happy that you're going to end your life, but that wouldn't make me happy. ; Therapist: That wouldn't make anybody happy. ; Therapist: I know you think it would make you happy, but I can tell you it's not the answer. ; Therapist: I'd like you to go voluntarily through this process. ; Therapist: Will you do that? ; Patient: Go. ; Therapist: You'll go? ; Patient: Alright. ; Therapist: So I'm going to make arrangements to get you there. ; Therapist: And when you're there and they're getting ready to discharge you, make sure you set up an appointment to see me right away. ; Therapist: Because usually I'm going to keep you about five, maybe ten days at the most. ; Therapist: So I know they take care of this, but I'm going to ask you this too. ; Therapist: Make sure that you have an appointment set up to see me so I can see you right after you get out. ; Therapist: Can you do that for me? ; Patient: Alright. ; Therapist: I'm going to go make those arrangements and we'll get you over there. ; Therapist: We'll get you over there, okay?
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jill; sex- female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting clinic ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Suicidal ideations ; History: Past history patient had been experiencing similar suicidal ideations for which she was hospitalised for five days post which she felt better. ; Crisis Markers: Suicidal ideations; level of suicide risk severe ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative; mood depressed; affect restricted; thought reflected hopelessness ; Psychotherapy Type: Crisis intervention ; Psychotherapy Technique : Crisis response planning ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient discussed her hopelessness in life and that she wanted to end her life. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Patient will be admitted in the hospital for 5-10 days ; Next session details: Right after hospital discharge

dialogue: Therapist: Hello Alyssa. ; Patient: Hello. ; Therapist: It's good to see you today. ; Therapist: I'm glad you came to see me. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, tell me a little bit more about why you're here. ; Patient: Um, well I guess I have anger issues. ; Patient: I just find myself getting mad all the time. ; Patient: And uh, feeling all the trouble over it. ; Patient: People can't handle it so, I'm gonna come here for it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, which way did you come here for it? ; Patient: The courts. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Got it. ; Patient: So, yeah I'm not really, I don't really want to be here but. ; Patient: So, I'm not excited about being here. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, I hear that. ; Therapist: Well, what is your objective? ; Therapist: What do you want out of this today? ; Patient: Um, I mean I know, I'm probably a lot angrier than the average person. ; Patient: So, I mean people do a lot of things to make me mad. ; Patient: So, I guess that's like a better way to not be so mad all the time. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And maybe manage that a little bit better. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Tell me, um, is it school when you're getting mad? ; Therapist: Is it home when you're getting mad? ; Therapist: Is it friends? ; Therapist: So, tell me about that little bit. ; Patient: Um, just with my friends I'm cool. ; Patient: It's just definitely at home with my mom. ; Patient: We fight almost every day. ; Patient: And at school I get, I get the teachers. ; Patient: So, I get like detention and stuff like that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, before we get into this a little bit, I'd like to tell you a little bit about your brain. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Have you ever heard of the amygdala? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: When you get into high school, you're going to know about this in advance, but you're going to learn about this in high school science. ; Therapist: So, your amygdala is like right here at the base of your brain back here. ; Therapist: And it's known as the alarm center. ; Therapist: So, you think about pulling an alarm, you know, an alarm is going off in your brain. ; Therapist: And that alarm normally it indicates fight, flight, or freeze. ; Therapist: So, it makes you want to fight, fight back, right? ; Therapist: It makes you want to freeze, you just kind of panic, freeze, don't know what you do. ; Therapist: Or flight, which means get out of there, you know, get away. ; Therapist: Get away. ; Therapist: Alright? ; Therapist: So, that's kind of what your brain, that's the alarm system, that's kind of your brain. ; Therapist: So, let's think about some situations when you're in these angry situations. ; Therapist: And let's just kind of step through them. ; Therapist: So, give me an example, really specific of maybe two. ; Therapist: When the alarm is going off and you are really angry. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm definitely a fighter. ; Therapist: Okay, you're a fighter. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Patient: Because just thinking, just yesterday with my mom, she told me to do this, which I was going to do. ; Patient: I just wanted the show to end. ; Patient: She kept yelling at me to do it. ; Patient: And I didn't like the way she was yelling at me. ; Patient: And I just wanted to do like I was going to do it. ; Patient: Because she would just shut up about it. ; Patient: So, I mean it just pissed me off. ; Patient: So, I started yelling at her and she started yelling at me. ; Patient: And then a little brother came in, it was just the whole family. ; Patient: And everyone was just yelling at me. ; Patient: And I don't remember all the details, but I just remember I ended up punching a wall. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: That was just yesterday. ; Therapist: Okay, that was just yesterday. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So, the situation, mom asked you to do something, you were kind of in the middle of something, she got past your knee and you started yelling, she started yelling, it starts escalating, you punch a wall. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I got that situation. ; Therapist: Tell me about a situation at school where your alarm center is like going off. ; Patient: My history teacher, sometimes just looking at her, she just has this attitude, she's not walking in. ; Patient: And then, but I mean it's such a boring teacher, so I tend to sleep in class and I can't help it. ; Patient: And then she'll call me out for the whole class. ; Patient: And it just makes me mad. ; Patient: And we'll start going back and forth saying stuff and it goes, I end up cussing her out. ; Patient: And that's when I had to go to detention. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: I see. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you're in class, teacher's calling you out, and you're just wondering if a lot of anger and cursing get you in the nice place. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Jane, good example. ; Therapist: Is there any time when there's anxiety that's happening before the anger comes out? ; Therapist: When you're in bad anxiety. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Like maybe, yeah, if you ever get anxious where you just kind of freeze, or yours are more of a reactive of a fight, of a lash out, of a get it out. ; Therapist: That's kind of your response. ; Patient: I don't want to feel something, I have to get it out. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I can't even think of a time when I actually stop to think. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I think that's good. ; Therapist: Well, I want you to, it's kind of helpful, I think, to understand a little bit about what's going on in your brain, and then you can maybe help monitor it, help control it, help manage it a little bit better. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So let's, I'd like to take you through an example of something. ; Therapist: It's called, and it's a way of, it's called wise mind. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You're trying to be very conscientious about what's going on around you, how you're feeling, and how you're going to react. ; Therapist: Instead of just reacting, when that alarm goes off, you're going to think about it, name it, and then react. ; Therapist: Hopefully, maybe we can get a little bit more control on anger reactions coming. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And I need that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I don't want to see myself being too good at it, but. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, you know what, Alyssa? ; Therapist: Knowing that you need that, just saying, I need that, that's a really big step. ; Therapist: It really is. ; Therapist: Some people don't even acknowledge that they need it, don't want to acknowledge it, don't care to acknowledge it, and they're not going to really get any, not going to change. ; Therapist: But you're here. ; Therapist: Maybe you don't want to be here. ; Therapist: But I'm hearing you say that you want to make a change, and that's really huge, because I think you want things to be different for yourself, it sounds like. ; Therapist: I mean. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: But also, just watch people with something messing with them. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, there's a desire there, I see, and I appreciate that, and that's great. ; Therapist: And there are lots of different techniques for this, and I'm just going to offer one today, and then you can practice it all week, and then when we talk next week, we'll kind of see how you are with that, and if it's not working for you, we'll make modifications, we might change this, okay? ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And this is a technique where you can do it at school, at home, and it only takes about one minute. ; Therapist: Sometimes we don't have a lot of time. ; Therapist: You know, it's great when you can take 15 minutes to calm down, maybe you're going to bed at night, and you're doing something that makes you calm down, and it's quiet, but a lot of time, in the heat of the moment, we don't have a lot of time. ; Therapist: Or when you feel that anger rising, there's not a lot of time, all right? ; Patient: It happens. ; Therapist: It happens a lot. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: This little procedure is called STOP. ; Therapist: S-T-O-P. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: It's an acronym, S-T-O-P. ; Therapist: So S-T-O-P. ; Therapist: So it means, the first, the S, is to stop. ; Therapist: So, for example, you're watching TV, and your mom says, Alyssa, can you do this, please? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Right then and there, you're going to say, okay, stop, and then you're going to take a breath. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Therapist: You're going to breathe in, breathe deeply, and you're going to breathe out. ; Therapist: Just like take two deep breaths, and think about your breathing. ; Therapist: Breathe in, and breathe out. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Therapist: So the T is for take a breath. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: Take a breath. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And when you're taking a breath, think about, you know, your brain really needs a lot of oxygen. ; Therapist: So when you're breathing in, you're breathing oxygen into your lungs, gets into your blood, gets to your brain. ; Therapist: You're getting a lot of oxygen in your brain, which really helps you think better. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: So you're breathing in, getting that oxygen right there. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: The O means observe. ; Therapist: What is going on around you right now? ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: So in this situation, your mom asks you to do the dishes. ; Therapist: You're watching a program. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: You'd like to finish the program, I think I heard you say, and then you're going to do the dishes. ; Therapist: That's how you would like it. ; Therapist: It may not be how mom would like it, but you might be able to, if you can kind of get, observe the situation and how you're feeling. ; Therapist: I'm a little mad. ; Therapist: Mom just asked me to do it. ; Therapist: Doesn't she see I'm like watching a show here? ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: So you're observing how you're feeling. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: Watching the show. ; Therapist: I'm getting frustrated that she's asking me to do this right now. ; Therapist: Observe it, name it, claim it, and say, okay, that's how I'm feeling right now. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: So you're just aware. ; Therapist: You're observing the situation and how you're feeling. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Therapist: And then the, so the O is for observe. ; Therapist: And the P is for proceed. ; Therapist: That means move forward. ; Therapist: But something that's going to benefit you. ; Therapist: That's going to be positive. ; Therapist: That's going to work for you. ; Therapist: Yelling at your mom. ; Therapist: Is that working for you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Get you in trouble. ; Therapist: Get your hand in the wall. ; Therapist: You might get hurt. ; Therapist: Moving forward, yelling at your mom's not working for you too well, is it? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So we're going to proceed with something that's going to work for you. ; Therapist: In this situation, do you have an idea that might work for you? ; Patient: Um, I mean I just talk to her, but it's just so hard to talk to her without yelling. ; Patient: But I mean I guess if I stopped, I wouldn't be like quite so mad. ; Patient: So I just tell her that. ; Patient: I'm going to do it later. ; Patient: But I mean I see her get pissed off about that. ; Patient: I just want to get that out. ; Therapist: But it's a good idea though. ; Therapist: It's a good thought. ; Therapist: It might be worth a try to say. ; Therapist: And maybe it's more instead of telling her I'm going to do it later, saying, Mom, I've got ten more minutes with this show. ; Therapist: Here's ten more minutes. ; Therapist: I'm really interested in this show. ; Therapist: Can I just finish the ten more minutes and then I will do the dishes? ; Therapist: Kind of put it in a question. ; Therapist: So instead of saying, I'm going to do it later, say, I just got ten more minutes and I really want to finish this show. ; Therapist: Is it okay if I just do the dishes as soon as, in ten minutes when I finish this show? ; Therapist: Does that sound like something that maybe? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean that's what I said before, but I mean I was kind of, I probably won't have liked the way I was saying it and stuff like that. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah, I hear that. ; Therapist: Well, I'm glad you can acknowledge that. ; Therapist: That's really good. ; Therapist: That's a real big step. ; Therapist: That's a real big step. ; Therapist: So let's step through that one more time. ; Therapist: S-T-O-P. ; Therapist: The S is for? ; Patient: Stop. ; Therapist: Yeah, all right, stop. ; Therapist: Before you react, before you respond in anger, you're just going to stop. ; Therapist: What's the T? ; Patient: Take a breath. ; Therapist: Exactly. ; Therapist: Take a breath. ; Therapist: You're getting oxygen into your brain. ; Therapist: So you can think clearly, rationally. ; Therapist: Take two big breaths. ; Therapist: Three, maybe. ; Therapist: O. ; Patient: Observe. ; Therapist: Observe. ; Therapist: What's going on? ; Therapist: What's going on in my body, what are my thoughts, what's the situation? ; Therapist: You know, how am I feeling right now? ; Therapist: Name it, claim it, okay? ; Therapist: I'm going to press read in here. ; Therapist: I'm going to finish this. ; Therapist: All right, and then what's the P? ; Patient: Proceed. ; Therapist: Proceed, that's right. ; Therapist: Proceed. ; Therapist: How am I going to go forward in a way that's going to be helpful to me or good for me or benefit me, right? ; Therapist: So what, in that situation, what's the P going to be? ; Therapist: What's the proceed going to be? ; Therapist: How are you going to proceed? ; Patient: Just top of my mind, like a calmer. ; Therapist: Yeah, in a calm voice. ; Therapist: Ask her, as soon as this program is over, can I do it, mom? ; Therapist: I really want to finish this, then I promise you I'll do the dishes as soon as this program is over. ; Patient: Yeah, I'll do it with a compromise. ; Therapist: Yeah, there you go. ; Therapist: There you go. ; Therapist: In that situation, very good. ; Therapist: You're getting a little bit what you want, she's going to get what she wants, it's a great compromise. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Worth a shot? ; Therapist: Worth a try? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I'm just one. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: You know, it takes a lot of time to make a change. ; Therapist: It really does. ; Therapist: You've been doing it one way for a long time, and it takes a lot of time to do something different. ; Therapist: So I want you to be patient with yourself. ; Therapist: I want you to try this every day, all right? ; Therapist: And if you can kind of make notes for me, as we can talk about next week, like on Monday I had a fight with my mom, I tried it, it didn't work. ; Therapist: On Tuesday I had a fight with my mom, it worked a little bit, you know. ; Therapist: And the more you do this, the better you're going to get, and the more it's going to benefit you. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: The more it's going to benefit you. ; Patient: Yeah, I see it being a little struggle in the beginning. ; Therapist: Absolutely right. ; Patient: Just the way we talk with each other, it's hard to just stop and zone out and stuff. ; Therapist: You're right. ; Therapist: You're right. ; Therapist: Because there's a certain way in the house, and it's going to be, yeah, be patient with yourself. ; Therapist: And realize this is going to take some time, okay? ; Therapist: Let's think about at school, a situation, if you wanted to take that one situation at school, too, okay? ; Therapist: Say you're in history class. ; Therapist: You're in history, but you don't get along so well. ; Therapist: You're in your history class, and she's calling on you, right? ; Therapist: This is when you get angry. ; Therapist: Is that correct about that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: How can I stop when she's calling on me? ; Patient: Like I had to answer that. ; Therapist: Now, is she asking you, so is she saying, okay, Alyssa, tell me the answer to this question? ; Therapist: Is that what she's calling? ; Therapist: Or is she saying Alyssa, wake up, because you're asleep? ; Therapist: What is she saying? ; Patient: Yeah, she wants to trick me because she knows I was sleeping and not paying attention, so she asks me that thing, ; Patient: took a question, and obviously I don't know. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You're going to step through this stop process with that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So your teacher's going to ask you, Alyssa, why don't you tell us about that? ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: Instead of what's the normal reaction for you? ; Therapist: Your alarm center going off. ; Therapist: What's the normal reaction for you? ; Patient: I don't know, teacher. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You're going to try to stop. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: You're going to take a breath. ; Therapist: Two breaths. ; Therapist: You're going to say, all right, how you feeling at that point? ; Therapist: She's embarrassing me. ; Therapist: I don't know. ; Therapist: What else is going on? ; Patient: Angry. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Angry. ; Therapist: She knows I don't know. ; Therapist: She's just trying to test me. ; Therapist: She knows I don't know the answer because I'm asleep. ; Patient: Yeah, she just knows. ; Patient: She's been calling, but she's just messing with me. ; Patient: She's just messing with me. ; Therapist: So it's frustrating. ; Therapist: Exactly. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So you're naming that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I'm frustrated. ; Therapist: She doesn't know the answer. ; Therapist: Why is she calling me? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You're observing what's going on in the situation, but how are you going to proceed in a positive way? ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: Instead of yelling and getting sent out of the room, can you think of a way that might benefit you more? ; Therapist: It might be to your advantage. ; Therapist: Getting out of the room and going down the hall is not helping you too much. ; Therapist: So what's a way you can proceed? ; Therapist: You are frustrated. ; Therapist: You are maybe a little bit embarrassed. ; Therapist: You maybe don't know the answer. ; Therapist: What can you do instead of yell at that teacher and get angry at her? ; Therapist: What are the other thoughts maybe? ; Patient: This is just how I don't know. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I don't know what to say. ; Therapist: Well, that's the truth. ; Therapist: You might know or you may not know, but that's the truth. ; Therapist: You can say just simply that. ; Therapist: I don't know. ; Therapist: Then she's going to go to somebody else, right? ; Patient: Maybe. ; Therapist: Maybe? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: That would be the hope that she goes to somebody else. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: But for you, you won't be sent out of the room. ; Therapist: You won't be getting in trouble. ; Therapist: You won't be in ISS for the day and missing out. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: One objective I want for you in school is for you to get to the next grade. ; Therapist: Get to the next grade. ; Therapist: You've got to be in that classroom. ; Therapist: Learn a little bit so you can get to the next grade. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm going to want to. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: You've got a desire to do that. ; Therapist: So this procedure only takes 45 seconds or so for you to stop, take a few breaths, observe what's going on, kind of name your emotions. ; Therapist: Okay, I'm this and this and this. ; Therapist: However, don't want to respond with angry words or yelling or cursing because it's not going to benefit me. ; Therapist: Trying to make a change here. ; Therapist: Then I'm going to figure out what is my best tool to proceed that's going to help me. ; Therapist: Work out an arrangement with mom or just tell the teacher you don't know. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And again, be patient with yourself because this type of change takes a while. ; Patient: Yeah, it's probably going to take a while. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Are you willing to maybe practice this once a day, every day? ; Therapist: It can either be at home or it can be in the classroom this next week? ; Patient: Yeah, I know something comes up and it's open to all school models. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm going to just try it and see how it works. ; Therapist: If this, I have a lot of tricks up my sleeve, so if this one isn't working, we can modify it or we can try something else. ; Therapist: But try this every day and then we'll just kind of talk about it next week and just kind of see how it's going. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Listen, I appreciate you wanting to make change and willing to do something about that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: All right.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name alyssa; sex female; occupation student ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Increased anger ; History: Patient has been experiencing increased anger from quite some time which makes her end up in difficult situations. She recently had a heated argument with her mother where gradually whole family stepped in and started yelling at her which made her so furious and she punched the wall. She once slept in one of her classes at school post which she had an argument with the teacher and she ended up abusing her in front of everyone. She got a detention from the school due to this incident. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour patient was cooperative and rapport could be established ; Psychotherapy Type: Type mbct; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Psychoeducation, stop technique ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients anger issues were discussed and she was psychoeducated about bodys biological mechanism of anger along with stop technique to practise. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : To maintain a diary writing her everyday experiences ; Next session details: After 1 week

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Julie, how are you? ; Patient: Hi, I'm good thanks. ; Therapist: I'm Natasha, welcome to the service. ; Patient: Nice to meet you Natasha. ; Therapist: Nice to meet you too. ; Therapist: Do you want to have a seat? ; Therapist: Thank you for coming today. ; Therapist: How did you get here? ; Therapist: Did you travel by car or train? ; Therapist: How did you find the traffic? ; Patient: Yeah, I drove today and the traffic wasn't too bad actually. ; Patient: I got here in about 15 or 20 minutes. ; Patient: Oh, that's good. ; Patient: I was held up. ; Patient: There was a big smash on the road so it took me a little bit longer. ; Therapist: So I'm glad that you were able to make it in. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: Julie, I'm glad that you've made the effort to come in today. ; Therapist: How did you hear about our service? ; Patient: Well, I was talking to a friend and saying that I thought I might benefit from having a chat to somebody. ; Patient: And she told me that one of her friends had actually come to your service before and said that it was very good. ; Therapist: Excellent. ; Therapist: Well, thank you for coming in. ; Therapist: When you came in, you filled out some forms, which the girls have given me, which is great. ; Therapist: So that gives me a little bit of a background to where you're from and things of that nature. ; Therapist: And I just wanted to start by saying that our service is a counselling service for women. ; Therapist: And therefore you fit that category, which is really good. ; Therapist: Now, I just wanted to let you know that this is our first initial interview, I guess. ; Therapist: So today we will be just setting some, I'll be hearing some of your story. ; Therapist: And we'll work through a little bit of a process. ; Therapist: And then I'm sure we'll get the opportunity to meet again. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: That sounds good. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Excellent. ; Therapist: Now, within the pack that I've given you, or the girls at the front have given you, Julie, there is some information on how we keep your privacy and confidentiality. ; Therapist: So I just wanted to clarify that before we go into our session today. ; Therapist: So within the community centre here, we do, everything that you say to me today is kept within a confidential environment. ; Therapist: However, I am a mandatory reporter, which means that if you tell me something that I feel that you may be at risk, or you may be at risk of harm to yourself or hurting someone else. ; Therapist: If you have children, if they may be at risk, or if you're participating in illegal activity, I am a mandatory reporter, and I will need to let somebody know about that so that we can try to get you some help and assistance in dealing with that particular situation. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Yes, that's fine. ; Patient: I understand. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: Excellent. ; Therapist: So Julie, let's just start by, what has brought you here today? ; Patient: Well, my husband and I have been fighting on and off the last couple of months, and I'm just noticing that we can't seem to come to any agreement lately. ; Patient: I'm losing sleep, I'm feeling exhausted, and I'm at a point where I feel like I might like to leave the marriage. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How long have you been married for? ; Patient: We've been together for eight years. ; Therapist: Oh, wow. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's a decent amount of time. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And do you have any children? ; Patient: Yes, we have three children. ; Patient: I have two little ones that are under five, and we have a seven-year-old who's at school. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you must be kept busy then? ; Patient: I'm always very busy. ; Patient: There's just always so much to do, and I'm really feeling very tired. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And the children today, whereabouts? ; Therapist: Who's looking after them today for you? ; Patient: Well, my two younger children today are being cared for by my mum, and my oldest one is at school today. ; Therapist: Excellent. ; Therapist: And where's your husband today? ; Patient: He's gone to work. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: So it seems as if you're at a point in your marriage where you're feeling as if the marriage has changed a little bit, and it's focused, and you're kind of a little bit worried about what the future holds for yourself and your husband. ; Patient: I am. ; Patient: I feel now that I can't come to any solution with the problems, and he's been drinking a lot, and he always enjoyed a social drink when we first got married, but I'm noticing now that he's drinking more and more. ; Patient: He seems to be drinking most days of the week, and when he does drink, he's very, very difficult to talk to. ; Therapist: So the alcohol seems to be a problem. ; Therapist: Do you think that might be relating to the changing behaviour that you mentioned earlier? ; Patient: Yes, I do. ; Patient: I think that the drinking has definitely changed his behaviour significantly, and he's very unreasonable, and he has a very short fuse. ; Patient: He's very, very easy to make angry over the smallest of things. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: So that must be difficult for you and the children. ; Therapist: Have you noticed if the children have picked up on the change in his behaviour? ; Patient: Well, he does have a very good relationship with the children, and he actively participates in their daily lives, and the children haven't mentioned anything to me, and they don't seem to have changed their behaviour in any way. ; Patient: The arguments don't tend to happen in front of the children either. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Are the arguments something that... ; Therapist: Is it over more trivial things, or are there big, key things that you're kind of arguing with him about? ; Patient: Well, the arguments can start over something small. ; Patient: It can be just a simple argument over a task in the house. ; Patient: That can escalate into an argument about his family, or about my mother, or about money issues, and it just seems to escalate out of control. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So, Julie, have you... ; Therapist: In terms of his drinking, I'm kind of just trying to ascertain maybe what has developed in your marriage that's taken you to the point that potentially, you know, you've come to see me today. ; Therapist: And it appears as if the drinking is really the focus of perhaps your feeling of, you know, wanting to disconnect from the marriage and feeling isolated within the marriage. ; Therapist: Would that be right? ; Patient: That's true. ; Patient: That's right. ; Patient: I think the drinking is my main issue with his behaviour, and I think the drinking is greatly contributing to the way that he's behaving towards me. ; Therapist: Have you spoken to him about this? ; Patient: I have. ; Patient: I've tried to talk to him about the drinking a couple of times, and he just gets very, very defensive with me. ; Therapist: Potentially he's not acknowledging then that he may have a drinking problem. ; Patient: That's true. ; Patient: That's correct. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: I can understand that this must be difficult for you, Julie, and I'm pleased that you've come here today to try to, you know, work through some of these issues. ; Therapist: Now, Julie, in terms of, I guess, your commitment to the marriage, in terms of where you want the marriage kind of to go, do you think that you have a strong base that you can potentially, you know, if we were able to help your husband with the drinking side of things, that your marriage itself might be strong enough to overcome and to move forward in the relationship? ; Therapist: Or, you know, tell me a little bit about what your thoughts are with that. ; Patient: Well, I'm hopeful that we could resolve the issues that we're having, and although at the moment I feel like I need to break away from him, if he was able to get the support that he needed and we were able to get the support together, I think that I would be willing to give the marriage an opportunity to continue and to resolve our issues. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Julie, in terms of your own support, you mentioned your mum's looking after the children today. ; Therapist: Do you... Would you consider yourself to have friends and family that you... ; Therapist: You know, have you spoken to anyone else about this issue? ; Patient: Well, I have. ; Patient: I spoke to my girlfriend who recommended your service, and she's a very good support to me and to the children. ; Patient: And I have a very supportive family network as well. ; Patient: I have sisters who live in Sydney and also my mum, so they're all around me and they're very, very caring towards me. ; Therapist: Have any of those... ; Therapist: Any of the family or friends noticed a change in your husband's behaviour? ; Patient: Yes, they have. ; Patient: Actually, recently we had a social function and my brother did comment to me on how much alcohol my husband consumed at this social event. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So this is impacting on you as well as the, I guess, the extended family as well. ; Therapist: Well, it's really good to hear that you do have a support network outside of this room, I guess, which is really, really good. ; Therapist: And it's great that you've got that, and I'd encourage you to use your mum and your family and friends, you know, as a gentle ear to listen, to, you know, to help you support yourself and the children through this phase or this stage in your relationship with your husband. ; Therapist: So, Julie, I'm just trying to think about potentially... ; Therapist: Just to recap, so you're saying that your relationship with your husband has changed from what it was. ; Therapist: You've been with him for about eight years and you have got three children. ; Therapist: You've mentioned that the primary changes his behaviour and that you believe that it probably is linked to his change in drinking habits. ; Patient: That's right. ; Therapist: And from what I understand, you've expressed that you would be happy to potentially work with him to resolve or seek help for him in relation to his drinking habits. ; Therapist: How old do you... Would that be right in what I've said there? ; Patient: Yes, that's right. ; Patient: That's correct. ; Patient: I would be happy to work on things if he was willing to do that as well. ; Therapist: Not knowing your husband, I guess I would probably need to ask you if... ; Therapist: Do you think that your husband would be receptive to maybe some marriage counselling or going to see somebody about his drinking? ; Therapist: Is he the type of person that might be receptive to that or...? ; Patient: I think he would. ; Patient: I think if I was able to approach him when he was calm and relaxed, I think that, yes, he probably would be receptive to that. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: That's positive. ; Therapist: That's really good, because some people that I meet, you know, the answer to that would be quite different. ; Therapist: So I think that's really positive for you, Julie. ; Therapist: I think what we probably need to look at now is maybe continuing this relationship between you and I. ; Therapist: So I'd love to see you again and meet up with you again. ; Therapist: But also, too, I think we probably need to explore that avenue of either getting you some marriage counselling or something along those lines, as well as seeing whether or not your husband might be interested in looking at some services to help him with his drinking issues that he has. ; Therapist: So if it's OK by you, what we might do from here is organise for us to meet again. ; Therapist: What time is best for you? ; Patient: Around this time is a good time for me, and any Thursday or Friday during the day is good. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So what we'll do is we'll organise maybe for this time next week, and we'll meet again. ; Therapist: But in the meantime, I think we probably need to put you in contact with a relationships counsellor, and we'll try to get that side of things going. ; Therapist: And as a result of that, we'll be able to work out how receptive your husband is of potentially seeking some help for him as well. ; Therapist: I would like to just say that you mentioned that you probably would like to escape a little bit from it at the moment. ; Therapist: So perhaps I might be able to give you some advice or some information on some things that you might be able to do to take yourself away from that situation. ; Therapist: If you feel as if it's a little bit too much, maybe you might like to tap into your mum or your family and friends as well if you don't feel comfortable using some of the other services in the area. ; Therapist: How do you feel about that? ; Patient: That would be good. ; Patient: I'd appreciate that. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Well, thank you, Julie, for taking the time. ; Therapist: I'm really happy that you were able to come in today, and I look forward to going on this journey with you. ; Therapist: It's not a solution. ; Therapist: We can't fix everything here today. ; Therapist: It will be a process. ; Therapist: But hopefully together we can see a really positive outcome for you and your family. ; Patient: Thank you very much for talking to me today. ; Patient: That's been great. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: And I look forward to seeing you next week. ; Patient: Thank you very much.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name; julia, sex female ; Referral Information : Friend referred her to the counselor ; Therapist Information : Name; natasha ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms exhaustion chief complaints 1 sleeplessness 2 conflicts ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech, mood  affect depressed, judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in the session 1 problem patient has problems in her marriage characterized by frequent arguments and unresolved conflicts and her husbands increasing alcohol consumption. 2physical symptoms feels exhaustion and sleeplessness due to the ongoing conflicts. 3 technique therapist validates patients feelings, and marriage counseling, and support for her husband regarding his drinking problem. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Cmd  not clear ; Action Plan : Therapist advised he to put in contact with a relationships counsellor ; Next session details: Next week

dialogue: Therapist: Alright, so let's, if we could, let's rank those two things. ; Therapist: Right, so one is everyone is judging me. ; Therapist: They saw how I was. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And the other is a poor grade. ; Therapist: Which one is a larger fear for you? ; Patient: I would say maybe like judging. ; Therapist: Okay, so the grade's a concern. ; Patient: Yeah, but I figure I could do better on the subsequent one. ; Patient: But when people have this opinion of you, I feel like that doesn't go away as quickly. ; Therapist: Alright, um, and what would it mean if they, they thought you were anxious during that presentation? ; Patient: I guess I worry that they would think I'm anxious because I don't know what I'm doing or I don't belong there. ; Therapist: Okay, I don't belong there. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So if they notice you were anxiety, then they think you don't belong at that level. ; Patient: Yeah, like I don't deserve to be in that program. ; Therapist: I don't deserve to be in that program. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If they don't recognize those symptoms, they wouldn't think that, but if they do, that's ; Therapist: what they might think. ; Patient: Right, like maybe they think that's why I'm anxious or that's why I'm not doing well. ; Therapist: Well, how do you feel about your abilities and status in the program you're in? ; Patient: I think, you know, typically I'm one of the top students in my program and I seem to get the concepts pretty well. ; Patient: It's just when I have to demonstrate those concepts or demonstrate via like a presentation or something that I'm worried that, you know, maybe I'm an imposter or something. ; Patient: But, so I start to question myself. ; Patient: But I think in general that, you know, I'm a pretty good student before this and I'm doing pretty well in the program. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're a good student. ; Therapist: You recognize that. ; Therapist: You have this one area where you don't feel like you do a great job. ; Therapist: That's presentations. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But in terms of grade, you really only had one bad presentation. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But grades aside, you're anxious and you're worried your classmates are going to pick ; Therapist: up on that. ; Patient: Yeah, exactly. ; Therapist: Okay, so if they thought you were, you used the word imposter. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So if they thought you were an imposter, let's just say that that was something they actually believed because of what's been happening. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What would that mean? ; Therapist: What would it mean to you if your classmates thought you were an imposter? ; Patient: Um, I don't know. ; Patient: Maybe I am. ; Patient: Maybe I don't deserve to be there. ; Therapist: I don't deserve to be there. ; Patient: Yeah, like maybe I shouldn't be in this program. ; Patient: Like maybe I should just drop out. ; Therapist: Alright, so if they believe, if they believe you're an imposter based on these physical symptoms and anxiety. ; Therapist: Maybe that means to you anyway, maybe that means you shouldn't, you are an imposter, you shouldn't be there. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What's it, what's it feel like to say that? ; Patient: Depressing. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I feel like I've worked really hard, you know, to get through, you know, at least halfway through my program and it really hurts to think that that would be true. ; Therapist: To think this whole time you've really been, you've been faking it. ; Therapist: You don't really belong there. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, I'd like to move a little bit into evaluating evidence if that's okay. ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: So in cognitive therapy we like to look at what's, you know, what we're feeling and what we're thinking and what's, what we can see, what's observable around us and, you know, that becomes evidence and then we analyze it, evaluate it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You're worried at some level, you're worried that you don't deserve to be where you are right now. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: That you're not good enough to be a student in this program. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What evidence supports that belief that you're not good enough? ; Patient: Now that I'm thinking about it here, I mean, there's not a ton to support it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: But in, on that day I can think of all sorts of, you know, things to tell myself. ; Therapist: Well, let's go there then on that day. ; Patient: So maybe like, I'm not, because I'm not prepared or because I'm messing up on, on the presentation that I'm going to get a bad grade and, you know, if I can't, if I can't speak in front of people, how am I going to speak in front of kids as a teacher, you know, one day that it will translate to something else. ; Patient: Like if I can't get past this. ; Therapist: So even if I survive the program somehow I might be bad at my job. ; Patient: Yeah.
