dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: Hello, Sarah. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm alright. ; Therapist: You're alright? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: I understand that you've come to counseling because you have a particular issue that's been bothering you recently. ; Patient: Yeah, I've been really stressed out at work. ; Patient: I'm getting to the point where it's really hard to handle things that are going on. ; Therapist: So work-related problems. ; Therapist: Are you okay talking about that today? ; Patient: I think I need to, yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So what I'd like to do in the beginning is kind of set a plan for our meeting today. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we can move off that plan if we need to, but I'd just like to start with that and give us some structure to what we'll be doing. ; Therapist: So first, and this is something I want to co-create with you, right? ; Therapist: So your input is extremely valuable to it. ; Therapist: I don't want to just lay it out and we follow it. ; Therapist: I want you to be an active part of putting this together. ; Therapist: So as I throw out some ideas, let me know if it's something that makes sense to you ; Therapist: or doesn't. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I'd like to start by having you explain in depth kind of what you're going through at work. ; Therapist: And I want to hear that story. ; Therapist: Then I'm going to look for some patterns in the way you're thinking and see if there's something that I recognize and all that, something I can point out that may help you a bit. ; Therapist: And we'll get more to that later. ; Therapist: And then to kind of, as we wrap up, move toward the end, maybe start getting some ideas of things you can do between sessions, between now and when I see you next time, that can help combat these symptoms, make you feel a little better. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that seem like a fairly straightforward agenda? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any changes or anything you'd like to make to that? ; Patient: No, I think as long as you think I can tell my whole story in enough time. ; Therapist: Well, we'll see. ; Therapist: We'll see. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You just kind of tell me what's going on as you feel comfortable. ; Therapist: And don't worry about the agenda, but just know that overall that's kind of what I'm thinking about for the structure. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And then as we wrap up, we'll set to make an appointment next time. ; Therapist: And like I said, we'll end up with some ideas. ; Therapist: I hope they can help you. ; Therapist: So let's get started with kind of your experience with all this. ; Therapist: So tell me about your job. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So I'm a caseworker and, you know, what I do, I usually go into people's homes and, you know, talk to the families, do inspections, that kind of thing. ; Patient: And, you know, I've been doing it for a while now, not too long, but about five years. ; Patient: And overall, I like my job and everything. ; Patient: But just, you know, something happened at work and it just really kind of, I just feel like one minute everything was fine and now it just feels like everything's really out of control. ; Patient: So, you know, I was just, you know, doing my normal job, making reports and everything like that. ; Patient: And, you know, I made a report about this family that I felt, you know, maybe the children weren't getting quite what they needed. ; Patient: They seemed malnourished. ; Patient: The house was really unclean. ; Patient: You know, I suspected that the parents were using drugs there and it's just really not a good environment. ; Patient: And, you know, it turns out that the kids were taken away and, you know, the family, it just, I'm like really freaked out, you know, maybe the kids aren't doing well. ; Patient: They're away from their parents. ; Patient: Even though it wasn't a great environment, I know that the kids really love their parents and it's just, it's really, really weighing on me. ; Patient: And it's become kind of like a really big issue at work, I guess, where like everybody knows about it and, you know, I just feel like I tore this family apart and I don't know if I made the right decision and I just, it's like, you know, I used to just, I used to be so confident in what I did and now I just feel like I'm second guessing everything. ; Therapist: So this is really stressful on you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, you like, so I make sure I understand, you like your job, but this, this dealing you've had with this particular family and what happened as a result of that dealing has just really thrown you for a loop. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's making me not like my job. ; Patient: Like I wake up in the morning and I'm like, I should just pretend I'm sick. ; Patient: I don't want to go, you know, I just feel like, you know, at night I'm more stressed out, you know, maybe I have an extra glass of wine and I just feel so on edge all the time. ; Therapist: So it's really drastically changed your work experience. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I used to enjoy going to work and, you know, feel fulfilled and now I just feel like I do not want to go at all. ; Therapist: So there's a sense of dread, anxiety. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you feel down at all? ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Patient: I think anxiety more so, but I definitely feel down. ; Patient: Like, you know, even on the weekends, sometimes I just wake up and I want to stay in bed and, you know, I just, I feel like I'm having a good time and then I remember what happened and it just brings me back to that place and I'm just, I don't like it. ; Therapist: It's not a good feeling. ; Patient: No.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sarah ; Therapist Information : Name dr grande ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms depression chief complaints stress, heightened anxiety, increased alcohol consumption, and difficulty relaxing. ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior cooeprative; mood  affect depressed, thought, perception distored, cognitive functions impaired, judgement poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging cognitive restructuring ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 introduction therapist brief her about the therapeutic work, introduces the session, emphasizing the importance of client participation and co-creation of the session structure. 2 problem patient expresses significant stress related to her job as a caseworker. Feels increased anxiety, guilt, and a sense of dread regarding her job. She feels persistently, consumption of alcohol has also increased and difficulty relaxing. 3 action therapist tries to plan to identify patterns in her thinking and develop coping strategies. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety and depression

dialogue: Patient: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Patient: I hope you find this video useful. ; Patient: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Patient: As always, thanks for watching. ; Patient: Hi, Hazel. ; Patient: How are you doing today? ; Therapist: I'm okay. ; Patient: Are you okay? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I know when we met last time for your intake, you were concerned about some presentations that you had to give at school. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: Do you want to talk about that today? ; Therapist: Yeah, so in school, I am in school for teaching, and we have to give presentations a lot, as you can imagine, on different things. ; Therapist: And so, it's something that's recurring. ; Therapist: And what happened was, I gave a really bad one one time. ; Patient: A bad presentation? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I wasn't feeling very well, and I gave, I think I was just really tired from studying all night, and I gave a really bad presentation. ; Therapist: And then, like now, ever since, like when I've tried to give subsequent presentations, I am just so nervous, and I'm up there like sweating, and like starting to forget what I'm going to say. ; Therapist: And I'm just like a fear of getting up there and having to get a presentation, because I feel like I'm going to vomit. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: So was there a time before, like recently, when you had to give presentations? ; Therapist: Yeah, I mean like before and earlier in my, like I'm towards the end of my degree, so throughout my program I have, I have a lot to do. ; Patient: And how did you do with those? ; Therapist: Pretty well. ; Therapist: I mean, I consider myself a pretty good student, so normally I do pretty well. ; Therapist: It seemed to come out of nowhere. ; Patient: So this presentation that you gave with the, where you received a poor score, maybe just an isolated incident? ; Therapist: Yeah, like I was saying, I wasn't, I wasn't feeling very well, I don't think, and it really hasn't happened. ; Patient: But that experience has still led to a lot of anxiety with subsequent presentations. ; Therapist: Oh yeah. ; Therapist: Like I'm worried about my grades suffering as a result and, you know, how well I'm going to do. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: So, would it be okay if we kind of step through the whole process of you giving a presentation? ; Therapist: Yeah, sure. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Is, before I start with that, is this something that leads to anxiety, like right now or other times or really just in that moment when you're presenting? ; Therapist: Mostly it's most intense in that moment and like maybe like leading up to it, like in preparation that I know that this is going to happen. ; Therapist: Like I always know when I'm going to present, like it'll be like, she'll, the teacher will say, oh, well, you know, you're this Thursday, someone else's next Thursday. ; Therapist: So the closer it gets to that event, the more anxious I am, like in anticipation. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So you start feeling anxiety a few days before presentation or? ; Therapist: Yeah, I would say a few days mostly. ; Patient: When does it start to get really distressing for you? ; Therapist: Like two days before or one day before. ; Therapist: Then I'm like, oh my gosh, like, am I ready? ; Therapist: Like what if I mess up? ; Therapist: You know, what if I get a bad grade? ; Therapist: All these like what ifs. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So, would it be okay if we step into this process and kind of break down the steps of the presentation? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: So let's say that you're taking, what's one of the classes you're taking now? ; Therapist: Early childhood. ; Patient: Early childhood. ; Patient: So let's say you have a presentation in that class a few days from now. ; Patient: It's just a normal presentation. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: So let's now move to two days out. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Where you would start to feel a little anxiety about it. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: What's going through your mind at that two day out point? ; Therapist: I would say like, am I prepared enough? ; Therapist: Like did I do enough, you know, to study or to write down? ; Therapist: Did I do enough? ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: So your thought is, did I do enough preparation? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Which leads to maybe I didn't is what I'm really thinking. ; Therapist: Like I'm not prepared enough as I should be. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I'm not prepared. ; Patient: I'm not prepared enough. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: So that's the thought you're having about 48 hours before the presentation. ; Patient: I'm not prepared enough. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: So kind of thinking about that thought and what happens afterward, do you have a reaction like any type of emotional affective, we call it affective reaction to that? ; Therapist: So at that point I'm usually like more like anxious, maybe like irritable a little bit, um, mostly. ; Patient: And that goes substantially unchanged, that feeling for how long? ; Therapist: Um, like the day before it like kind of gets more intense when I'm like nitpicking like, well, I forgot this or I didn't forget this. ; Therapist: And you know, remembering what happened last time when I didn't do so well and worrying about my grade, like more thoughts pop in my head of things that I forgot or what if sort of things. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: So the same type of thought, just more intense. ; Therapist: More intense. ; Patient: And the feeling is also more intense. ; Therapist: Yes.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sarah, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm alright today. ; Therapist: You're doing alright today? ; Patient: I am doing alright today, yes. ; Therapist: I understand that you've been having some symptoms and that's what has brought you into our agency. ; Therapist: Could you tell me about that? ; Patient: I've been having a lot of worry. ; Therapist: A lot of worry? ; Patient: Yes, a lot of worry on and off for about the past four or five months maybe. ; Therapist: About four or five months? ; Patient: About four or five months, maybe about six months. ; Patient: Just around four, five, six months. ; Patient: I just started back to school after being a stay-at-home mom for twenty years. ; Patient: The kids are all off to college now in a way. ; Patient: I decided why not go back to school, do something else now. ; Patient: It's just been causing, well I've just been being worried so much lately. ; Therapist: Alright, so a lot of worry. ; Therapist: Some are at four or five or six months it's been going a lot. ; Patient: Somewhere in there, four, five, six months. ; Therapist: Have you had this worry more days than you haven't had it in that last four to six months? ; Patient: I've had a lot of good days. ; Patient: I mean I've had some bad days but I've had a lot of good days too. ; Patient: So I don't know. ; Therapist: Not quite sure? ; Patient: Not quite sure. ; Therapist: Do you find the worry difficult to control? ; Patient: When I do or yes. ; Patient: Yes, very much so. ; Therapist: So I'm going to ask you some questions related to this. ; Therapist: Let me know if you've experienced these symptoms. ; Therapist: Do you feel restless, keyed up, or on edge? ; Patient: Yes, yes I do. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about, are you easily tired? ; Patient: All the time. ; Patient: So tired all the time. ; Patient: Yeah, all the time. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Do you have trouble concentrating or finding your mind going blank? ; Patient: I find my mind just wondering. ; Patient: Just going blank. ; Patient: I would say I'm going to go blank, yes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you find that you've been irritable? ; Patient: Very much so. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any muscle tension? ; Patient: Yes, just rigidness. ; Therapist: Tell me about how you've been sleeping. ; Patient: Not very well. ; Patient: I'm not going to say very well lately. ; Patient: I find it hard just, I can't go to sleep and I can't stay asleep. ; Patient: It's just been hard. ; Therapist: Do you drink alcohol or use any drugs? ; Patient: No, I don't. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a panic attack? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Any trauma in your history? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Any mental health disorders at all? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Do you find the symptoms very distressing? ; Patient: Yes, distressing. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: In what areas are they distressing? ; Patient: At home. ; Patient: So much at home. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm doing great in school. ; Therapist: School's okay? ; Patient: School's going high. 4.0. ; Therapist: Wow. ; Therapist: Very good. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Just at home, I'm just in a constant state of worry all the time. ; Therapist: How about when you go out with friends? ; Patient: Have fun. ; Therapist: Great times. ; Patient: Great times with my friends. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: I love going out. ; Therapist: Is there something specific to your home environment you think might be contributing to this because you don't have it at school, you don't have it socially? ; Patient: Eh. ; Patient: I mean, we have some problems here and there. ; Therapist: Some problems here and there? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Nothing you could isolate as maybe causing these symptoms? ; Patient: One of those maybe, maybe not things, but just nothing I can't work through. ; Therapist: Nothing you can't work through? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright, Sarah. ; Therapist: I'm going to get you in to see one of our counselors, if that's okay with you. ; Therapist: Just take a couple days for you to get in, get an appointment set and for you to get in. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: I would like that. ; Therapist: To see a counselor in a couple days? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'll get that set up and I want to thank you for answering these questions. ; Therapist: It's been really helpful to me. ; Patient: Thank you.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sherry, how you're doing today. ; Patient: Good, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Patient: Good, good. ; Therapist: Your brother brought you in today and he had some concerns about your mood. ; Patient: I mean he has but it's kind of weird because it's actually been great. ; Patient: It's been great. ; Patient: It's been great. ; Patient: I used to have issues with mood but I don't anymore and now I just, for the last couple days at least, maybe about a week, I don't know I haven't been paying attention but I have felt awesome. ; Patient: I've gotten so much done. ; Patient: I do stuff at work, I do stuff at home, I went shopping. ; Patient: I am doing great with, well kind of great with my interpersonal relationships. ; Patient: I was thinking about at work this week, I thought I was so proud of myself. ; Patient: Firstly I got a promotion and also I was happy with that but then another one of my coworkers, he had his birthday so I was like, oh let me do something nice for him and I went home and I baked him a cake. ; Patient: But it was kind of annoying because when I got there he got mad, which is stupid, because he said, he didn't appreciate the fact that it said over the hill but he's like old. ; Patient: So I thought it would be funny but it wasn't apparently. ; Patient: But so, yeah besides that this week's been awesome. ; Patient: Like I said I got my promotion and I made a lot of money with a nice increase I should say and I just, yeah so I've been feeling awesome, getting a lot done. ; Therapist: Yeah, I feel like you're getting a lot accomplished at work and at home and what types of things have you been doing? ; Patient: So there's a couple projects at work that I've been working on. ; Patient: I got all those done. ; Patient: And I, at home I have been working on unpacking because I moved in kind of a while ago but I still have boxes sitting around and stuff. ; Patient: So I got that all taken care of. ; Patient: I'm completely unpacked. ; Patient: Over the weekend I went and bought some home decor stuff so it really makes my house look just like I want it to look and I'm happy with it. ; Therapist: Alright, so your mood is up. ; Therapist: Your brother specifically had concerns about spending money. ; Patient: I mean he's worried because I went on a shopping spree. ; Patient: So he doesn't really know how much I am making with this new promotion and I didn't really want to tell him. ; Patient: I might actually because I'm proud of myself. ; Patient: I deserve it and I've worked so hard for so long at this company. ; Patient: So with the shopping spree I was kind of like treating myself. ; Patient: And so I went out and I did spend a lot of money. ; Patient: I actually maxed out one of my credit cards but I don't have a lot of bills right now. ; Patient: I paid off all my debts and I finished paying off my student loans too. ; Patient: So I could pay for it. ; Patient: So that's why he's worried. ; Patient: And I called him because I ran out of space in my car and I was going to try to put this table that I was going to buy on top of my car but it didn't have one of those things to attach it. ; Patient: So it didn't work out. ; Patient: And so I think he kind of got worried because he thought I was buying too much. ; Patient: But I returned that item because obviously I couldn't fit it in my car and he couldn't come help me. ; Patient: But besides that I've been fine. ; Therapist: Alright so you haven't gotten any trouble at work or at home or anything? ; Patient: No not at all. ; Patient: I mean like I said I got a promotion at work. ; Patient: My bosses are extremely happy with how productive I've been, how much I'm getting done, the quality of my work. ; Patient: I'm able to like look over the reports and everything I turn in several times before I do it and I always make sure I do. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Any changes with your sleep habits? ; Patient: Yes and no. ; Patient: I mean yes because I haven't really been sleeping as much as I used to. ; Patient: I think I used to sleep too much but like I haven't needed to this week. ; Patient: But it hasn't been an issue. ; Patient: It's actually been a good thing. ; Therapist: So how much did you sleep last night? ; Patient: Just about an hour and a half. ; Therapist: You feel rested? ; Patient: I do feel rested. ; Patient: I might take a nap later like a 30 minute nap but then I'll be fine. ; Therapist: So you have a lot of energy? ; Patient: I do. ; Therapist: Do you have any feelings of depression or anything like that? ; Therapist: Sadness, anything? ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Patient: I feel great, yeah. ; Therapist: You feel great. ; Therapist: Have you ever had anything like that? ; Patient: I have actually. ; Patient: In the past I was diagnosed with depression and so I know what it feels like and I know that I don't have anything like that right now. ; Therapist: How long ago was that? ; Patient: A few years ago. ; Therapist: A few years ago. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Any thoughts about death or dying or anything related to that? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Patient: I mean, no, I mean obviously you hear about people dying on TV or like friends and family members but I don't dwell on it. ; Patient: I feel like in the past I might have but I haven't been. ; Therapist: Any drug or alcohol use? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Therapist: How are you doing medically? ; Therapist: Anything medically going on? ; Patient: No, I'm healthy. ; Therapist: You're healthy? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And do you see or hear anything that, things that other people can't see or hear? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Therapist: Has it ever happened? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Alright, Sherry. ; Therapist: You answering these questions for me has been helpful. ; Therapist: I know that you're feeling well but I'd like you to talk to a counselor if that's okay. ; Therapist: I know that you're aware your brother's concerned. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: That's why I'm here for him. ; Therapist: You're here for him? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if it'd be okay with you, I'd like you to speak with a counselor at least for a little bit and I can arrange that in just a few moments if that's okay. ; Patient: That's fine. ; Therapist: Thanks. ; Patient: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sherry, sex female, accompanied by brother ; Therapist Information : Psychiatrist ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms elevated mood manic phase chief complaints impulsive spending, elevated mood, lack of sleep ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior excited; speech fast, mood  affect elevated, thought disorganized, perception delusional, cognitive functions poor, judgement and insight poor ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient feels extremely happy and productive over the past week, as compared to her previous history of depression. Sleep has reduced and impulsively shopping. 2 advise she is advised to speak with a counselor to further assess her mental health ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Manic episode ; Action Plan : Reffred to a counselor

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, I'm Jordan. ; Therapist: It's so nice to meet you. ; Patient: Hi, I'm Judy. ; Therapist: How are you doing? ; Patient: I'm pretty good. ; Therapist: Well welcome, sit down. ; Therapist: Have you ever been to a counseling session before? ; Patient: No, this will be my first time. ; Therapist: Well okay then, so just a little bit about us. ; Therapist: We're a counseling center and we work with people with a range of different things going on with them. ; Therapist: And between the two of us we can work through whatever is going on with you in your life. ; Therapist: But before we begin, I just wanted to let you know that everything you say here is confidential. ; Therapist: Unless you're intending to harm yourself or other people and then we're obligated to report it for their own safety. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yeah, that makes sense too. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So I also just want to forewarn you, today is going to be a lot of questions. ; Therapist: Just trying to get some background of where you're at and where you want to go. ; Therapist: Also, would it be okay with you if I write down some things as we talk? ; Patient: Yeah, that's totally fine. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So to begin, can you tell me a little bit about yourself? ; Patient: Yeah, like I said, my name is Judy. ; Patient: I'm 42. ; Patient: I have two kids. ; Patient: Max, who's eight years old, and Chelsea, who is six. ; Patient: Max plays soccer. ; Patient: He's very active around the home. ; Patient: Like almost too active. ; Patient: And Chelsea is a little know-all, but keeps me in line. ; Patient: And kids are both very active, pretty good in school, get along pretty well, and they're good. ; Patient: They're good kids. ; Patient: Sweet kids. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: I'm so glad. ; Therapist: So I'd love to hear what's been going on from your perspective and why you're excited to come here today. ; Patient: Well, I have a lot of negative stuff going on in my life right now. ; Patient: I've been very stressed lately because I lost my job pretty recently. ; Patient: It was a rough time and I haven't been handling it very well according to my husband. ; Patient: And he told me that I had to come to counseling where he would leave me. ; Patient: So that's why I'm here. ; Therapist: I'm definitely glad that you came. ; Therapist: When did you notice this change in yourself or notice that this was a problem? ; Patient: Well, I lost my job about a month ago. ; Patient: I got laid off a month ago. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it seems like losing your job has really affected your relationship with your husband and family. ; Therapist: You said you have two other kids, that you love with them, right? ; Patient: Yes, I have two kids Max and Chelsea. ; Patient: I love them a lot and we live all together, the four of us. ; Patient: The children are wonderful, but I feel like I haven't been a great mom recently to them or my husband. ; Patient: I think that's unfair to me. ; Therapist: So that leads great into my next question. ; Therapist: What's your relationship with your husband like? ; Patient: Well, we've had our ups and downs like every marriage. ; Patient: I spend a lot of time with the kids. ; Patient: He works a lot. ; Patient: He's not very close with the kids. ; Patient: But I'm not as close with my parents. ; Patient: I'm very close with my mom. ; Patient: And she's been there for me a lot in the past. ; Therapist: Interesting. ; Therapist: And how long have you been married for? ; Patient: Just seven years. ; Therapist: And what do you like to do in your free time with your family? ; Therapist: Do you spend time with them? ; Patient: Yeah, I go to the gym a lot. ; Patient: That's more of an individual activity for me. ; Patient: It's something that releases a lot of my stress. ; Patient: And that's kind of how I, I don't know, it's part of who I am. ; Patient: But with the kids, I like them and I drive them all over the place all the time. ; Patient: I like to practice, I like to practice everything. ; Patient: So there's not a lot of time for me to really have time with my kids. ; Patient: But I don't know, I like to, you know, we read together every night. ; Patient: I try to make time for the kids. ; Patient: And I take them to the beach when it's warm. ; Patient: You know, there's a lot of things that we do together. ; Therapist: Good, good. ; Therapist: Do you find you can draw support from your family? ; Therapist: You mentioned your aunt, but... ; Patient: Well, I don't really want to warn the kids because they think they're so young. ; Patient: And I think they know that something's up, but I don't really know to what extent they know. ; Patient: But I am closer to my aunt. ; Patient: She's always been there for me. ; Patient: But my husband and I have had a rough patch recently since I lost my job. ; Therapist: So, when you're stressed, you sometimes go to your aunt, but do you turn to people for comfort? ; Therapist: Or do you have an activity that helps you calm down or another method that helps you cope? ; Patient: Like I said, I have been going to the gym a lot, but I haven't been doing that as much recently. ; Patient: Maybe, I'm not really sure why I haven't made time for it. ; Patient: I haven't really felt like myself recently. ; Patient: But a lot of times, I turn to other things more than people. ; Therapist: What kind of things do you mean? ; Therapist: Like substances, drugs and alcohol? ; Patient: Yeah, I've never used them before, but I feel like it helps me relax, calm down. ; Patient: And a lot of times, it's something that I feel like I need to be, I guess, relaxed. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you find that's affecting your family? ; Therapist: Your relationships with them or the way you interact? ; Patient: It didn't for a while. ; Patient: But like I said, about a month ago was a turning point. ; Patient: And when I lost my job, I do feel very ashamed. ; Patient: I made a horrible mistake the other day. ; Patient: I can't believe I'm saying this, but I drove with them in the car after I had a few drinks and they got pulled over. ; Patient: I felt like I endangered my family. ; Patient: I felt like I was being a bad mom and that was a really big life to me. ; Therapist: That must have been pretty scary for you. ; Therapist: But if you think of it this way, it could be a turning point. ; Therapist: And you now notice what you're doing wrong and how you can improve it. ; Therapist: So it's progress that you're admitting that and that you do need to improve on certain things. ; Therapist: Do you take any other medications? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What medications? ; Patient: Oxycodone. ; Therapist: And why do you have a prescription for that? ; Patient: Well, I had surgery a few years back and I got fulfilled. ; Patient: I didn't really finish all the pills, but I've been taking them recently when I feel like I need to. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And how often do you take them? ; Patient: I've taken three over the course of a month, but I know that I shouldn't be. ; Therapist: How do you feel when you take them? ; Patient: It's numbing and it allows me to relax and escape from the issues in the home and workplace. ; Patient: I guess not really a workplace anymore, but I know that I shouldn't be doing what I'm doing and I know that it's wrong. ; Patient: And I guess that's why I'm here. ; Therapist: How has your family ever had a history of drug abuse problems and drinking? ; Patient: My dad, I think, was an alcoholic for a while, not really diagnosed. ; Patient: I grew up with a lot of that in the home. ; Patient: A lot of just genuine parents didn't mesh too well or a lot of infighting in the home. ; Patient: And the older I get, the more that I think that it might have been alcohol related on my father's part. ; Patient: My mother definitely not. ; Patient: My father though, and I believe that his father had a problem similar to that as well. ; Therapist: And is it the first time you found yourself turning to it? ; Patient: A few times in college I found myself depressed, confused about growing up, getting a career. ; Patient: I wasn't an addict in college, but I would do things with the intention of feeling better and forgetting. ; Patient: I think that's kind of something that's been beneath the surface for a while. ; Patient: When I find myself stressful, I can sink back into that. ; Therapist: Have you ever experienced any form of sexual assault or abuse that maybe made you turn to alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Are you having trouble eating or sleeping? ; Patient: Eating, yeah, not as much or as healthy as I have before, but sleeping absolutely because of stress. ; Patient: I find myself not sleeping as well. ; Therapist: Yeah, that definitely happens with stress. ; Therapist: And what's a typical day like for you? ; Patient: Well, lately my husband's been taking care of the kids more because of last week and the incident with getting pulled over. ; Patient: He doesn't trust me with the kids, which I guess they understand. ; Patient: He doesn't trust me to drive kids places because of last week, so he usually will take them to school and I'll make him late for work and that makes him upset. ; Patient: And there's an argument there. ; Patient: When I wake up, I'll have a drink, so I'm not too hung up from the night before. ; Patient: Then I watch my show, I get the mail, and usually there's a bill, so I have a few more drinks. ; Patient: And then I try to start dinner, but it's usually hard because I'm pretty intoxicated, but I start dinner and usually at the night is the letter of a shit show and the kids are frustrated and you figure it out. ; Therapist: And are you feeling sad or down in addition to being stressed? ; Patient: I'm pretty sad. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And when you're sad, do you turn to your faith? ; Therapist: Have you been praying a lot? ; Patient: Some I used to, but I don't as much anymore. ; Patient: It's hard to believe that somebody's watching over me with all this negative stuff. ; Therapist: Does other things give you hope besides your faith? ; Patient: The kids. ; Patient: Watching them play together and be together really gives me a lot of hope. ; Patient: I love seeing them do what they love to do and I love it when I know that what I do can enable them to enjoy their activities. ; Patient: But it's been hard to do that recently because I drive them to school, I've been taking them to activities because my husband's been doing this for me. ; Patient: So it's getting kind of empty-fills with them getting into the family. ; Therapist: Thank you for sharing that. ; Therapist: So we can start to meet on a regular basis and try to work through all these things together. ; Therapist: From what I've collected, from what you kind of just told me, you're really stressed about losing your job and so you want to find different ways to cope with your stress. ; Therapist: And then also try to rebuild the trust in your family, with your husband, your kids that they may have lost during the driving incident last week. ; Patient: Sounds a lot like what I want to do. ; Patient: I hope that you're able to help me with that. ; Therapist: So in order for this to be most effective, let's brainstorm some small steps we can work on. ; Therapist: Maybe make a list together and it can be very small unless it's not too overwhelming at first. ; Therapist: So for instance, to work on the drinking thing, we can start by cutting down the number of drinks slowly today. ; Therapist: And it can be really hard to just stop cold turkey because you can get withdrawal symptoms or it may make you even more stressed out. ; Therapist: So I want you to be able to be confident in the goal you're setting and in yourself. ; Therapist: So can you do one last drink each day or something like that. ; Therapist: So what would you like to achieve from our work together in the future, by the end? ; Patient: Yeah, I hear what you're saying. ; Patient: I understand. ; Patient: I guess I don't want to stop moving completely. ; Patient: But it sounds like a very logical solution at this point. ; Patient: It doesn't sound like something I'd be able to do at this point immediately. ; Patient: We can maybe get there. ; Patient: I'm not really sure if we can completely get there. ; Patient: And then after that, I'd really like to fix my relationship with my family. ; Patient: So if I go to my husband, we can patch things with my parents too. ; Therapist: So let's start with a goal regarding drinking. ; Therapist: What do you think is a reasonable thing for yourself? ; Patient: I can start having four drinks a day, maybe four maybe. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: That's a good one. ; Therapist: Then in a few days you can try having three, and two, and one, until you don't need to turn to alcohol for comfort, and so on and so forth. ; Therapist: If you need a different way to find comfort, you can try stress relieving activities. ; Therapist: So what would be a good activity for you to do? ; Patient: I think I could try journaling, maybe drawing or painting. ; Patient: I did a lot of art in college. ; Patient: I'd really like to get back into that and I would just call it a day. ; Therapist: That's a really great idea. ; Therapist: Then in the future, what are you thinking regarding your career? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I don't think anyone's going to want somebody as dressed up as me right now. ; Patient: What was your old job again? ; Patient: I was a staff captain. ; Therapist: Well, you don't need to jump right back into work again. ; Therapist: That can be a way in the future, or maybe a month or two. ; Therapist: If you think about it in the future, what would be your goal? ; Patient: I guess I'd like to get back in the game, but I think more important for me is that I patch things up with my family. ; Patient: But I do need to try making money again to support the family. ; Patient: It's not logical for me to assume that I can go a long time without it. ; Patient: That's why I want to fix my issues, get back in the job, and see what I can do. ; Therapist: What kind of things do you think could help rebuild the trust within your family? ; Patient: I could block out some time each week to really spend a long time with each of my family members, my kids and my husband. ; Patient: Kids I don't think really understand what's going on, so I don't have to work as hard with them, but I would still love to. ; Patient: I just really do need to work in relationship with my husband, go back to what things we used to do together, and see what we can do to get back there. ; Therapist: A way you could do that is try family therapy or couples counseling. ; Therapist: Would you be interested in something like that? ; Patient: Yeah, that's definitely something we could do. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So, I'm very happy that you came to talk to me today. ; Therapist: From what I heard, it sounds like losing your job has been incredibly stressful for you. ; Therapist: And you turned to substance abuse to try and relieve some of that stress. ; Therapist: Do you feel a little bit better after talking to me? ; Patient: I absolutely do. ; Patient: I feel like the weight has really been lifted off my shoulders, and the fact that somebody is going to be in charge of my recovery, I think is huge. ; Therapist: We'll definitely be working hand in hand, so you're in charge of your recovery, but I'm definitely here to help you along the way. ; Therapist: I really am looking forward to our next session together. ; Therapist: Me too. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So, until our next session, I want you to try and journal every time that you're feeling upset or like you need to drink, stress, and then bring your journal and we can go through and find the times you felt like you needed substance to help you. ; Therapist: And in addition to that, maybe try and cut back on your drinking, maybe one less glass or something of wine or anything for now. ; Therapist: And then next time, let me know how that goes. ; Patient: Yeah, I can totally make sure of that. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So, I want you to know that I really do believe in you and that you can get through this. ; Therapist: And if you continue to come to our sessions, we really can work together to accomplish these goals that we just discussed. ; Patient: Thanks. ; Patient: I hope so too. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Have a good day. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name judy, age 42, sex female, marital status married ; Therapist Information : Name jordan ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms substance use chief complaints 1 conflict with husband 2 stress 3 unable to stop alcohol consumption 4 sadness ; History: Substance use history her dad has a history of alchol consumption. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior normal; speech normal, mood  affect dull, ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listeningjournalingthought challenging. ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient is stressed due to losing her job and her subsequent reliance on unhealthy coping mechanisms such as alcohol and prescription medication which is causing her mental health problems. She has a history of alcohol consumption. 2 family dynamics she is stressed about her relationship with her husband n kinds. She is trying to rebuild trust and improving communication within the family unit. 3 goal setting the counselor set goals for her recovery journey, including reducing alcohol consumption, exploring alternative coping strategies, and working towards rebuilding trust in her relationships, emphasized the importance of seeking support. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Substance use ; Action Plan : Till next session, patient is asked to write journal every time when she is feeling upset or and then bring your journal which they can go through and find the times she felt like she needed substance to help her. ; Next session details: Session scheduled.

dialogue: Therapist: I just want to change gears again. ; Therapist: I want to talk about any potential trauma or abuse. ; Therapist: Are you comfortable with that topic? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You mentioned earlier there's been no occasions where you've had nonconsensual sexual contact. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: What about physical abuse? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about emotional abuse? ; Patient: I don't know if it really counts as emotional abuse. ; Therapist: Well tell me. ; Patient: My dad can be really intense about things and when you don't necessarily meet his expectations or bring home the grade he was expecting or if you're not as successful as your sister, he can be kind of harsh. ; Therapist: Can you give me an example of something he might have said? ; Patient: Like why can't you ever be good enough or don't tell people you're my daughter when you go out in public or I wish we had two of your sisters and didn't have you or they also switched you at the hospital because you couldn't possibly be part of this family, that sort of thing. ; Therapist: Fairly strong statements. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What's that feel like when he says things like that? ; Patient: I guess now I'm used to it. ; Patient: Before it was terrible but you just kind of grow numb to stuff like that. ; Therapist: You feel like you're numb to it now? ; Patient: I've heard it enough that I know it's coming so you just kind of get used to it. ; Therapist: Still got to be a little bit painful? ; Patient: Yeah, it is. ; Patient: But you can only hear things so many times before it's like alright well you're hearing the same stuff. ; Therapist: Is there ever been a change in your anxiety levels or your drinking when you would make comments like that? ; Patient: I think sometimes if he got off on a tangent or whatever and got really insulting. ; Patient: Generally I would need to blow some steam and I'd go out with my friends or whatever and I think that's when it started to get into the heavier drinking during that time because I would get anxious and stressed out and not thinking clearly. ; Therapist: Would you consider this a significant part of your history? ; Patient: I guess so. ; Therapist: I mean it seems a little upsetting to you to say the least. ; Patient: Yeah, it is. ; Therapist: Something maybe we can talk about later? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So I want to switch gears again a little bit. ; Therapist: What do you do for fun for recreation? ; Patient: Other than partying? ; Therapist: Well, okay, I'll put that in there. ; Therapist: Partying, that's one thing. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay, yeah. ; Therapist: So other than that? ; Patient: I like to shop. ; Therapist: Like to shop? ; Patient: And I like to hike. ; Patient: I like the mountains. ; Therapist: Hiking? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: When was the last time you were hiking? ; Patient: Two years ago. ; Patient: It's been a while. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What else? ; Patient: I like being out with my friends. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Or, um, like going to see live shows, like music stuff. ; Therapist: Okay, live shows? ; Therapist: Like theater or? ; Patient: Like music. ; Patient: Like bands and stuff. ; Therapist: Oh, okay. ; Therapist: Like music. ; Therapist: When was the last time you've done that? ; Patient: Probably a year. ; Therapist: A year. ; Therapist: Do you consider your life to be fun? ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Has it ever been? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I can think of instances that were fun. ; Patient: I don't know if I would call my entire life situation fun. ; Therapist: When was the last instance that you could remember? ; Patient: Like when I go out with my friends and blow up steam. ; Patient: That's fun. ; Therapist: So these little moments here and there. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But consistently, not the case. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I want to switch gears again and ask you about any type of, or any time in your life when you may have had suicidal thoughts or behaviors. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a time when you contemplated suicide? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Never? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And right now, it's not something you're thinking about? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: What do you think has protected you against having any type of suicidal thoughts? ; Patient: I want to succeed. ; Patient: I want to do more. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Now how about harm to others? ; Therapist: Have you thought about harming someone else? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Never? ; Therapist: What do you think protects you against that? ; Patient: I think I'm definitely a nice person. ; Therapist: Nice person? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you ever get angry? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Who doesn't? ; Therapist: But it's never translated to anything where you've had any desire to hurt anybody? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So you deal with anger pretty well? ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Again, some of these questions, I'm aware probably don't apply, but I want to go through them just in case. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Has there ever been a time where you heard or saw something that other people did not hear or see? ; Patient: Like a hallucination? ; Therapist: Like a hallucination. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Other than perhaps under the influence of alcohol, was there ever a time you felt out of touch with reality? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How would you describe your judgment when making decisions? ; Patient: When I'm sober or when I am? ; Therapist: When you're sober. ; Patient: I think it's pretty good. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Good judgment? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, my anxiety plays into it a little bit. ; Patient: But I think generally it's good. ; Therapist: And when you're under the influence? ; Patient: Not as good. ; Therapist: Not as good? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Any questions for me so far? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I've been asking a lot of questions, huh? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I know. ; Therapist: We're almost through. ; Therapist: I appreciate you bearing with me. ; Therapist: I'd like to talk about your goals. ; Therapist: And I want to talk about on two levels. ; Therapist: So your goals in life. ; Therapist: So these are like your general goals. ; Therapist: And then your specific goals for your time with me. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: So let's start with your general goals for your life. ; Therapist: What would you like? ; Patient: I want to get a job when I graduate. ; Patient: And I want to be self-sufficient. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I like to not be so worried all the time. ; Patient: Just be kind of more at ease in general. ; Patient: Maybe get my own apartment, live on my own, that type of thing. ; Therapist: Live on your own? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Any other life goals? ; Therapist: Any goals surrounding family or anything like that? ; Patient: Maybe figure out how to communicate better with them, I guess. ; Therapist: How about having your own family? ; Patient: Yeah, for sure. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If you think of any other goals later on, or answers to these questions of any nature, feel free to just add that in. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So we can go back and edit this and add to it. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about goals for treatment? ; Patient: The drinking is one. ; Patient: The anxiety. ; Therapist: Anxiety. ; Patient: Maybe try to graduate. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Graduating college? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What was that last part? ; Patient: Just getting through the last year. ; Therapist: Oh, yeah. ; Therapist: Surviving the last year of college. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Drinking, anxiety, graduating college. ; Therapist: Anything else that would be a goal of therapy? ; Patient: I think those are the big ones I'm really concerned about. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So if you could meet those three goals, you feel like the counseling would have been successful? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So one last area I want to cover with you. ; Therapist: What do you consider your strengths that are going to help you to meet these goals and to meet your life goals? ; Patient: I think I'm ready now. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You're ready? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: What else? ; Patient: I think I'm dedicated to getting better and dedicated to the future that I want. ; Patient: I'm a hard worker. ; Patient: I don't know that I would have made it this far if I wasn't despite everything else. ; Therapist: Hard worker. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: What do you think I'm pretty understanding? ; Therapist: Understanding? ; Therapist: How about intelligent? ; Patient: I guess so. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You guess so? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I never really thought about it. ; Therapist: Never thought about it. ; Therapist: How about social skills? ; Patient: I think I'm good at maintaining my friendships. ; Therapist: Do you think about the future a lot? ; Therapist: What your future is going to be like? ; Patient: Sometimes. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how does it look to you right now? ; Patient: Not the way I want it to look. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, we'll try to work on that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Are there any other questions that you want to ask me before we wrap up intake? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Patient: That was a lot. ; Therapist: What's that? ; Patient: That was a lot. ; Therapist: That was a lot. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: We did cover a lot. ; Therapist: As I mentioned, if you have any other questions about this at any time, we can come back to revisit this. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: We can add on to it. ; Therapist: And likely as we go through the sessions, I'll have even more questions. ; Therapist: Maybe not as intensely packaged all at one time like this was, but I'll have more questions for you. ; Therapist: And I appreciate you answering the questions. ; Therapist: I know some of them are probably a bit challenging to talk about. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So I'm going to finish this up, and I'm going to get you scheduled to see it in about a week. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's all I have for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Of course. ; Therapist: And we'll get started with the counseling sessions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right, Sam. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sam, education last year of college ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety chief complaints 1 emotional numbness 2 alcohol addiction 3 stress ; History: History of emotional abuse by her father ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior; nad speech nad, mood  affect depressed, thought negative; perception nad, cognitive functions impaired, judgement and insight intact. ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in the session 1 problem patient feels numb to repeated insults yet feels anxiety, particularly triggered by certain behaviors. 2 addiction patients has a drinking pattern, especially during periods of high anxiety. 3activities patient has stopped doing things which he used to like earlier like hiking, parting, and music shows etc 4 therapy goals securing a job after graduation, communicate better with family members, considering having their own family in the future. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety and depression ; Action Plan : Planned to start a counseling sessions. ; Next session details: Plan to start counseling session from next session onwards.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Alice, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good. ; Therapist: Doing good? ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you some questions and give you some problems to solve. ; Therapist: Please try to answer them as best as you can. ; Therapist: What year is this? ; Patient: It is 2015. ; Therapist: What season of the year is this? ; Patient: Beach season. ; Therapist: What is the date today? ; Patient: Tuesday. ; Therapist: What day of the week is this? ; Patient: Tuesday. ; Therapist: What month is this? ; Patient: It is May. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what country we are in? ; Patient: America. ; Therapist: What county are we in? ; Patient: We are in Kent County. ; Therapist: What city are we in? ; Patient: The Capitol. ; Therapist: What is the name or the address of this building? ; Patient: We are at Wilmington College. ; Therapist: What floor of the building are we on? ; Patient: Two. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I am going to name three objects. ; Therapist: After I have said them, I want you to repeat them back to me. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Apple, table, penny. ; Patient: Apple, table, penny, penny. ; Therapist: Remember what they are because I am going to ask you to name them again in a few minutes. ; Therapist: Now I am going to give you a word and ask you to spell it forward and backward. ; Therapist: The word is world. ; Therapist: First, can you spell it forward?
